We begin by noting that as the disk rotates, the mass experiences a centripetal acceleration that must be provided by friction. The maximum static friction available is

  f_max = μmg.

If the mass is to remain at rest relative to the disk, then the required centripetal force
  F_c = mω²R
must satisfy

  mω²R ≤ μmg.

Thus, the mass will slip when

  mω²R = μmg  ⟹  ω² = μg/R  ⟹  ω = √(μg/R).

When the mass begins to slip it loses its grip on the disk and leaves tangentially with speed

  v = ωR = R√(μg/R) = √(μgR).

Now, upon leaving the disk, the mass becomes a projectile. Since it is on a horizontal disk, it leaves with only a horizontal velocity and no vertical component. It then falls a vertical distance h under gravity. The time t taken to fall from height h is found from

  h = (1/2)gt²  ⟹  t = √(2h/g).

During the time t, the mass travels horizontally a distance

  d = v · t = √(μgR) · √(2h/g).

Notice that the factors of g cancel:

  d = √(μR) · √(2h) = √(2μRh).

Thus, the horizontal distance traveled from the point of leaving the disk is

  d = √(2μRh).

In summary, the final answer is

  \[ \boxed{\sqrt{2\mu R \, h}} \].

We are given a particle of mass m moving under the force
  F(r) = – k/r² + k′/r³    (with k > 0),
and we wish to work in polar coordinates (r, θ). We will work step‐by‐step.

────────────────────────
Step (a): The Lagrangian

For a particle in a plane the kinetic energy is

  T = ½ m (ṙ² + r² θ̇²).

Since the force is central (i.e. it depends only on r) we may define a potential V(r) so that
  F(r) = – dV/dr.
Thus,
  dV/dr = k/r² – k′/r³.
Integrate:
  V(r) = ∫ (k/r² – k′/r³) dr = – k/r + (k′/(2r²)) + constant.
We can drop the constant without loss of generality. Thus the Lagrangian is
  L = T – V = ½ m (ṙ² + r² θ̇²) – [ – k/r + k′/(2r²)],
or, more neatly,
  L = ½ m (ṙ² + r² θ̇²) + k/r – k′/(2r²).

────────────────────────
Step (b): Equations of Motion and Conservation of Angular Momentum

The Euler–Lagrange equations are
  d/dt (∂L/∂q̇) – ∂L/∂q = 0,
for each coordinate q.

1. For θ:
  ∂L/∂θ̇ = m r² θ̇   and  ∂L/∂θ = 0  (since L does not explicitly depend on θ).
Thus,
  d/dt (m r² θ̇) = 0.
This tells us that the quantity
  l = m r² θ̇,
called the orbital angular momentum, is conserved.

2. For r:
We have
  ∂L/∂ṙ = m ṙ   so  d/dt (m ṙ) = m r̈.
Also,
  ∂L/∂r = m r θ̇² – k/r² + k′/r³.
Thus, the Euler–Lagrange equation for r is
  m r̈ – [m r θ̇² – k/r² + k′/r³] = 0,
or
  m r̈ = m r θ̇² – k/r² + k′/r³.
This is the equation of motion for the radial coordinate.

────────────────────────
Step (c): Equation of the Orbit r(θ)

We now wish to eliminate time in favor of the angle θ. We start by introducing the standard substitution:
  u(θ) = 1/r.
Then, using the conservation of angular momentum l = m r² θ̇, one can show (by a standard derivation which we briefly indicate) that the radial equation becomes the following “orbit equation”:
  d²u/dθ² + u = – (m/(l² u²)) F( r = 1/u ).
Since
  F(r) = – k/r² + k′/r³,
when we set r = 1/u we have
  F(1/u) = – k u² + k′ u³.
Thus, substitute:
  d²u/dθ² + u = – (m/(l² u²)) (– k u² + k′ u³)
       = (m/(l² u²)) [k u² – k′ u³]
       = (mk)/l² – (mk'/l²) u.
Hence, the orbit equation becomes:
  d²u/dθ² + u + (mk'/l²) u = (mk)/l².
That is,
  d²u/dθ² + [1 + (mk'/l²)] u = (mk)/l².
Let
  α = 1 + (mk'/l²).
Since we assume that l² > – m k′, we have α > 0. Then our equation is
  d²u/dθ² + α u = (mk)/l².

This is a linear non‐homogeneous second order differential equation with constant coefficients. Its general solution is the sum of the general solution of the homogeneous equation and a particular solution.

The homogeneous part:
  d²u/dθ² + α u = 0
has general solution:
  u_h(θ) = A cos(√α θ) + B sin(√α θ),
or equivalently, we can write
  u_h(θ) = C cos(√α (θ – θ₀)),
where C and θ₀ are arbitrary constants.

A particular solution of the full equation is a constant value u_p such that:
  α u_p = (mk)/l²   ⟹  u_p = (mk)/(l² α).

Thus the general solution is
  u(θ) = (mk)/(l² α) + C cos(√α (θ – θ₀)).
Returning to r we recall that u = 1/r (so r = 1/u). Hence, we obtain the orbit in the standard form:
  1/r = (mk)/(l² α) + C cos(√α (θ – θ₀)),
or equivalently,
  r(θ) = 1 / [ (mk)/(l² α) + C cos(√α (θ – θ₀) ) ].

────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The Lagrangian is
  L = ½ m (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) + k/r – k′/(2r²).

(b) The equations of motion are
  For r:
   m r̈ = m r θ̇² – k/r² + k′/r³,
  for θ:
   d/dt (m r² θ̇) = 0,
which shows that the orbital angular momentum l = m r²θ̇ is conserved.

(c) Defining u = 1/r and letting α = 1 + (mk′)/(l²), the orbit is described by
  u(θ) = (mk)/(l²α) + C cos(√α (θ – θ₀)).
Thus the orbit is
  r(θ) = 1 / [ (mk)/(l²α) + C cos(√α (θ – θ₀)) ].

────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &L = \frac{1}{2} m \Bigl(\dot{r}^2 + r^2\,\dot{\theta}^2\Bigr) + \frac{k}{r} - \frac{k'}{2r^2}, \\
\\
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{Equations of motion:}\quad
\begin{cases}
m\ddot{r} = m r \dot\theta^2 - \frac{k}{r^2} + \frac{k'}{r^3},\\[1mm]
\frac{d}{dt}\bigl(m r^2 \dot\theta\bigr)=0\quad\text{(so that } l = m r^2 \dot\theta \text{ is conserved)}
\end{cases}, \\
\\
\text{(c)}\quad &\text{Let } u = \frac{1}{r} \text{ and } \alpha = 1 + \frac{m k'}{l^2}. \text{ Then } \\
&\frac{d^2 u}{d\theta^2} + \alpha\, u = \frac{m k}{l^2},\\[1mm]
&\Longrightarrow u(\theta) = \frac{m k}{l^2\alpha} + C \cos\Bigl(\sqrt{\alpha}\,( \theta-\theta_0)\Bigr) ,\\[1mm]
&\Longrightarrow r(\theta) = \frac{1}{\displaystyle \frac{m k}{l^2\alpha} + C \cos\Bigl(\sqrt{\alpha}\,( \theta-\theta_0)\Bigr) }.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to study how the emission and reception of two light‐pulses in one inertial frame S are seen by an observer at rest in a second frame S′ moving with speed v (with β = v/c) along the x‐axis. In S the light source (at x = 0) emits two pulses: one, P₁, at t = 0 and a later one, P₂, at t = τ. An observer in S′ (with coordinates x′ = 0 along his worldline) receives the first pulse at t′ = 0. We shall answer parts (a), (b) and (c) step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Arrival Time Interval in S′

Because the observer in S′ is not at rest in S, the reception times of the two light‐pulses seen in S′ will differ from the emission separation τ. (It is very important to note that the event “emission of P₂” is different from the event “reception of P₂” at the observer’s position.)

Let us use the following method:

1. In S the first pulse P₁ is emitted at (t = 0, x = 0) and it is received by the observer when their worldline crosses that light–cone. We choose the origins so that the reception of P₁ in S′ occurs at (t′ = 0, x′ = 0).

2. In S the second pulse P₂ is emitted at (t = τ, x = 0). Because light travels at speed c and the observer in S is moving along x = vt, the reception event E (the event where the second pulse meets the observer) in S is determined as follows. The light from P₂ propagates as
  x = c (t – τ),    for t ≥ τ,
and the observer’s worldline in S is
  x = vt.
Setting them equal (i.e. the light catches the observer) we have
  vt_rec = c (t_rec – τ).
Solve for the reception time t_rec in S:
  t_rec (c – v) = cτ ⟹ t_rec = τ·(c/(c – v)) = τ/(1 – β).

3. Now, having the reception event in S with coordinates (t = τ/(1–β), x = vτ/(1–β)), we wish to know the corresponding time in S′. The Lorentz transformation for time is
  t′ = γ (t – vx/c²),
with γ = 1/√(1 – β²). Thus, for the reception of P₂ we have:
  t′_rec = γ [t_rec – (v/c²)(v t_rec)]
        = γ t_rec (1 – v²/c²)
        = γ t_rec (1 – β²).
But note that
  γ (1 – β²) = (1/√(1–β²)) (1 – β²) = √(1 – β²) = 1/γ.
So that
  t′_rec = t_rec/γ = τ/(γ(1 – β)).

Since the first pulse was received at t′ = 0, the time interval (as measured at x′ = 0) between receptions is
  Δt′ = τ/(γ(1 – β)).

It is often better to write this result in “symmetric” form. Recall that
  γ = 1/√(1 – β²),
so that
  γ (1 – β) = (1 – β)/√(1–β²) = √((1–β)²/(1–β²))
which leads to the equivalent form
  Δt′ = τ √((1+β)/(1–β)).

Thus, an acceptable answer is:

──────────────────────────────
Answer (a):
  Δt′ = τ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)).

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Exact Expression for the Longitudinal Doppler Effect

From the result of part (a) the “period” measured in S′, T′, is
  T′ = Δt′ = τ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)).
Since the frequency is the inverse period, and if the frequency in S is f = 1/τ then in S′ the frequency is
  f′ = 1/T′ = f √((1 – β)/(1 + β)).
Because the speed of light is constant (c = fλ = f′λ′), the experimentally observed wavelength in S′ will be
  λ′ = c/f′ = c/(f √((1 – β)/(1 + β))) = λ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)),
where λ = c/f is the wavelength in S.

Thus we arrive at the exact Doppler formula for light (the longitudinal Doppler shift):

──────────────────────────────
Answer (b):
  λ′ = λ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)).

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Application to Hβ Emission from Accelerated Protons

We are told that protons are accelerated through a potential V = 20 kV. When they neutralize to form H atoms, they emit the Hβ line (with wavelength λ = 4861.33 Å) while drifting with constant velocity. The optical axis of the spectrometer is parallel to the proton motion so that the Doppler effect is purely longitudinal.

1. First, find the proton speed. A proton of charge q = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C gains kinetic energy
  K = qV.
Using V = 20,000 volts, we have:
  K = 20,000 × 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J = 3.204×10⁻¹⁵ J.
The kinetic energy of a non‐relativistic particle is also given by
  K = (1/2) m_p v²,
with m_p ≈ 1.673×10⁻²⁷ kg. Solving for v:
  v = √(2K/m_p) = √(2 × 3.204×10⁻¹⁵ J / 1.673×10⁻²⁷ kg).
Let us compute the argument:
  2K = 6.408×10⁻¹⁵ J,
  6.408×10⁻¹⁵ / 1.673×10⁻²⁷ ≈ 3.832×10¹² (m²/s²).
Thus,
  v ≈ √(3.832×10¹²) ≈ 1.957×10⁶ m/s.
Then, β is
  β = v/c ≈ 1.957×10⁶ m/s / 3.0×10⁸ m/s ≈ 0.006523.
We may round β ≈ 0.00652.

2. The exact Doppler formula gives
  λ′ = λ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)).
When β is small, we can expand this to second order in β. Writing the Taylor series for the square-root we have:
  √((1+β)/(1–β)) = 1 + β + (1/2)β² + O(β³).
Thus, to first order, the fractional wavelength change is
  (Δλ/λ) ≈ β,
and including the second–order correction,
  (Δλ/λ) ≈ β + (1/2)β².
Hence the observed wavelength is approximately
  λ′ ≈ λ (1 + β + 1/2 β²).

3. Now, plugging in the numbers:
  β ≈ 0.00652 and (1/2)β² ≈ 0.5 × (0.00652)².
First, (0.00652)² ≈ 4.25×10⁻⁵, so (1/2)β² ≈ 2.125×10⁻⁵.
Thus,
  λ′ ≈ 4861.33 Å × (1 + 0.00652 + 2.125×10⁻⁵)
    ≈ 4861.33 Å × (1.00654125).
Multiplying,
  Δλ = 4861.33 Å × 0.00654125 ≈ 31.8 Å.
Thus, the shifted wavelength is approximately
  λ′ ≈ 4861.33 Å + 31.8 Å ≈ 4893.1 Å.
Notice that to first–order the shift would be about 31.75 Å and the second–order contributes roughly 0.1 Å.

──────────────────────────────
Answer (c):
  To first and second order in β we find 
    λ′ ≈ λ (1 + β + ½ β²).
For Hβ (λ = 4861.33 Å) with β ≈ 0.00652, the Doppler–shift is 
    Δλ ≈ 4861.33×(0.00652 + 0.5×(0.00652)²) ≈ 31.8 Å,
so that
    λ′ ≈ 4893.1 Å.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers:

(a) Δt′ = τ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)).

(b) λ′ = λ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)).

(c) For Hβ with λ = 4861.33 Å and proton speed corresponding to β ≈ 0.00652:
    λ′ ≈ λ (1 + β + ½ β²) ≈ 4893.1 Å. 

Thus, in boxed form we have:

&\text{(a)}\quad \Delta t' = \tau\,\sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}},\\[1mm]
&\text{(b)}\quad \lambda' = \lambda\,\sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}},\\[1mm]
&\text{(c)}\quad \lambda' \approx \lambda\,(1 + \beta + \tfrac{1}{2}\beta^2)
\quad\text{with}\quad \beta\approx 0.00652, \quad \lambda' \approx 4893.1\,\text{\AA}.
\end{aligned}
}

We wish to analyze a system in which a spaceship “tows” a defective satellite by pulling on one end of a massive (uniform‐density) rope. (Throughout we assume empty space so that no external forces act aside from those generated within the system.) The rope is 50 m long with mass density 1 kg/m so that its mass is 50 kg, while the satellite’s mass is 950 kg. In (a) and (b) the spaceship “tows” the system so that the whole system accelerates at a = 5 m/s². Later in (c) the spaceship “mistakenly” decelerates at 1 m/s²; we will then discuss the consequences.

Because the rope itself has mass, the force transmitted (i.e. the tension) will not be uniform along its length. It is instructive to “cut” the rope at a variable point and demand that the force (or tension) there be just equal to the net force required to accelerate all the mass that lies “behind” that point (i.e. farther from the spaceship).

────────────────────────────
Part (a): Force exerted by the spaceship on the rope

When the spaceship pulls on the rope it must accelerate both the entire rope and the satellite. That is, the net mass which is being accelerated is
  m_total = m_satellite + m_rope = 950 kg + 50 kg = 1000 kg.

Since the entire rope and satellite accelerate at 5 m/s², Newton’s second law gives

  F = m_total × a = 1000 kg × 5 m/s² = 5000 N.

Thus, the force exerted by the spaceship on the rope is 5000 N.

────────────────────────────
Part (b): The tension along the rope

Because the rope is massive, different portions must “contribute” to accelerating the mass behind them. Let us define a coordinate x along the rope in such a way that

  x = 0 at the satellite end,
  x = L = 50 m at the spaceship end.

At a distance x from the satellite end, the total mass that lies “behind” that point (i.e. the satellite plus the rope of length x) is

  m(x) = m_satellite + (rope density)×(x) = 950 + 1⋅x = 950 + x (kg).

Since this mass is accelerated at 5 m/s², the tension T(x) just at that point must supply the force

  T(x) = a ⋅ m(x) = 5 (950 + x) (N).

It is instructive to check the endpoints:
 • At x = 0 (right at the satellite end), the tension is
  T(0) = 5⋅950 = 4750 N,
 which is just enough to accelerate the satellite.
 • At x = 50 m (the spaceship end), the tension is
  T(50) = 5 (950 + 50) = 5×1000 = 5000 N,
 which equals the total force applied by the spaceship.

Thus, the tension increases linearly along the rope from 4750 N at the satellite to 5000 N at the spaceship.

────────────────────────────
Part (c): Consequences of the mishap (spaceship deceleration)

Now suppose that, due to a malfunction, the spaceship’s acceleration is suddenly reversed – it now decelerates at 1 m/s². (That is, in the inertial “lab” frame the spaceship now has an acceleration of –1 m/s².) At the moment of the mishap the rope and satellite, which had been accelerating together at 5 m/s², continue with their instantaneous speeds and tendency to accelerate at 5 m/s² (because of their inertia and the fact that the tension distribution does not change “instantaneously” along a massive rope).

What happens is essentially as follows:

1. Since the spaceship immediately begins decelerating (accelerating in the direction opposite to its previous motion) with a = –1 m/s², the end of the rope attached to the spaceship will also begin to decelerate. However, the satellite (and the “tails” of the rope further from the spaceship) due to inertia keeps moving with the original acceleration (initially at 5 m/s²).

2. This mismatch means that the rope will no longer be taut uniformly. In fact, because the spaceship “pulls back”, the rope will tend to go slack between the spaceship and the satellite. In the region where the rope slackens the usual linear tension gradient (found when the whole system accelerates uniformly) will disappear temporarily.

3. Once slack develops the satellite and parts of the rope keep moving ahead relative to the decelerating spaceship. Ultimately the slack will be taken up suddenly (as the rope goes taut again by virtue of the satellite’s inertia relative to the suddenly decelerating spaceship). This “snap” can produce a rapid, impulsive force – a tension surge – that may propagate as a shock wave along the rope.

4. Such sudden jerk forces may induce large oscillations (or “whip‐like” motions) in the rope. In a real system these could lead to structural stress in the rope and possibly damage both the rope and the spacecraft’s control systems. Moreover, the defective satellite might experience an abrupt change in acceleration, with potential consequences for its attitude and trajectory.

In summary, the mishap results in the loss of uniform towing: a deceleration by the spaceship creates a relative motion within the system. Under these circumstances the cable temporarily loses tension (or “goes slack”), and when re‐established the sudden tension pulse may produce oscillations or shocks that could be hazardous. In effect, the uniform acceleration condition is disrupted, and the system (the rope and the towed satellite) is prone to dynamic instabilities until a new equilibrium is achieved.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The force exerted by the spaceship on the rope is

  5000 N.

(b) If we let x (in meters) measure the distance from the satellite end (with x = 0 at the satellite and x = 50 at the spaceship), then the tension along the rope is

  T(x) = 5 (950 + x) N,
 which varies from 4750 N at the satellite end to 5000 N at the spaceship end.

(c) When the spaceship suddenly decelerates at 1 m/s², its end of the rope decelerates while the satellite and far portions of the rope, by inertia, continue their previous motion. The rope will lose its uniform tension (going slack), and when the slack is taken up abruptly a shock (jerk) is produced. This causes oscillations and sudden, potentially hazardous forces on the rope and satellite, risking structural damage, abrupt changes in the satellite’s motion, and overall dynamic instability until a new towing equilibrium can be established.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX:

\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & F = 5000\,\textrm{N},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & T(x) = 5\,(950 + x)\,\textrm{N}\quad\text{for } 0 \le x \le 50\ \textrm{(with }x=0\text{ at the satellite)},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{Deceleration of the spaceship causes the rope to slack as its near end decelerates while}\\
& \quad \text{the satellite and far rope continue at the original speed. When the rope re‐tightens, an impulsive}\\
& \quad \text{tension surge produces jerks and oscillations which can damage the rope and adversely affect the}\\
& \quad \text{satellite’s motion.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start with the potential
  U(x) = (kx²)/2 − (mλx³)/3,
where λ is small. The force is given by
  F = −dU/dx = −(kx − mλx²).
Then Newton’s second law (with mass m) reads

  m x¨ = −kx + mλx².

It is convenient to divide through by m and introduce the frequency ω defined by

  ω² = k/m.
Then the equation of motion is

  x¨ + ω²x = λ x².  (1)

Because the cubic term is small (of order λ) we can solve this equation using perturbation theory. We expand the solution as

  x(t) = x₀(t) + λ x₁(t) + O(λ²).

We substitute this expansion into (1) and collect orders in λ.

Step 1. Zeroth Order O(1):

Collecting the terms that do not have λ we obtain

  x₀¨ + ω² x₀ = 0.
This is the simple harmonic oscillator. Its general solution is
  x₀(t) = A cos ωt + B sin ωt.

The equilibrium point is at x = 0 (since U′(0) = 0). We are told that x(0)=0. (Typically one also gives a condition on the velocity; here we choose x₀′(0)= Aω with an appropriate constant so that the motion is not trivial.) Let us assume
  x(0) = 0  ⟹  A = 0,
and denote
  x₀′(0) = Bω = A₁ ω    (we use A₁ to denote the amplitude coming from the initial velocity).
For convenience we rename A₁ as A so that

  x₀(t) = A sin ωt.

Step 2. First Order O(λ):

At O(λ) the equation becomes

  x₁¨ + ω² x₁ = x₀².
Since x₀(t) = A sin ωt we have

  x₀² = A² sin² ωt.
Using the trigonometric identity
  sin² ωt = ½ (1 − cos 2ωt),
the forcing term is

  A² sin² ωt = (A²/2)[1 − cos 2ωt].

Thus the equation to solve is

  x₁¨ + ω² x₁ = (A²/2)[1 − cos 2ωt].  (2)

We must also satisfy the initial conditions coming from the full solution x(t) = x₀(t) + λ x₁(t):
  x(0)=0 and x′(0) are prescribed.
Since x₀(0) = 0, we require x₁(0) = 0.
Also, because x′(0) = x₀′(0) + λ x₁′(0) and we have already chosen x₀′(0)=Aω, it is natural to require
  x₁′(0) = 0.

Now we solve (2).

(a) Find a particular solution for the constant forcing. For a constant forcing term (A²/2), a constant function x₁ = C will give

  0 + ω² C = (A²/2).
Thus,
  C = A²/(2ω²).

(b) Next, we look for a particular solution for the term proportional to cos2ωt. We set
  x₁ = D cos 2ωt.
Then
  x₁¨ = −4ω² D cos 2ωt.
Substitute into the differential equation:
  (−4ω² D cos 2ωt) + ω² (D cos 2ωt) = −3ω²D cos2ωt = − (A²/2) cos2ωt.
This gives
  D = A²/(6ω²).

Thus a particular solution (x₁p) is
  x₁p(t) = A²/(2ω²) + [A²/(6ω²)] cos 2ωt.

(c) The homogeneous solution to (2) is the solution of
  x₁¨ + ω² x₁ = 0,
which is
  x₁h(t) = C cos ωt + D sin ωt.
We now impose the initial conditions on x₁.

At t=0:
  x₁(0) = C + A²/(2ω²) + [A²/(6ω²)] = 0.
So,
  C = −A²/(2ω²) − A²/(6ω²) = −(2A²)/(3ω²).

Also,
  x₁′(t) = − C ω sin ωt + D ω cos ωt − [A²/(6ω²)] 2ω sin 2ωt.
At t=0,
  x₁′(0) = D ω = 0  ⟹  D = 0.

Thus the full first-order correction is
  x₁(t) = −(2A²/(3ω²)) cos ωt + A²/(2ω²) + [A²/(6ω²)] cos 2ωt.

Step 3. Write the full solution to first order in λ:

Recalling that
  x(t) = x₀(t) + λ x₁(t),  and  x₀(t) = A sin ωt,
we have

  x(t) = A sin ωt + λ { −(2A²/(3ω²)) cos ωt + A²/(2ω²) + [A²/(6ω²)] cos 2ωt }.

It is often useful to rewrite the bracket in a slightly factored form. Notice that
  −(2A²/(3ω²)) cos ωt + A²/(2ω²) + [A²/(6ω²)] cos 2ωt
can be written as
  A²/(6ω²)[ −4 cos ωt + 3 + cos 2ωt ].
Thus, an equivalent form for the solution is

  x(t) = A sin ωt + λ (A²/(6ω²)) [ cos 2ωt − 4 cos ωt + 3 ].

We interpret the constant A as being determined by the initial velocity, since x′(0) = Aω. 

Final Answer in LaTeX:

  \boxed{x(t)= A\sin(\omega t) + \lambda\,\frac{A^2}{6\omega^2}\Bigl[\cos(2\omega t)-4\cos(\omega t)+3\Bigr],\quad \text{with } x(0)=0,\; x'(0)=A\omega.}
  \]

solution:
We can “escape” an asteroid by jumping if the speed you can give yourself exceeds that asteroid’s escape velocity. (Note that “escape by jumping” means your jump speed is high enough that gravity never pulls you back.)

Step 1. Escaping requires that your jump speed v_jump be at least as large as the escape velocity from the asteroid. For a spherical body of radius R and mass M the escape speed is

  v_escape = √(2GM/R).

Since the mass M is related to the density ρ by

  M = (4/3)πR³ρ,

we can substitute to obtain

  v_escape = √[(2G(4/3)πR³ρ)/R] = √[(8πGρ/3) R²]
          = R √(8πGρ/3).

Step 2. For escape we require

  v_jump ≥ R√(8πGρ/3).

Thus, if you can only jump with speed v_jump then the largest radius R you can “escape” from is

  R = v_jump / √(8πGρ/3).

Step 3. Now plug in representative numbers. Suppose a very athletic jump might give you a take‐off speed of about

  v_jump ≈ 3 m/s.

For the density of an asteroid we might use

  ρ ≈ 2000 kg/m³

(which is typical of many rocky or rubble‐pile asteroids). And G, the gravitational constant, is

  G = 6.67×10⁻¹¹ m³/(kg·s²).

Now, compute the factor under the square root:

  8πGρ/3 = (8 × π × 6.67×10⁻¹¹ m³/(kg·s²) × 2000 kg/m³)/3.

First, calculate the numerator:
  8π ≈ 25.13,
  25.13 × 6.67×10⁻¹¹ ≈ 1.675×10⁻⁹,
  1.675×10⁻⁹ × 2000 = 3.35×10⁻⁶.
Then divide by 3:
  3.35×10⁻⁶ / 3 ≈ 1.12×10⁻⁶ s⁻².

The square root is
  √(1.12×10⁻⁶) ≈ 0.00106 s⁻¹.

So,

  R = 3 m/s / 0.00106 s⁻¹ ≈ 2830 m ≈ 2.8 km.

Step 4. Interpretation

This means that if you can jump at about 3 m/s then you could “escape” an asteroid having a radius of about 2.8 km, corresponding to a diameter of roughly 5.6–6 km. (Many asteroids are much smaller than this; indeed, if you were standing on such a small world, you might jump and easily leave its surface.)

Final Answer in Latex boxed format:

\[ \boxed{R\approx 2.8\,\text{km}\quad\text{(i.e. an asteroid with diameter of roughly 6 km)}} \]

We are given a particle of mass m moving in a radially symmetric potential

  U(r) = k r.

For a circular orbit of radius r₀ (here, we simply denote it as r) we can use the effective potential and the condition for a minimum.

Step 1. Write the Effective Potential

For a central force problem the effective potential is
  U_eff(r) = U(r) + L²/(2m r²)
where L is the angular momentum.

In our case,
  U_eff(r) = k r + L²/(2m r²).

Step 2. Condition for a Circular Orbit

A circular orbit occurs at a radius r where the effective potential is at an extremum. This requires:
  dU_eff/dr = 0.
Differentiate U_eff:
  d/dr (k r) = k   and  d/dr [L²/(2m r²)] = –L²/(m r³).
So,
  k – L²/(m r³) = 0.
Hence,
  L² = m k r³.
That is our condition on the angular momentum.

Furthermore, the total energy E in the circular orbit is the effective potential at r:
  E = U_eff(r) = k r + L²/(2m r²).
Substitute L² = m k r³:
  E = k r + [m k r³/(2m r²)] = k r + (k r)/2 = (3/2) k r.

Thus, the answers for part (a) are:
  Angular momentum: L = √(m k r³),
  Energy: E = (3/2) k r.

Step 3. Frequency of Circular Motion

For circular motion the angular speed ω is related to the angular momentum by L = m r² ω, so
  ω = L/(m r²).
Substitute L = √(m k r³):
  ω = √(m k r³)/(m r²) = √(k/(m r)).

So, the frequency (more precisely, the angular frequency) is
  ω = √(k/(m r)).

Step 4. Frequency of Small Oscillations (Radial Perturbations)

Now consider a small radial departure r = r + δr from the circular orbit. The dynamics of the small radial oscillations are governed by the second derivative of the effective potential evaluated at the circular orbit radius.

We have
  U_eff(r) = k r + L²/(2m r²).
Its first derivative is already found:
  U_eff'(r) = k – L²/(m r³).
Differentiate again to get the second derivative:
  U_eff''(r) = d/dr (–L²/(m r³)) = 3L²/(m r⁴).

For small oscillations the angular frequency ω_r satisfies
  m ω_r² = U_eff''(r),
so
  ω_r² = (U_eff''(r))/m = (3L²)/(m² r⁴).

Again, substitute L² = m k r³:
  ω_r² = (3 m k r³)/(m² r⁴) = 3k/(m r).

Thus, the radial (small oscillation) frequency is
  ω_r = √(3k/(m r)).

Notice that the small oscillation frequency is √3 times the angular frequency of the circular orbit, since
  ω = √(k/(m r))  ⇒  ω_r = √3 ω.

Step 5. Final Answers

(a) For a circular orbit of radius r, the angular momentum and energy must satisfy:
  L = √(m k r³)   and  E = (3/2) k r.

(b) The angular frequency of the circular motion is:
  ω = √(k/(m r)).

(c) The frequency of small radial oscillations about this circular motion is:
  ω_r = √(3k/(m r)).

Thus, the final boxed answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)}\quad L=\sqrt{mkr^{3}},\quad E=\frac{3}{2}kr, \\
&\text{(b)}\quad \omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{mr}}, \\
&\text{(c)}\quad \omega_{r}=\sqrt{\frac{3k}{mr}}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start with the given orbit for a unit‐mass particle
  r = a e^(–bθ).
For a particle moving under a central force, it is very useful to introduce the variable

  u = 1/r.

Thus, in our case,
  u = 1/(a e^(–bθ)) = e^(bθ)/a.

The standard Binet equation for central force motion is
  d²u/dθ² + u = –F(r)/(h² u²),
where h is the conserved angular momentum and F(r) = –dU/dr is the central force. (Here we work with unit mass so that the kinetic energy and angular momentum expressions are simplified.)

Step 1. Compute the derivatives of u with respect to θ.

We have
  u(θ) = e^(bθ)/a.
Differentiate once:
  du/dθ = (b e^(bθ))/a = b u.
Differentiate a second time:
  d²u/dθ² = d(bu)/dθ = b (du/dθ) = b² u.

Thus,
  d²u/dθ² + u = b² u + u = (b² + 1) u.

Step 2. Insert into the Binet equation.

The Binet equation becomes
  (b² + 1) u = –F(r)/(h² u²).

Solve for F(r):
  F(r) = –h² u² (b² + 1) u = –h² (b² + 1) u³.

Since u = 1/r, u³ = 1/r³, hence
  F(r) = – h² (b² + 1)/r³.

Step 3. Relate the force to the potential energy.

By definition of a conservative force,
  F(r) = – dU/dr.
Thus,
  – dU/dr = – h² (b² + 1)/r³    ⟹  dU/dr = h² (b² + 1)/r³.

Now, integrate with respect to r:
  U(r) = ∫ [h² (b² + 1)/r³] dr = h² (b² + 1) ∫ r^(–3) dr.

Recall that
  ∫ r^(–3) dr = – 1/(2r²) + constant.
Thus,
  U(r) = – [h² (b² + 1)]/(2r²) + constant.

Since we are asked to find U(r) “to within a multiplicative constant,” we may simply write

  U(r) ∝ – 1/r².

Final Answer in boxed form:

  \[\boxed{U(r) = -\frac{h^2(b^2+1)}{2\,r^2}}\]

Thus, up to an overall multiplicative constant, the potential energy function is an inverse-square type potential.

We start by considering a satellite in a perfect Keplerian (central-force) elliptical orbit. In that case, the orbital shape (given by the eccentricity and semimajor axis) and its orientation in space remain fixed in the absence of perturbations. Now, let’s examine in turn the qualitative effects of the two given perturbations.

─────────────────────────────  
1. Perturbation (a): Earth’s Polar Flattening (Non‐Central Gravity)

• Because the Earth is not a perfect sphere but rather an oblate spheroid (flattened at the poles), the gravitational potential deviates from the simple 1/r law. The dominant correction is characterized by the “J₂ term” in a spherical harmonic expansion of the Earth's gravity.

• This non-central component produces torques on the orbit. In particular, the perturbation alters the potential energy in such a way that:
  – The argument of perigee (the orientation of the ellipse within its orbital plane) slowly precesses.
  – The line of nodes (the intersection of the orbital plane with the Earth’s equatorial plane) also precesses; for most orbits, the nodes regress (move opposite to the orbital motion).

• Because these are long‐term averaged (secular) effects, the shape of the ellipse (i.e., the eccentricity) and the semimajor axis remain essentially unchanged. What is altered is the orientation of the orbit in space.

─────────────────────────────  
2. Perturbation (b): Concentrated Atmospheric Drag near Perigee

• Atmospheric drag is a non-conservative force that extracts energy and angular momentum from the satellite. Because the atmospheric density decays rapidly with altitude, the drag is most significant at the perigee where the satellite is closest to Earth.

• The impulsive drag at perigee reduces the orbital energy more severely there. Although the change in velocity may be sudden, the overall effect is that:
  – The semimajor axis decreases (the orbit “shrinks”).
  – The loss of energy—with an associated change in angular momentum—tends to reduce the eccentricity, i.e. the orbit gradually becomes more circular.
  – The effect on orbit orientation is generally minor compared to the energy loss; rather, the primary modification is in the size and shape of the orbit.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Summary

(a) The oblateness of the Earth (polar flattening) leads to a non-central gravitational force that does not change the energy but causes the orbit’s orientation to precess (the line of nodes and the argument of perigee rotate slowly).

(b) Atmospheric drag, occurring primarily at perigee, lowers the satellite’s orbital energy and angular momentum—resulting in a decreasing semimajor axis and a reduction in eccentricity (making the orbit more circular over time).

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a) The Earth’s polar flattening (J₂ effect) produces torques that cause the orbital}\\
\quad \text{ellipse to precess, changing the orientation (both the line of nodes and the argument}\\
\quad \text{of perigee) without significantly affecting the semimajor axis or eccentricity.}\\[1mm]
\text{(b) Atmospheric drag, concentrated near perigee, dissipates orbital energy and angular}\\
\quad \text{momentum, reducing the semimajor axis and eccentricity. Thus, the orbit shrinks and}\\
\quad \text{tends to become more circular over time.}
\end{array}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to insert Mariner 4 into a heliocentric elliptical (Hohmann transfer) orbit whose perihelion is Earth’s circular orbit (of radius R_E) and aphelion is Mars’s circular orbit (of radius R_M). (In what follows we denote the Sun’s gravitational parameter by μ = GM_⊙.) In all cases we assume that only the Sun’s gravity matters (the planets’ fields can be neglected) and that the spacecraft meets Mars if it is launched at the proper time.

Before giving our answers, let us define

  a = (R_E + R_M) / 2     (the semi‐major axis of the transfer orbit).

Remember that in any central force (Kepler) orbit the speed at radius r is given by

  v = √[ μ (2/r – 1/a) ].

Also, the speed on a circular orbit of radius R is

  v_circ = √(μ/R).

We now proceed part by part.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): What velocity (relative to Earth) and in what direction must Mariner 4 have when leaving Earth?

When Mariner 4 leaves Earth it instantaneously “joins” an orbit about the Sun. Since Earth is already moving with speed

  v_E = √(μ/R_E)
 
around the Sun, the spacecraft must be given an extra heliocentric velocity so that its speed (at r = R_E) becomes

  v_p = √[ μ (2/R_E – 1/a) ]    (speed at perihelion of the ellipse).

Thus, compared to Earth the spacecraft must be given a “boost” equal to

  Δv = v_p – v_E.

It is easy to simplify this expression a little bit. Note that

  v_p = √[ μ (2/R_E – 2/(R_E+R_M)) ]
     = √[2μ (1/R_E – 1/(R_E+R_M)) ]
     = √(μ/R_E) √[2(1 – (R_E/(R_E+R_M)))]
     = √(μ/R_E) √(2R_M/(R_E+R_M)).

Thus the needed velocity “excess” relative to Earth is

  Δv = √(μ/R_E) [√(2R_M/(R_E+R_M)) – 1].

The direction of the boost should be along Earth’s instantaneous orbital velocity (i.e. tangential to the circular orbit) so that the heliocentric velocity v_p is in the same direction as v_E (only its magnitude is increased). In other words, Mariner 4 must leave Earth “in the direction of Earth’s motion.”

────────────────────────────
Step (b): How long will it take to reach Mars?

The transfer orbit is an ellipse of semi‐major axis a. The period of an ellipse is

  T = 2π √(a³/μ).

Since the transfer is from perihelion (Earth’s orbit) to aphelion (Mars’ orbit) – one half of a complete orbit – the time of flight is

  t = T/2 = π √(a³/μ).

We can substitute back a = (R_E+R_M)/2 to obtain

  t = π √[ ((R_E+R_M)/2)³ / μ ]
    = π √[ (R_E+R_M)³/(8μ) ].

────────────────────────────
Step (c): With what velocity, relative to Mars, will it reach the orbit of Mars?

At aphelion, the heliocentric speed of the spacecraft is

  v_a = √[ μ (2/R_M – 1/a) ].

Let us write this in a form similar to part (a). Since

  v_a = √[ μ (2/R_M – 2/(R_E+R_M)) ]
     = √(2μ (1/R_M – 1/(R_E+R_M)))
     = √(μ/R_M) √[2 (1 – (R_M/(R_E+R_M)))]
     = √(μ/R_M) √(2R_E/(R_E+R_M)).

On the other hand, Mars’s circular orbital speed is

  v_M = √(μ/R_M).

Since the transfer ellipse is tangent to Mars’s circular orbit at aphelion (but with v_a < v_M), the velocity of Mariner 4 relative to Mars is

  Δv_M = v_M – v_a
    = √(μ/R_M) [1 – √(2R_E/(R_E+R_M))].

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

Thus, one acceptable answer is as follows:

  (a) The spacecraft must be launched relative to Earth with speed
    Δv = √(μ/R_E) [√(2R_M/(R_E+R_M)) – 1],
    in the direction tangent to Earth’s orbit (i.e. in the direction of Earth’s orbital motion).

  (b) The time of flight is
    t = π √[((R_E + R_M)/2)³/μ] = π √[(R_E+R_M)³/(8μ)].

  (c) Upon reaching Mars, the spacecraft’s speed relative to Mars (in the heliocentric frame) is less than Mars’s orbital speed by
    Δv_M = √(μ/R_M) [1 – √(2R_E/(R_E+R_M))].

We now provide these answers in the boxed format.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX boxed format:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)} \quad \Delta v &= \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{R_E}}\Biggl(\sqrt{\frac{2R_M}{R_E+R_M}}-1\Biggr), \quad\text{directed tangentially (in the direction of Earth's motion).} \\
\\
\text{(b)} \quad t &= \pi \sqrt{\frac{\Bigl(\frac{R_E+R_M}{2}\Bigr)^3}{\mu}}=\pi\sqrt{\frac{(R_E+R_M)^3}{8\mu}}, \\
\\
\text{(c)} \quad \Delta v_M &= \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{R_M}}\Biggl(1-\sqrt{\frac{2R_E}{R_E+R_M}}\Biggr).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We are given a particle of mass m that is constrained to move in the xz‐plane along the parabola

  z = x²/a

with a constant gravitational acceleration g directed downward (in the negative z direction).

We will solve the problem step by step.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Choose a Generalized Coordinate

The constraint z = x²/a shows that knowing the x coordinate completely determines the z coordinate. Thus a natural choice of generalized coordinate is

  q = x   and  z = x²/a.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Write the Lagrangian in Terms of x and ẋ

The kinetic energy T is given by

  T = (1/2)m (ẋ² + ż²).

Since z = x²/a, differentiate with respect to time:

  ż = d/dt (x²/a) = (2x/a)ẋ.

Thus

  T = (1/2)m [ẋ² + (2x/a)² ẋ²] = (1/2)m ẋ² [1 + 4x²/a²].

The potential energy V is due to gravity, with z = x²/a, so

  V = mgz = mg(x²/a).

Thus the Lagrangian L is

  L = T – V = (1/2)m [1 + (4x²/a²)]ẋ² – mg(x²/a).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Find the Equilibrium Position

The equilibrium position occurs when the net generalized force vanishes. Since the potential energy is

  V(x) = mg (x²/a),

its derivative is

  dV/dx = (2mg/a)x.

Setting dV/dx = 0 gives

  x = 0.

Thus, the equilibrium position is x = 0 (which corresponds to z = 0).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (d): Equation for Small Oscillations

For small oscillations we consider small displacements x about x = 0. In the kinetic energy, note that

  1 + 4x²/a² ≈ 1   (for small x).

Thus the approximate kinetic energy is

  T ≈ (1/2)mẋ².

The potential energy is already quadratic in x:

  V ≈ mg (x²/a).

For a simple harmonic oscillator the potential energy is of the form (1/2) k x²; hence here we can identify the effective spring constant by requiring

  (1/2) k x² = mg (x²/a)  ⟹  k = 2mg/a.

The Euler–Lagrange equation from the approximate Lagrangian

  L ≈ (1/2)mẋ² – mg(x²/a)

leads to

  mẍ + kx = 0 ⟹ ẍ + (2g/a)x = 0.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (e): Solve the Equation for Small Oscillations

The differential equation for small oscillations is

  ẍ + (2g/a)x = 0.

Its general solution is

  x(t) = A cos (ωt) + B sin (ωt),

where the angular frequency is

  ω = √(2g/a).

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

We now summarize our answers in boxed form:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & \text{Use } q = x\text{ (with } z=x^2/a\text{)}.\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & L = \frac{1}{2}m\left(1+\frac{4x^2}{a^2}\right)\dot{x}^2 - mg\frac{x^2}{a}.\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{The equilibrium occurs at } x=0 \quad (z=0).\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad & \text{For small } x:\; \ddot{x} + \frac{2g}{a}x=0.\\[1mm]
\text{(e)}\quad & x(t)= A\cos\Bigl(\sqrt{\frac{2g}{a}}\,t\Bigr)+ B\sin\Bigl(\sqrt{\frac{2g}{a}}\,t\Bigr).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

\text{(b)}\quad & L = \frac{1}{2}m\left(1+\frac{4x^2}{a^2}\right)\dot{x}^2 - mg\frac{x^2}{a}.\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{The equilibrium occurs at } x=0 \quad (z=0).\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad & \text{For small } x:\; \ddot{x} + \frac{2g}{a}x=0.\\[1mm]
\text{(e)}\quad & x(t)= A\cos\Bigl(\sqrt{\frac{2g}{a}}\,t\Bigr)+ B\sin\Bigl(\sqrt{\frac{2g}{a}}\,t\Bigr).

solution:
We wish to understand what happens if an electron initially in a circular orbit about a “tritium nucleus” (with effective charge +1) suddenly “sees” a nucleus whose charge has increased to +2. (In our model an electron is orbiting a point‐charge nucleus in a Coulomb potential.) Because the change is sudden the electron’s position and velocity are unchanged at that instant. (It is only the potential that changes.) However, the force acting on it is now that due to a nucleus of charge +2. (For simplicity we use “ke²” to denote the Coulomb constant times the product of charges; you may take k = 1/4πε₀ if desired.)

Let us denote the radius of the original circular orbit by r₀.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. The “Before” Situation

In the original Coulomb field (charge +1), a circular orbit is obtained when the centripetal force equals the Coulomb attraction:
  m v₀²/r₀ = ke²/r₀²     (1)
so that
  v₀² = ke²/(m r₀).

For a circular orbit the kinetic and potential energies are
  T = ½ m v₀² = ½ (ke²/r₀)
  U = –ke²/r₀.
Thus the total energy is
  E_i = T + U = (ke²/(2r₀)) – (ke²/r₀) = – ke²/(2r₀).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. The “After” Situation Immediately

When the nucleus suddenly changes its charge from +1 to +2 the electron’s instantaneous state (its r and v) remain the same. Therefore the kinetic energy is still
  T = ½ m v₀² = ke²/(2r₀)
(because v₀² has not changed). However, its potential energy is now
  U' = – (2 ke²)/r₀.
Thus the new total energy is
  E_f = T + U' = (ke²/(2r₀)) – (2 ke²/r₀) = – (3 ke²)/(2r₀).

──────────────────────────────
(a) Ratio of the electron’s energy after to that before emission

We take our zero of energy as usual (0 when the electron is free, with zero kinetic energy). Then
  E_i = – ke²/(2r₀)  and  E_f = – (3 ke²)/(2r₀).

Thus the ratio is
  E_f/E_i = [ – (3 ke²)/(2r₀) ] / [ – ke²/(2r₀) ] = 3.

──────────────────────────────
(b) Qualitative Description of the New Orbit

Even though the electron’s position and speed do not change at the moment of the “jump”, the change in potential (doubling the attractive force) means that the velocity is not the circular one for the new (more tightly binding) potential. In fact, for a Coulomb potential with charge +2 a circular orbit of radius r would require
  m v_c²/r = (2 ke²)/r² → v_c² = 2ke²/(m r),
which is larger than the original v₀² = ke²/(m r₀) if r = r₀. Consequently the electron is “too slow” to remain in a circular orbit about the now stronger +2 nucleus. It instead finds itself in an elliptical orbit. A detailed analysis (below) shows that the electron’s position at the moment the potential is changed is an extremum of its radial coordinate – in fact it turns out to be the aphelion (greatest distance) of the new ellipse.

──────────────────────────────
(c) Finding the Distance of Closest and Farthest Approach

For a particle moving in a Coulomb (central–force) potential the orbit is a conic section. Its general equation in polar coordinates is

  r(θ) = p/(1 + e cosθ),
     (2)

where
  p = (L²)/(m (2 ke²))    [since the nucleus now has charge 2].

The angular momentum L is conserved. Initially we had a circular orbit with 
  L = m v₀ r₀.
We have already found v₀² = ke²/(m r₀) so that
  L² = m² v₀² r₀² = m² (ke²/(m r₀)) r₀² = m ke² r₀.
Thus the semilatus rectum is

  p = L²/[m (2 ke²)] = [m ke² r₀] / [m (2 ke²)] = r₀/2.

Next, the orbit’s eccentricity e is determined by

  e = √[1 + (2 E_f L²)/(m (2 ke²)²)].
Let us substitute E_f = – (3 ke²)/(2r₀) and L² = m ke² r₀:
  2 E_f L² = 2 * (– (3 ke²)/(2r₀)) * (m ke² r₀) = – 3 m k² e⁴? 
Let’s compute step‐by‐step:

Step (i): Multiply numerator: 2 E_f L² = 2 (–3 ke²/(2r₀)) (m ke² r₀) = – 3 m k² e⁴? 
It is best to keep the factors straight:
  2 E_f L² = –3 m (ke²)².
The denominator is:
  m (2 ke²)² = m (4 k² e^4).
Thus
  (2 E_f L²)/(m (2 ke²)²) = (– 3 m k² e^4)/(4 m k² e^4) = – 3/4.
Then
  e = √(1 – 3/4) = √(1/4) = 1/2.

Remember that the radial turning points (perihelium and aphelium) occur when 1 + e cosθ = 0, i.e., when the denominator is minimized or maximized. In fact, the minimum and maximum radii are given by
  r_min = p/(1 + e) and r_max = p/(1 – e).
We already found p = r₀/2 and e = 1/2, so
  r_min = (r₀/2)/(1 + 1/2) = (r₀/2)/(3/2) = r₀/3,
  r_max = (r₀/2)/(1 – 1/2) = (r₀/2)/(1/2) = r₀.

Thus the electron is at its farthest distance (aphelion) r₀ at the moment of the leap, and its closest approach is r₀/3.

──────────────────────────────
(d) Major and Minor Axes of the Elliptical Orbit

For any ellipse we have
  semimajor axis a = (r_min + r_max)/2.
Thus,
  a = (r₀/3 + r₀)/2 = (4r₀/3)/2 = 2r₀/3.

The eccentricity is e = (r_max – r_min)/(r_max + r_min). (One may verify that with r_max = r₀ and r_min = r₀/3 one obtains e = 1/2, as above.)

The semiminor axis b is given in terms of a and e by
  b = a √(1 – e²) = (2r₀/3) √(1 – 1/4) = (2r₀/3) √(3/4) = (r₀ √3)/3.

Thus the full (linear) lengths are:
  Major axis length = 2a = 4r₀/3,
  Minor axis length = 2b = 2r₀√3/3.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The ratio of the electron's final to initial energy is  
  E_f/E_i = 3.

(b) The electron, which finds itself with the same speed and position but in a potential twice as strong, now follows an elliptical orbit. Moreover, since the electron was at r₀ when the change occurred and that happens to be an extreme (the farthest point) for the new orbit, the electron is at the aphelion of its ellipse.

(c) The distances of closest and farthest approach are:
  r_min = r₀/3 and r_max = r₀.

(d) For the ellipse, the semimajor axis is a = 2r₀/3 (so the major axis is 4r₀/3) and the semiminor axis is b = (r₀√3)/3.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)}\quad \frac{E_f}{E_i} = 3,\\[1mm]
&\text{(b)}\quad \text{The electron now moves on an ellipse, with its initial position (at }r_0\text{) being the aphelion (largest distance).}\\[1mm]
&\text{(c)}\quad r_{\min} = \frac{r_0}{3},\quad r_{\max} = r_0,\\[1mm]
&\text{(d)}\quad \text{Semimajor axis }a = \frac{2r_0}{3},\quad \text{Semiminor axis }b = \frac{r_0\sqrt{3}}{3}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to derive the equations of motion for a “spring pendulum” – a mass m attached to a massless spring (spring constant k, natural length l) which is fixed at one end. We will work in a vertical plane and choose polar coordinates (r, θ) in the following way:

• r is the distance from the fixed support to the mass.

• θ is the angle made by the spring with the vertical (with “down” corresponding to θ = 0).

In what follows we derive the full nonlinear equations and then we linearize them assuming small displacements from equilibrium.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Write the Lagrangian

The kinetic energy T in polar coordinates is
  T = (1/2)m ( (dot{r})² + r² (dot{θ})² ).

The potential energy has two contributions:

1. Elastic potential energy from the spring:
  V_spring = ½ k (r – l)².

2. Gravitational potential energy. We choose a coordinate system in which the y–axis is upward and take the potential energy to be mgy. (Since the mass is at y = –r cosθ, we have)
  V_grav = m g y = – m g r cosθ.

Thus the total potential energy is
  V = ½ k (r – l)² – m g r cosθ.

The Lagrangian is then
  L = T – V = ½ m [ (dot{r})² + r²(dot{θ})² ] – ½ k (r – l)² + m g r cosθ.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Derive the Equations of Motion

We now treat r and θ as generalized coordinates.

• (a) For r:

We have
  ∂L/∂(dot{r}) = m dot{r}  ⟹ d/dt (∂L/∂(dot{r})) = m d²r/dt².
Also,
  ∂L/∂r = m r (dot{θ})² – k (r – l) + m g cosθ.
Then the Euler–Lagrange equation for r becomes:
  m d²r/dt² – m r (dot{θ})² + k (r – l) – m g cosθ = 0.
We label this as (1).

• (b) For θ:

We compute
  ∂L/∂(dot{θ}) = m r² dot{θ}  ⟹ d/dt (∂L/∂(dot{θ})) = m (2r dot{r} dot{θ} + r² d²θ/dt²).
Also, 
  ∂L/∂θ = – (–m g r sinθ) = m g r sinθ   (since derivative of cosθ is – sinθ).
Thus the Euler–Lagrange equation for θ is:
  d/dt (m r² dot{θ}) – m g r sinθ = 0,
or equivalently,
  d/dt (m r² dot{θ}) + m g r sinθ = 0.
We label this as (2).

Equations (1) and (2) are the full equations of motion for the spring pendulum.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Find the Equilibrium

For equilibrium we set θ = 0 (so the pendulum hangs vertically) and take r equal to the constant r₀ so that dot{r} = 0 and dot{θ} = 0. Then Eq. (1) reduces to
  k (r₀ – l) – m g cos0 = k (r₀ – l) – m g = 0.
Thus, the equilibrium radial distance is
  r₀ = l + (m g)/k.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Linearize for Small Oscillations

We now let r = r₀ + x, where x is a small radial displacement and assume that θ is small. We will expand the equations (1) and (2) to first order in x and θ.

Recall: when θ is small, we may use:
  cosθ ≈ 1, sinθ ≈ θ,
and we neglect terms that are quadratic (or higher) in the small quantities (x, θ and their time derivatives).

— Radial Equation —

Starting from (1):
  m d²r/dt² – m r (dot{θ})² + k (r – l) – m g cosθ = 0.
Replace r = r₀ + x and note that d²r/dt² = d²x/dt².

The term – m r (dot{θ})² is quadratic (both dot{θ} and small displacements are small) and may be dropped. Also, using cosθ ≈ 1, we have:
  m d²x/dt² + k ((r₀ + x) – l) – m g = 0.
But notice that (r₀ – l) = (m g)/k by the equilibrium condition. Therefore,
  k ((r₀ – l) + x) – m g = k (m g/k + x) – m g = m g + k x – m g = k x.
Thus the r–equation (to linear order) becomes
  m d²x/dt² + k x = 0,
or
  d²x/dt² + (k/m)x = 0.

— Angular Equation —

For (2) we have
  d/dt (m r² dot{θ}) + m g r sinθ = 0.
Substitute r = r₀ + x. To first order we approximate r² ≈ r₀² (since the product of a small quantity and another small quantity is of second order) and r ≈ r₀ in the gravitational term. Thus, we get
  m r₀² d²θ/dt² + m g r₀ θ = 0,
which is equivalent to
  d²θ/dt² + (g / r₀) θ = 0.
Recall that r₀ = l + (mg)/k, so the angular frequency is √(g/r₀).

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Final Answers

Thus, the full equations of motion are

  (1) m d²r/dt² – m r (dot{θ})² + k (r – l) – m g cosθ = 0,
  (2) d/dt (m r² dot{θ}) + m g r sinθ = 0.

In the approximation of small displacements about the equilibrium (writing r = r₀ + x with r₀ = l + (mg)/k) and small θ, the equations decouple into two harmonic oscillators:

• Radial motion:
  d²x/dt² + (k/m)x = 0.

• Angular motion:
  d²θ/dt² + (g/(l + mg/k))θ = 0.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{Full equations:}\quad & m\ddot{r} - m\,r\,\dot{\theta}^2 + k(r-l) - mg\cos\theta = 0,\\[1mm]
& \frac{d}{dt}(mr^2\dot{\theta}) + mg\,r\sin\theta = 0;\\[2mm]
\text{Small oscillations (with } r=r_0+x,\; r_0=l+\frac{mg}{k} \text{):}\quad & \ddot{x} + \frac{k}{m}\,x = 0,\\[1mm]
& \ddot{\theta} + \frac{g}{l+\frac{mg}{k}}\,\theta = 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start by noting that the man’s weight is stated as w. In standard notation his mass is

  m = w/g.

Also, the elevator itself weighs w. (That fact isn’t used in the calculations for the man’s apparent weight and power output.)

──────────────────────────
Step (a): Apparent Weight of the Man

The elevator accelerates upward at a rate a. In a non-inertial frame such as that of the elevator, the effective gravitational field becomes

  g_eff = g + a.

Thus, if the man were at rest in the elevator, the scale (or the floor’s normal force) would read an apparent weight N given by

  N = m(g + a).

Expressing this in terms of w we have

  N = (w/g)(g + a) = w(1 + a/g).

──────────────────────────
Step (b): Power Output When Climbing

Now suppose the man starts climbing a ladder fixed in the elevator at a speed v relative to the elevator. When he climbs, he must overcome the effective gravitational force in the elevator (i.e. his apparent weight). That is, his muscle must provide an upward force equal to

  F = m(g + a).

Since he is climbing at a constant speed v relative to the elevator, the rate at which work is done (i.e. his power output) is

  Power, P = Force × speed = m(g + a) v.

In terms of w this is

  P = (w/g)(g + a) v = w(1 + a/g)v.

A Note on the Instantaneous Elevator Speed V:
One might wonder if the fact that the elevator is moving at speed V should be taken into account. However, the man’s muscle work is done against the effective gravity in the elevator frame, so his climbing work per unit time comes solely from the relative speed v and the effective force m(g + a). (In other words, although his total upward speed relative to the ground is V+v, the extra work done by climbing is associated with his motion relative to the elevator.)

──────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The man’s apparent weight is 
  N = w(1 + a/g).

(b) The rate of expenditure of energy when he climbs is 
  P = w(1 + a/g)v.

──────────────────────────
Final boxed answer in LaTeX:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & N = w\left(1+\frac{a}{g}\right),\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & P = w\left(1+\frac{a}{g}\right)v.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that when the only forces acting on the sliding mass are (i) an elastic “spring‐force” (directed toward the origin) of magnitude k|x| and (ii) a “friction” force that “damps out” the velocity of the mass relative to the rotating turntable – that is, with force
  F_fric = –c (ẋ – v)
(with v the velocity of the turntable at the position x, which is given by v = ω×x) – then the motion obeys Newton’s law (with mass m)
  m ẍ = –k x – c (ẋ – ω×x).

One acceptable answer to this three–part problem is given below. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.) We now explain step‐by–step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Finding k such that a point fixed in the turntable is an equilibrium

Suppose the body is “at rest with respect to the turntable” even though the entire turntable rotates (with constant angular velocity ω about the z–axis). (That is, in the lab frame the particle makes a circle while its “r–coordinate” on the turntable remains fixed.) In that case the particle’s lab–frame coordinate is
  x(t)= (x(t),y(t)) = R (cos(ωt+φ), sin(ωt+φ))
with constant radius R and some constant phase φ.

Its lab–frame velocity is 
  ẋ(t)= ω×x(t)    [since differentiating a rotation gives the “centripetal” term]. 

Also, since the particle is “fixed on the turntable” we have
  ẋ – v = ẋ – (ω×x) = 0,
so the friction force is zero. But the elastic force is still present. Its value in the lab frame is
  F_spring = – k x(t).
On the other hand, since the particle’s lab–frame acceleration is 
  ẍ(t)= –ω^2 x(t)   (centripetal acceleration),
Newton’s law tells us that
  m ẍ = –k x.
Thus we must have
  –mω^2 x = –k x,
or, for nonzero x,
  k = mω^2.
That is our answer for part (a).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Solving for the velocity ẋ(t), i.e. for v(t)=ẋ(t)

With k = mω^2 the equation of motion is
  m ẍ = –mω^2 x – c (ẋ – ω×x).

It is extremely convenient to define the “relative velocity”
  u(t) := ẋ(t) – ω×x(t).
(Notice that u is exactly the velocity “relative to the turntable”.)

Then the equation of motion becomes
  m ẍ = –mω^2 x – c u.
But we can also “differentiate” the definition of u. Since
  u = ẋ – ω×x,
its time derivative is
  u̇ = ẍ – ω×ẋ.
A short calculation (using ẋ = u + ω×x) shows that the acceleration ẍ may be eliminated; indeed, one obtains
  u̇ = – (c/m) u – ω× u.
That is a linear first–order ODE for u. Its solution is
  u(t) = e^{-(c/m)t} R(-ωt) u(0),
where R(θ) is the usual 2×2 rotation matrix (rotating vectors in the plane by an angle θ) and 
  u(0) = ẋ(0) – ω×x(0).
Now, since by definition ẋ = u + ω×x, we may therefore write the velocity as
  ẋ(t) = ω×x(t) + e^{-(c/m)t} R(-ωt)[ẋ(0) – ω×x(0)].
This is a complete answer for part (b) in terms of the initial conditions.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Solving for the position x(t)

Since u(t) = ẋ(t) – ω×x(t) and we now know u(t), we can “integrate” to find x(t). Write
  ẋ(t) = ω×x(t) + u(t)   with  u(t)= e^{-(c/m)t} R(-ωt)[ẋ(0) – ω×x(0)].
It is very natural now to “undo” the rotation. In fact, one acceptable answer is to write the solution in the “rotating coordinates” by first writing
  x(t) = R(ωt)X(t)
with X(t) a vector in the (nonrotating) frame attached to the turntable. It turns out that one may show (by a short calculation) that
  X(t) = X(0) + ∫₀ᵗ e^{-(c/m)s}R(-ωs)[ẋ(0) – ω×x(0)] ds,
so that the lab–frame solution is
  x(t) = R(ωt) [x(0) + ∫₀ᵗ e^{-(c/m)s} R(-ωs)[ẋ(0) – ω×x(0)] ds ].
Thus the general solution for x(t) is given in closed–form by the formula above.

In words the answer is as follows: The particle’s initial velocity (or, more precisely, its velocity relative to the turntable) decays exponentially at the rate c/m while also “rotating away” with the turntable. Consequently, regardless of its initial conditions it eventually moves with the turntable. (In particular, if it starts at rest in the lab frame it will first be “picked up” and then eventually co–rotate with the table.) A sketch of the motion would show an exponential spiral that converges to a circle.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) To have a fixed point (with respect to the turntable) as a solution we require
  k = m ω².

(b) Defining 
  u(t) = ẋ(t) – ω×x(t)  with  u(0)= ẋ(0) – ω×x(0),
the solution for the velocity is
  ẋ(t) = ω×x(t) + e^{-(c/m)t} R(-ωt)[ẋ(0) – ω×x(0)].

(c) An acceptable answer for the position is
  x(t) = R(ωt) [ x(0) + ∫₀ᵗ e^{-(c/m)s} R(-ωs)[ẋ(0) – ω×x(0)] ds ].
That is, the particle’s motion is given by a circular rotation (with angular speed ω) of its initial position combined with an exponentially decaying transient (proportional to the initial relative velocity). In words, the particle “spirals” from its initial state to eventually follow the turntable in perfect circular motion.

──────────────────────────────
Final boxed answers

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & k = m\omega^2,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \dot{\mathbf{x}}(t)=\omega\times\mathbf{x}(t)+e^{-\tfrac{c}{m}t}\,R(-\omega t)\Bigl[\dot{\mathbf{x}}(0)-\omega\times\mathbf{x}(0)\Bigr],\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \mathbf{x}(t)=R(\omega t)\left\{\mathbf{x}(0)+\int_{0}^{t}e^{-\tfrac{c}{m}s}\,R(-\omega s)\Bigl[\dot{\mathbf{x}}(0)-\omega\times\mathbf{x}(0)\Bigr]\,ds\right\}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

solution:
Step 1. Compute the velocity just before impact.
When free-falling from a height h = 1 m, the speed just before impact is given by
  v = √(2gh),
with g = 9.8 m/s². Thus,
  v = √(2 × 9.8 m/s² × 1 m) = √(19.6) ≈ 4.43 m/s.

Step 2. Determine the deceleration distance and calculate the deceleration.
The person decelerates over a distance d = 1 cm = 0.01 m. Assuming constant deceleration, we use the kinematic relation
  v² = 2ad
which gives the magnitude of the deceleration a as
  a = v²/(2d) = (4.43²)/(2 × 0.01) ≈ (19.6)/(0.02) ≈ 980 m/s².

Step 3. Calculate the total force on his legs.
While decelerating, his legs must overcome both his weight and provide the very large deceleration. The net upward force F_net needed is
  F_net = m × a.
However, the actual force produced by the legs, F_leg, must also counteract the downward force of gravity. That is, the work done by the legs over the deceleration distance must equal the kinetic energy plus the work done against gravity. In other words, over the distance d, the net impulse is
  (F_leg − mg) × d = (1/2) m v².
Thus, solving for F_leg we have
  F_leg = (1/2 m v²)/d + mg.

We can also compute it by noting that the legs must provide an upward acceleration of (a + g), so that
  F_leg = m (a + g).

Substitute the known values:
  F_leg = 80 kg × (980 m/s² + 9.8 m/s²) = 80 × 989.8 m/s² ≈ 79,184 N.

Step 4. Final answer in scientific notation.
So the total force on his legs during deceleration is about 7.9 × 10⁴ Newtons.

Final Answer:
  \[\boxed{7.9 \times 10^4 \text{ N}}\]

We start with the fact that in the Earth frame the moving clock is time‐dilated. If the proper time measured along the spaceship’s worldline is t′ and the Earth time is t, special relativity tells us that

  t′ = t/γ     (1)

where

  γ = 1/√(1 – v²/c²).

Since the traveler synchronizes his clock with that of his Earth friend at t = t′ = 0, both start at zero. Now, when the spaceship’s clock reads one hour (t′ = 1 hour), one would normally, in the Earth’s frame, associate the following time with the spaceship’s event:

  t = γ (1 hour).

Thus, if the Earthman “observes” his own clock directly (which shows his local time t) and by viewing, with proper correction for the light–travel delay, the moving spaceship’s clock showing t′ = 1 hour, he concludes that his own clock reads

  t = γ hours = 1/√(1 – v²/c²) hours.

Step by step reasoning:
1. When the spaceship clock reads one hour (its proper time: t′ = 1 hour), the Earth’s clock (where the spaceship is moving with velocity v) will read a longer time because of time dilation. 
2. In the Earth frame this is expressed by t = γ t′.
3. Therefore, when t′ = 1 hour, we have t = γ · 1 hour = 1/√(1 – v²/c²) hours.
4. Although the Earthman sees the moving clock through a telescope (and must account for light–travel time), he can correct for that delay (knowing the spaceship’s speed and distance) and thereby deduce that at the Earth-time reading of t, the spaceship clock read one hour.

So, the final answer is:

  t = 1/√(1 – v²/c²) hours.

Thus, the Earthman’s clock reads

  \[\boxed{t = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}} \text{ hours when the spaceship clock reads } 1 \text{ hour.}}\]

We will show that when an impulse P is applied perpendicularly at the “free‐end” A of a two–rod system (rods AB and BC, each of mass m and length a) that are joined by a frictionless hinge at B (with the three points A, B, C initially collinear) the “instantaneous” motion (i.e. the very–short–time result immediately after the pulse) is completely determined by

• the translation gained by each rod’s center–of–mass (which, taken together, guarantee that the whole two–rod system acquires total momentum P), 

• the extra “spin” each rod must acquire (because an impulse applied away from a centre–of–mass not only imparts translation but also a rotation), and 

• the additional requirement that the velocity of the common hinge B must be the same when computed “from” each rod.

One acceptable answer was as follows. (Any answer equivalent to the one below is correct.)

Let us fix coordinates so that initially the three points lie on the x–axis with
  A = (–a, 0), B = (0, 0), C = (a, 0),
and let the positive y–direction be that in which the impulse P is applied at A (that is, P is a vector P = (0,P)). Because the table is frictionless no external impulse is transmitted to the other rod; however, the “internal impulse” transmitted at the hinge is such that the instantaneous velocities of B (as computed from the motion of rod AB and of rod BC) must agree.

One may show (by carefully writing the impulse–momentum equations for each rod about its centre–of–mass and then imposing that the velocity vB of the common point B be unique) that the answers come out as

 • For rod AB (with centre–of–mass at M₁ = (–a/2,0)) the centre–of–mass obtains
  V₁ = (0, (P + J_y)/m)
 and its spin rate about M₁ is
  ω₁ = 6(J_y – P)/(m a)
 while for rod BC (with centre–of–mass at M₂ = (a/2,0)) the only impulse is that from the hinge giving
  V₂ = (0, –J_y/m)
 and its spin is
  ω₂ = 6J_y/(m a).

The additional condition is that the velocity of the hinge B must be the same when computed “from” the two rods. Writing the velocity of B (which, for a given rod is the velocity of its centre–of–mass plus the contribution from rotation about the centre–of–mass) one may show that the matching condition forces
  J_y = P/4.
Then a short bit of algebra gives

  V₁ = (0, (P+P/4)/m) = (0, 5P/(4m))  and  V₂ = (0, –P/(4m)).

Now, since in rod AB the end–A (with A – M₁ = (–a/2,0)) gets the extra rotational “kick”
  v₍rot₎(A) = –ω₁ (a/2)      (the minus sign is a matter of our chosen sign convention)
we deduce that
  v_A = V₁ + (0, –ω₁ a/2).
In exactly the same way, one finds for the hinge point B
  v_B = V₁ + (0, ω₁ a/2)    (as computed from rod AB)
or, equivalently, 
  v_B = V₂ – (0, ω₂ a/2)    (as computed from rod BC).
One may then verify that
  v_B = (0, –P/m).
Also, the rates of spin come out as
  ω₁ = –9P/(2m a)   and  ω₂ = 3P/(2m a),
where the negative value of ω₁ indicates that rod AB rotates clockwise while rod BC rotates counterclockwise.

Finally, one may also check that the velocity for the free–end A (which gets the full effect of the impulse) is
  v_A = (0, 7P/(2m))
and that the free–end C acquires
  v_C = (0, P/(2m)).

Thus, immediately after the impulse the three points have the following velocities:
  • A moves upward with speed 7P⁄(2m),
  • B moves downward with speed P⁄m (that is, v_B = –P/m in our y–axis convention) 
  • C moves upward with speed P⁄(2m),
and the two rods acquire “spin” about their centres–of–mass given by
  ω₍AB₎ = –9P⁄(2m a)  and  ω₍BC₎ =  3P⁄(2m a).

Any answer equivalent to the following boxed answer is correct.

We will show step‐by‐step that

(1) The combination (c𝑘, ω) transforms under a Lorentz transformation exactly as any other 4–vector does, and

(2) Using this fact we can derive the relativistic Doppler formulas for light emitted from an atom (with rest–frequency ω₀) when the atom is moving with speed v (with β = v/c) toward or away from the observer.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Showing that (c𝑘, ω) is a relativistic 4–vector

Any electromagnetic wave may be characterized by a phase
  φ = k · r – ωt.
One of the postulates of special relativity is that the phase of a wave is invariant under a Lorentz transformation. (That is, the phase measured in one inertial frame is the same as that measured in another.)

Now write the phase in a manifestly “4–vector” form. Introduce the 4–position
  x^μ = (r, ct).
Then we can define a 4–wavevector as
  k^μ = (𝑘, ω/c)
so that the phase becomes
  φ = k · r – ωt = k^μ x_μ    (using a suitable metric in which time appears with the factor c).
Often, one prefers to write the time–component “up” and include a factor of c with the spatial components. Equivalently, one may write
  (c𝑘, ω)
which is just a rescaling of the components. In any event, the point is that the phase, being a scalar (invariant), is constructed in terms of the inner product of two 4–vectors. Hence, since x^μ is a 4–vector and the phase is invariant, the quantity (c𝑘, ω) (or, equivalently, k^μ = (𝑘, ω/c)) necessarily must transform as a 4–vector under Lorentz transformations.

Thus, (c𝑘, ω) is a relativistic 4–vector.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Deriving the Doppler Shift for an Atom Emitting Light

Let the atom have a rest–frame in which it emits light with angular frequency ω₀. We now wish to find the frequency ω as measured by an observer in the “lab frame” in which the atom moves with constant speed v along the x–axis. There are two cases to consider: light emitted in the direction of motion (as seen in the lab frame, corresponding to the atom “approaching” the observer) and light emitted opposite to the motion (for the “receding” case).

It is simplest to use the 4–vector formulation. In the rest frame S′ (of the emitter) the 4–wavevector is

  k′^μ = ( (ω₀/c) n′, ω₀/c )
          = (components, with n′ being the unit vector in the direction of the photon).

Now, choose coordinates so that the atom moves along the x–axis with velocity v. The Lorentz transformation for a boost in the x–direction gives for the time component (here our 4–vector is written with time as the last component)
  ω = γ ( ω₀ + v k′_x )    (with c’s arranged appropriately)
where γ = 1/√(1 – β²) and k′_x = (ω₀/c) cosθ′. (Here, θ′ is the angle the photon makes with the +x–axis in the rest frame of the emitter.)

Now, the situation must be analyzed according to what “approaching” or “receding” means for the observer. A common and convenient choice is to define the emission direction in the emitter’s rest frame by using the aberration formula so that the photon appears in the lab frame to be traveling toward (or away from) the observer.

A standard choice is as follows:

1. For an atom moving toward the observer, choose coordinates so that in the lab frame the photon is emitted in the +x–direction (the direction of the atom’s motion). In that case, by using the aberration formula the photon is seen in the emitter’s rest frame to be emitted at an angle θ′ satisfying
  cosθ′ = 1.
Thus, k′_x = ω₀/c and the Lorentz transformation gives:
  ω = γ (ω₀ + v (ω₀/c))
    = ω₀ γ (1 + β).

2. For an atom moving away from the observer, the photon must be emitted in the –x–direction in the lab frame. Then, in the emitter’s rest frame, the emission is along −x so that
  cosθ′ = –1,
and hence k′_x = –ω₀/c. The Lorentz transformation then gives:
  ω = γ (ω₀ + v (–ω₀/c))
    = ω₀ γ (1 – β).

It is sometimes preferable to rewrite these in a “symmetric” form. Notice that
  γ (1 + β) = √((1 + β)/(1 – β))
and
  γ (1 – β) = √((1 – β)/(1 + β)).
Thus, one obtains the final relativistic Doppler shift formulas:

• For the atom approaching the observer (blue shifted):
  ω_obs = ω₀ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)),

• For the atom receding from the observer (red shifted):
  ω_obs = ω₀ √((1 – β)/(1 + β)).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The 4–vector (c𝑘, ω) is indeed a relativistic 4–vector because it is defined so that the phase φ = k · r – ωt is invariant under Lorentz transformations; since the 4–position (r, ct) is a 4–vector, the quantity (c𝑘, ω) must transform accordingly.

(b) If an atom at rest emits light with angular frequency ω₀ and moves with velocity v = βc relative to an observer, then the Lorentz transformation yields the observed frequencies:
  for an atom moving toward the observer:
    ω_obs = ω₀ √((1 + β)/(1 – β)),
  for an atom moving away from the observer:
    ω_obs = ω₀ √((1 – β)/(1 + β)).

Thus, our final boxed answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad \text{Since } \phi = \mathbf{k}\cdot\mathbf{r} -\omega t \text{ is invariant, the pair } (c\mathbf{k},\omega) \text{ must transform as a 4-vector.}\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}&\quad \omega_{\text{obs}} = \begin{cases}
\omega_0 \sqrt{\dfrac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}} \quad (\text{approaching}),\\[2mm]
\omega_0 \sqrt{\dfrac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}} \quad (\text{receding}),
\end{cases}\quad \text{with } \beta = \dfrac{v}{c}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Step 1: Identifying effective acceleration at the equator

For a non-rotating planet, we have gravitational acceleration g = GM/R² at any point on the surface. However, due to rotation the effective gravitational acceleration at the equator is reduced by the centrifugal term. Thus, at the equator the effective acceleration is

  g_eff = GM/R² − V²/R,

where V is the given tangential speed at the equator.

Step 2: Using the given condition

We are told that rotation reduces gravity at the equator to ½ that of the pole. At the pole, there is no centrifugal effect, so

  g_pole = GM/R².

Thus, the effective gravitational acceleration at the equator is

  g_eff = g_pole/2.

Setting up the equation:

  GM/R² − V²/R = (1/2)·(GM/R²).

Step 3: Solving for GM in terms of V and R

Rearrange the equation to isolate V²/R:

  GM/R² − (1/2)(GM/R²) = V²/R
  (1/2)(GM/R²) = V²/R.

Multiply both sides by 2:

  GM/R² = 2V²/R.

Then multiply by R:

  GM/R = 2V²     (1)

Step 4: Finding the escape velocity from the pole

The escape velocity from the surface, where gravitational potential energy equals the kinetic energy required to escape, is given by the standard formula:

  v_esc = sqrt(2GM/R).

Substitute the result from (1), where GM/R = 2V²:

  v_esc = sqrt(2 · (2V²))
  v_esc = sqrt(4V²)
  v_esc = 2V.

Step 5: Final Answer

Thus, the escape velocity for a polar particle on the planet expressed as a multiple of V is

  \[ \boxed{2V} \]

We wish to describe a ring (of mass M and radius R) that is free to “swing” about a fixed pivot attached at one point of its rim (its “support‐point”), while a small bead (of mass m) is free to slide without friction on the ring. (See Figure 2.49 in the text.) One acceptable answer is to choose as “generalized coordinates” (see “coordinate‐democracy” in Lagrangian mechanics) the “pendulum angle” φ (of the ring about the fixed pivot) and the “relative angle” ψ locating the bead on the ring. (One may, for example, choose ψ so that when ψ = 0 the bead “coincides” with the pivot; then the “absolute” angular location of the bead is φ + ψ.) With this choice one may show that

────────────────────────────
Part (a). Lagrangian

An acceptable answer is

   L = T – V with
   T = [kinetic energy] = (ring) + (bead) and V = – (potential energy).

One finds that (after some “geometrical work” in writing the bead’s velocity in the inertial frame)
  the kinetic energy is
   T = M R² φ̇² + ½ mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇)²
and the gravitational energy is (choosing the zero so that the potential is – gR cos(…) etc.)
   V = – M gR cos φ – m gR cos(φ + ψ).

Thus one acceptable answer is

   L = M R² φ̇² + ½ mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇)² + M gR cos φ + m gR cos(φ + ψ).  (1)

Any answer which is equivalent to (1) (perhaps after a constant or a change of sign convention) is acceptable.
────────────────────────────
Part (b). Equations of motion

Taking φ and ψ as independent coordinates the Euler–Lagrange equations are

  For φ:
   d/dt { ∂L/∂φ̇ } – ∂L/∂φ = 0,
  and for ψ:
   d/dt { ∂L/∂ψ̇ } – ∂L/∂ψ = 0.

A short calculation gives

  • For φ:
   d/dt [ 2M R² φ̇ + mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇) ]
     – { – M gR sin φ – m gR sin(φ + ψ) } = 0,
or, writing the potential–term “out front,”
   d/dt [ 2M R² φ̇ + mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇) ]
   – M gR sin φ – m gR sin(φ + ψ) = 0.
                                (2)

  • For ψ:
   d/dt [ mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇) ] – { – m gR sin(φ + ψ) } = 0,
i.e.,
   d/dt [ mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇) ] – m gR sin(φ + ψ) = 0.           (3)

These are “the equations of motion.”
────────────────────────────
Part (c). Normal–modes in two limits

For small oscillations we assume that both φ and ψ are small so that sin φ ≈ φ and sin(φ + ψ) ≈ φ + ψ and (later) cos may be expanded to lowest order.

A very useful change of variable is to introduce
  q₁ = φ   and  q₂ = φ + ψ.
Then (1) becomes (after ignoring constant terms) a quadratic Lagrangian. In fact one may show that to quadratic order

  T ≃ M R² φ̇² + ½ mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇)² = M R² (q̇₁)² + ½ mR² (q̇₂)²,
  V ≃ ½ (M + m)gR φ² + ½ m gR (φ + ψ)² = ½ (M + m)gR (q₁)² + ½ m gR (q₂)².
That is, the “ring‐coordinate” q₁ and the “bead coordinate” q₂ decouple. (It is not hard to check that if one “traces through” the definitions one finds the same quadratic approximations by eliminating “small–coupling” terms that are proportional to ψ (or φ) in the kinetic energy.) 

Thus the two normal–modes are

  Mode 1 (“bead mode”): q₂ oscillates with
   ω₁² = g/R      so ω₁ = √(g/R).
In this mode the ring does not move (φ = 0, so that ψ = q₂); the bead slides back and forth along a fixed ring.

  Mode 2 (“ring mode”): q₁ oscillates with
   ω₂² = (M + m)g/(2MR)  so ω₂ = √[(M + m)g/(2MR)].
In this mode the bead “sticks” rigidly to the ring (so that q₂ = q₁, i.e. ψ = 0) and the ring swings as a pendulum about the pivot.
 
Now note that in the two limits one has

  • If m ≫ M then ω₂ ≃ √[m g/(2MR)] is very high compared to ω₁ = √(g/R) — so one normal mode is a very rapid “ring–mode” (in which the bead must follow the ring’s fast motion) while the other is essentially the sliding of the bead on a nearly fixed ring.

  • If m ≪ M then
   ω₂ ≃ √[ (M)g/(2MR)] = √[g/(2R)]
which is lower than ω₁ = √(g/R). In this case the ring’s motion is hardly affected by the bead.
────────────────────────────
Part (d). Normal–mode frequencies (general m and M)

A short algebra (or the method of “diagonalizing” the quadratic Lagrangian in the variables q₁ = φ and q₂ = φ + ψ) shows that the two normal–mode frequencies are exactly

  ω₁ = √(g/R)       and  ω₂ = √[(M + m) g/(2MR)].
One may check that in the limits m ≫ M or m ≪ M the answers reduce to those given in part (c).
 
An answer equivalent to the one given above is entirely acceptable.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

One acceptable answer is

(a) The Lagrangian is 
  
  L = M R² φ̇² + ½ mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇)² + M gR cos φ + m gR cos(φ + ψ).

(b) The Euler–Lagrange equations are 
  
  d/dt[2MR² φ̇ + mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇)] – M gR sin φ – m gR sin(φ + ψ) = 0,
                       (2)
  d/dt[mR² (φ̇ + ψ̇)] – m gR sin(φ + ψ) = 0.      (3)

(c) For small oscillations one may introduce the combinations q₁ = φ and q₂ = φ + ψ so that the quadratic Lagrangian decouples. One then finds that one normal mode (with q₂ varying and q₁ = 0) has frequency 
  ω₁ = √(g/R)
while the other mode (with the bead “sticking” to the ring so that ψ = 0, i.e. q₁ = q₂) has frequency 
  ω₂ = √[(M + m) g/(2MR)].
In the limit m ≫ M the “ring mode” (ω₂) is very high in frequency (the ring is forced to move very rapidly to “carry” the heavy bead), while for m ≪ M one has ω₂ ≃ √[g/(2R)], so that the ring nearly “ignores” the light bead.

(d) Thus the two normal–mode frequencies (for arbitrary m and M) are
  
  ω₁ = √(g/R),     ω₂ = √[(M + m) g/(2MR)].
 
Any answer equivalent to the answer above is correct.

\text{(d)}\quad \omega_1 &= \sqrt{\frac{g}{R}},\qquad

\end{aligned}
}
\]
