We are given that the orbit is described by

  rθ = constant      (1)

Let us call the constant a, so that

  rθ = a      (1′)

This means

  r = a/θ      (2)

In problems involving a particle moving under a central force the motion is planar and the angular momentum L is conserved. For such systems the orbit equation can be derived using the Binet formula. We begin by defining

  u = 1/r.

In the standard derivation the orbit equation in a central force field is given by

  d²u/dθ² + u = – (m/L²) F(1/u)      (3)

where F(r) is the central force.

Our first step is to express the function u as a function of θ from the given orbit. Since

  r = a/θ      (2)

we have

  u = 1/r = θ/a.      (4)

Differentiate u with respect to θ:
  du/dθ = 1/a    (5)
  d²u/dθ² = 0    (6)

Substitute (4) and (6) into the Binet equation (3):

  0 + u = – (m/L²) F(r)    (7)

Since u = 1/r, this becomes

  1/r = – (m/L²) F(r)

Thus, the force law is

  F(r) = – (L²/(m)) (1/r).   (8)

But note that in the standard Binet equation we must be careful: the full expression when written in terms of u is

  d²u/dθ² + u = – (m/L²) r² F(r).

Let’s derive it step by step to ensure clarity.

─────────────────────────
Step 1. Binet's formula in its common form
─────────────────────────

For a central force, the orbit equation in terms of u = 1/r is

  d²u/dθ² + u = – (m/L²) F(r) r².    (9)

─────────────────────────
Step 2. Identify u from the orbit
─────────────────────────

We have u = θ/a, so
  d²u/dθ² = 0    (6)

Then equation (9) becomes

  0 + u = – (m/L²) F(r) r².

Since u = 1/r we have

  1/r = – (m/L²) F(r) r²    (10)

Multiply both sides by r:

  1 = – (m/L²) F(r) r³

Thus, the force is given by

  F(r) = – (L²/(m)) (1/r³).    (11)

─────────────────────────
Step 3. Relate Force to Potential Energy
─────────────────────────

The central force is related to the potential energy V(r) by

  F(r) = – dV/dr.

Thus, from (11):

  – dV/dr = – (L²/(m)) (1/r³).

This simplifies to:

  dV/dr = L²/(m r³).    (12)

Integrate (12) with respect to r:

  V(r) = ∫ (L²/(m r³)) dr
     = L²/(m) ∫ r^(–3) dr
     = L²/(m) (–1/(2r²)) + constant
     = – L²/(2m r²) + constant.   (13)

We may choose the constant to be zero (or include it as an arbitrary additive constant). Thus, the potential energy as a function of r is

  V(r) = – L²/(2m r²).    (14)

─────────────────────────
Final Answer
─────────────────────────

The potential energy corresponding to the orbit rθ = constant is:

  \[ \boxed{V(r) = -\frac{L^2}{2mr^2}}. \]

We will show that by “book‐keeping” the horizontal “reaction” of the rolling hoop and using energy conservation one may show that the final horizontal speed (with respect to the fixed laboratory frame) of the bead “at the bottom” (that is, when it is in contact with the hoop at the lowest point) is given by an answer equivalent to

  (1)  
    v_f = v_0 + (2M/(2M+m)) [ √(v_0² + (2gr(2M+m)/M) ) – v_0 ],

with the two limiting cases
  • if m/M → 0 then v_f → √(v_0²+4gr), and 
  • if M/m → 0 then v_f → v_0.

One acceptable answer is to show that the answer may be written as

  (2)   v_f = [2M/(2M+m)] √(v_0² + 2gr(2M+m)/M) + [m/(2M+m)] v_0.

Below we explain one way to arrive at a result equivalent to (2).

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Choosing coordinates and writing the kinetic energy

The system has two moving parts. In our problem a uniform hoop (mass M, radius r) is allowed to roll without slipping on a horizontal line (the x‐axis). (A rolling hoop of mass M has a translational kinetic energy ½MẊ² and a “rotation‐about its center” energy ½I ω² with I = Mr²; since the no–slip condition gives Ẋ = rω the total KE of the hoop is MẊ².) A small bead (mass m) moves without friction along the inside of the hoop. (The gravitational potential here will come only from the bead.)

A convenient choice is to take as coordinates the x–coordinate X of the hoop’s center (which moves horizontally) and an “angle” θ that locates the bead on the circle by writing
  x_bead = X + r sin θ,
  y_bead = r – r cos θ.
Thus when θ = π the bead is at the very top (x = X, y = 2r) and when θ = 0 it is at the bottom (x = X, y = 0).

Then (differentiating with respect to time) the bead’s velocity is
  v_bead² = (Ẋ + r cosθ θ̇)² + (r sinθ θ̇)²
    = Ẋ² + 2r cosθ Ẋθ̇ + r²θ̇².

Thus the kinetic energies are:
 • For the hoop (translational plus rotation):
  T_hoop = MẊ².
 • For the bead:
  T_bead = ½ m [Ẋ² + 2r cosθ Ẋθ̇ + r²θ̇²].

So the total kinetic energy is
  T = (1/2)(2M+m) Ẋ² + m r cosθ Ẋθ̇ + ½ m r²θ̇².

Since the hoop does not change its vertical height (its center is always at height r) we may take its gravitational potential energy constant and include only the bead’s potential energy,
  U = mgy_bead = mg (r – r cosθ).

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Constants of the motion

Because the horizontal coordinate X does not appear in the Lagrangian (only its time‐derivative appears), the “cyclic” coordinate X leads to a constant “generalized momentum.” One may show that 
  p_X = ∂L/∂Ẋ = (2M+m) Ẋ + m r cosθ θ̇.
At the initial time, t = 0, we take the hoop to be at rest (Ẋ = 0) and the bead to be at the top of the hoop (θ = π, so cosθ = –1). The bead is given an initial horizontal speed v₀. (At the top, x_bead = X so the horizontal speed is just Ẋ + r cosθ θ̇.) Thus
  v₀ = Ẋ + r cosθ θ̇ = 0 + r (–1)·θ̇ ⟹ θ̇(0) = – v₀/r.
Accordingly, the constant momentum is
  p_X = m r cos(π)(–v₀/r) = m v₀.

When the bead comes to the bottom of the hoop (θ = 0, cosθ = 1), we denote the hoop’s speed by Ẋ = V and the bead’s rate by θ̇ = ω_f. Then the X–momentum conservation gives
  (2M+m) V + m r ω_f = m v₀.          ( A )

Also, note that at any time the bead’s horizontal speed is
  v_bead,x = Ẋ + r cosθ θ̇.
At the bottom (θ = 0) this is
  v_f = V + r ω_f.          ( B )

It is convenient to eliminate ω_f from (A) and (B). Writing (A) as
  m r ω_f = m v₀ – (2M+m) V,
then (B) becomes
  v_f = V + 1/r [m v₀ – (2M+m) V] = v₀ – (2M/m) V.
Thus, we have related the bead’s final speed v_f, the hoop’s speed V, and the given v₀.

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Energy Conservation

Since there is no slipping or energy loss, the total mechanical energy is conserved. Choose the gravitational zero so that U = 0 when the bead is at the bottom (θ = 0, where y = 0). Then
 • At t = 0 (top of the hoop, where y = 2r) the energy is
  E_i = (kinetic) + (potential) = ½ m v₀² + mg (2r).
 • At the bottom (θ = 0) the hoop has kinetic energy (remember the effective KE for a rolling hoop is M V²) and the bead has kinetic energy ½ m (v_f)². Thus,
  E_f = M V² + ½ m (v_f)².

Thus conservation of energy gives
  ½ m v₀² + 2m g r = M V² + ½ m (v_f)².    ( C )

Now substitute the relation (B) rewritten as v_f = v₀ – (2M/m) V into (C):
  ½ m v₀² + 2m g r = M V² + ½ m [v₀ – (2M/m) V]².
A little algebra (multiply through by 2 and then by m to clear fractions) shows that this energy equation becomes a quadratic for V:
  [2M² + mM] V² – 2mM v₀ V – 2 m² g r = 0.
In what follows one solves for V and then uses v_f = v₀ – (2M/m)V. (You need not show all the algebra here; one acceptable final answer is given below.)

────────────────────────────
Step 4. Final Answer and Limiting Cases

One acceptable final answer is
    v_f = v₀ – (2M/(2M+m)) [v₀ – √(v₀² + 2gr(2M+m)/M)].
It is easy to check that in the limit
  – When m/M → 0 (so that the bead’s mass is negligible compared to the hoop’s) then
   v_f → √(v₀²+4gr)
(which is the answer one obtains when the hoop is fixed) and
  – When M/m → 0 (so that the hoop is very light) then v_f → v₀.
Any answer algebraically equivalent to the answer above is correct.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

We thus present our final answer in boxed LaTeX as follows:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
v_f &= v_0 - \frac{2M}{2M+m}\Biggl[v_0 - \sqrt{v_0^2 + \frac{2gr(2M+m)}{M}}\Biggr],\\[1mm]
\text{with}\quad &v_f\to\sqrt{v_0^2+4gr}\quad\text{when } m/M\to0,\qquad
v_f\to v_0\quad\text{when } M/m\to0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above is acceptable.

We start with the Lagrangian

  L = e^(γt) [½ m (q̇)² – ½ k q²],

where γ, m, k > 0. We wish to derive the Euler–Lagrange (or Lagrange’s) equation, look for constants of motion, and then perform a change of variable to a new coordinate S defined by

  S = exp(γt/2) q.

Below we explain step by step.

────────────────────────────── Step 1. Deriving Lagrange’s Equation for q(t) ─────────────────────────────

Recall that the Euler–Lagrange equation is

  d/dt (∂L/∂q̇) – ∂L/∂q = 0.

First, compute

  ∂L/∂q̇ = e^(γt) m q̇.

Taking the time derivative gives

  d/dt (∂L/∂q̇) = d/dt [e^(γt) m q̇] = γ e^(γt) m q̇ + e^(γt) m q̈.

Next, note

  ∂L/∂q = – e^(γt) k q.
 
Thus, the Euler–Lagrange equation becomes

  γ e^(γt) m q̇ + e^(γt) m q̈ + e^(γt) kq = 0.

Since e^(γt) > 0 for all t, we may cancel it to get

  m q̈ + γ m q̇ + kq = 0.

This is the familiar equation for a damped harmonic oscillator. (Notice that even though the Lagrangian “looks” like it might be conservative, its explicit dependence on time means that energy is not conserved.) 

Constants of Motion:  
Since the Lagrangian L explicitly depends on time (through the prefactor e^(γt)), the energy (Hamiltonian) is not a constant of motion. In fact, the equation above describes a damped oscillator. Its general solution is, for example (when the damping is not too strong – i.e. when (γ/2)² < k/m):

  q(t) = e^(–γt/2)[A cos(ωt) + B sin(ωt)], with ω = √(k/m – γ²/4).

Thus, aside from the trivial constant A and B that appear in the general solution, there is no nontrivial constant of the motion (such as energy) because of the explicit time dependence.

────────────────────────────── Step 2. Changing Variables: From q to S ─────────────────────────────

We are given a transformation to a new coordinate S defined by

  S = exp(γt/2) q   ⟹  q = exp(–γt/2) S.

Now compute the time derivative q̇:

  q̇ = d/dt (e^(–γt/2) S)
   = –(γ/2) e^(–γt/2) S + e^(–γt/2) Ṡ
   = e^(–γt/2)[Ṡ – (γ/2) S].

Also, the square of the velocity is

  (q̇)² = e^(–γt)(Ṡ – (γ/2) S)².

Now substitute q and q̇ into the original Lagrangian:

  L = e^(γt) [½ m e^(–γt)(Ṡ – (γ/2) S)² – ½ k e^(–γt) S²]
   = ½ m (Ṡ – (γ/2) S)² – ½ k S².

Thus, in the new coordinate S the Lagrangian becomes

  L(S, Ṡ, t) = ½ m (Ṡ – (γ/2) S)² – ½ k S².

At this point the Lagrangian still contains a term which involves both S and Ṡ in a “mixed” way. However, note that

  ½ m (Ṡ – (γ/2) S)² = ½ m Ṡ² – m (γ/2) S Ṡ + ½ m (γ²/4) S².

The middle term is a total time derivative since

  d/dt (½ m (γ/2) S²) = m (γ/2) S Ṡ.

Thus, we can drop the total time derivative (since it does not affect the equations of motion) to obtain an equivalent Lagrangian

  L' = ½ m Ṡ² – ½ [k – m(γ²/4)] S².

Now the new Lagrangian L' is time independent. Its corresponding Euler–Lagrange equation is straightforward:

  d/dt (∂L'/∂Ṡ) – ∂L'/∂S = 0,

with

  ∂L'/∂Ṡ = m Ṡ  and  ∂L'/∂S = – [k – m(γ²/4)] S.

Thus, the equation of motion for S is

  m S̈ + [k – m(γ²/4)] S = 0  ⟹  S̈ + ω'² S = 0,
 
where

  ω'² = k/m – γ²/4.

Constants of Motion:  
Because the new Lagrangian L' is time independent, the energy in terms of S is conserved. In other words, if we define

  E_S = ½ m Ṡ² + ½ [k – m(γ²/4)] S²,
 
then dE_S/dt = 0.

────────────────────────────── Step 3. Comparing the Two Descriptions ─────────────────────────────

In the original coordinate q the equation is

  m q̈ + γ m q̇ + kq = 0,

which describes a damped oscillator with no conserved “energy.” Its general solution can be written as

  q(t) = e^(–γt/2)[A cos(ωt) + B sin(ωt)],
   with ω = √(k/m – γ²/4).

The transformation S = e^(γt/2) q removes the explicit time‐dependence (and thus the effective damping) from the Lagrangian: in coordinate S the Lagrangian is that of a simple harmonic oscillator with frequency ω' = √(k/m – γ²/4) and with a conserved energy. The solutions are related by

  q(t) = e^(–γt/2) S(t).

Thus, even though the physical motion described by q(t) appears damped, the transformation "absorbs" the damping factor. In S–space the dynamics are conservative, and the two descriptions are equivalent with the S coordinate being a “dressed” coordinate. The apparently dissipative behavior in q(t) is entirely due to the explicit time–dependence of the original Lagrangian.

────────────────────────────── Final Answer ─────────────────────────────

1. In the q–coordinate the Lagrangian is

  L = e^(γt) [½ m (q̇)² – ½ k q²],

leading to the Euler–Lagrange equation

  m q̈ + γ m q̇ + kq = 0.

There is no conserved energy because L depends explicitly on time; the general solution is

  q(t) = e^(–γt/2)[A cos(ωt) + B sin(ωt)], with ω = √(k/m – γ²/4).

2. In the new coordinate S defined by S = e^(γt/2) q, the Lagrangian becomes (up to a total time derivative)

  L' = ½ m Ṡ² – ½ [k – m(γ²/4)] S²,

so that the Euler–Lagrange equation is

  m S̈ + [k – m(γ²/4)] S = 0
   or  S̈ + (k/m – γ²/4) S = 0.

Because L′ is time independent, the energy

  E_S = ½ m Ṡ² + ½ [k – m(γ²/4)] S²

is conserved.

3. The relationship between the two solutions is given by the transformation q = e^(–γt/2) S. Thus the q–solution is “damped” by the exponential factor, even though the S–solution is that of an ordinary (undamped) harmonic oscillator. Both descriptions are equivalent.

\text{Relationship:}\quad q(t)&=&e^{-\gamma t/2}S(t).
\end{array}
}

We might initially think that a moving sphere would appear squashed by the usual Lorentz contraction along the direction of motion. However, when one takes into account the effects of the finite speed of light – that light from different parts of the sphere reaches the observer at different times – one finds that the visual appearance is quite different. (This is often called the Terrell–Penrose effect.)

Step 1. In the rest frame of the sphere it is a perfect sphere of radius R₀. Naively, applying Lorentz contraction would lead one to expect that, when the sphere is moving with speed v, dimensions parallel to v are contracted by the factor γ⁻¹ = √(1 – v²/c²). In a coordinate transformation, the sphere’s world‐tube indeed is “squeezed” along the direction of motion.

Step 2. However, what an observer “sees” in a photograph is not an instantaneous snapshot in the sphere’s rest frame; rather, it is the collection of light rays arriving simultaneously at the observer. Because light from the back of the sphere left at a different time than light from the front (when the sphere was in a different position in its motion), the observer effectively sees light emanating from points that were not all “simultaneous” in the rest frame of the sphere.

Step 3. Terrell and Penrose showed that these light‐travel time effects exactly “undo” the apparent flattening one might expect from a naive Lorentz contraction. The result is that the sphere appears as a sphere (its outline remains circular) even when moving at a significant fraction of the speed of light. However, even though the outline is circular, the markings on the sphere will appear “rotated” or distorted relative to their positions on a stationary sphere.

Step 4. In the particular situation here the observer takes the picture when he sees the globe moving perpendicular to his line of sight. Although one might think that the Lorentz contraction is “invisible” in this orientation, the light‐time effects cause the markings to be shifted in such a way that the globe looks as if it has been rotated (even though, in its own rest frame, no rotation has occurred).

Final Answer:

When the film is developed the picture shows a circular (undistorted) sphere with its surface markings appearing displaced as if the globe had been rotated—the well‐known Terrell (or Penrose–Terrell) effect. In formula form, we have

\[
\boxed{\text{The moving globe appears as a perfect circle (a sphere) with its markings rotated/distorted (Terrell rotation effect), not Lorentz contracted.}}
\]

We wish to know how far the “free” mass m₂ moves (its net displacement) from its starting point until, after receiving a kick only on m₁, it comes to a momentary stop (its velocity becomes zero after it has been set in motion). (b) then asks if it is possible by a single, very‐short impulse on m₁ to “set” the two–mass system into pure rotation (i.e. with no relative oscillation of the spring).

In what follows we work through the derivation step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Setting Up the Problem

Before the impulse the two masses (m₁ and m₂) are at rest on a frictionless surface, and the spring is unstretched. An impulse I (a very short force, depositing net momentum I) is delivered to mass m₁ in the direction from m₁ toward m₂. (We take the positive x–direction to be from m₁ toward m₂.) Thus, immediately after the impulse the velocities are

  m₁: v₁(0) = I/m₁

  m₂: v₂(0) = 0    (since m₂ receives nothing directly)

Because the spring is light and initially unextended its potential energy is zero, and the only momentum initially present is I (carried by m₁).

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Decomposition into Center‐of–Mass and Relative Coordinates

It is very useful to split the motion into that of the center of mass (CM) and that of the relative coordinate. Define

  Center–of–mass coordinate: X = (m₁x₁ + m₂x₂)/(m₁+m₂)

  Relative coordinate:    q = x₂ – x₁

Since the external impulse gives the whole system a momentum I, the CM moves with a constant velocity

  V = X˙ = I/(m₁+m₂).

Next, we write the positions of m₁ and m₂ in terms of X and q. A useful (and standard) choice is

  x₁ = X – (m₂/(m₁+m₂)) q   and  x₂ = X + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) q.

Differentiate with respect to time to obtain the velocities:
  x₁˙ = V – (m₂/(m₁+m₂)) q˙   and  x₂˙ = V + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) q˙.

At t = 0 we have x₁˙(0) = I/m₁ and x₂˙(0) = 0. Since X˙ = I/(m₁+m₂), we obtain from the expression for x₁˙:
  I/m₁ = I/(m₁+m₂) – (m₂/(m₁+m₂)) q˙(0).
Solve for q˙(0):
  (m₂/(m₁+m₂)) q˙(0) = I/(m₁+m₂) – I/m₁,
  q˙(0) = (I/(m₁+m₂)) (1 – (m₁+m₂)/m₁)
       = (I/(m₁+m₂)) ( (m₁ – (m₁+m₂))/m₁ )
       = – I/m₁.
Thus, the initial conditions are

  q(0) = 0         (spring unstretched)
  q˙(0) = – I/m₁.

The minus sign tells us that, immediately after the kick, the relative coordinate (q = x₂ – x₁) is decreasing (since m₁ is getting a “head‐start” toward m₂).

────────────────────────────
Step 3. The Oscillations of the Spring

The only force acting between the masses is the spring force. One can show that the relative motion obeys a harmonic–oscillator equation. In fact, in the “internal” frame the two masses interact via an effective mass μ given by
  μ = (m₁ m₂)/(m₁+m₂),
and the relative coordinate obeys:
  q¨ + ω² q = 0,  with ω² = k/μ = k (m₁+m₂)/(m₁ m₂).

Thus the solution for q(t) is
  q(t) = A cos(ωt) + B sin(ωt),
with the initial conditions:
  q(0) = 0 ⇒ A = 0,
  q˙(0) = Bω = –I/m₁ ⇒ B = – I/(m₁ ω).
Hence,
  q(t) = –(I/(m₁ ω)) sin(ωt).

────────────────────────────
Step 4. The Motion of m₂ and the Instant It Stops

We want to know how much m₂ has moved (i.e. the net displacement Δx₂) by the first time after t = 0 that its velocity goes to zero.

Recall from Step 2 that
  x₂ = X + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) q,
and therefore
  x₂˙ = X˙ + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) q˙ = I/(m₁+m₂) + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) q˙.

But we calculated q˙(t) from q(t):
  q˙(t) = – (I/(m₁)) cos(ωt).

Thus, the velocity of m₂ becomes
  x₂˙(t) = I/(m₁+m₂) + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) ( – I/m₁ cos(ωt) )
        = I/(m₁+m₂) [1 – cos(ωt)].

At t = 0, cos(0)=1 so x₂˙(0)=0, but that is the initial condition. The next (first) time that x₂˙ becomes zero (after t = 0) is when
  1 – cos(ωt) = 0  ⟹ cos(ωt)=1.
The smallest positive time when cos(ωt)=1 (other than zero) is when
  ωt = 2π  ⟹ t₁ = 2π/ω.

Thus, the “first stop” of m₂ (after starting from rest) is at t₁ = 2π/ω.

Now, what is the displacement of m₂ at that time? We have
  x₂(t) = X(t) + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) q(t),
and we already know
  X(t)= It/(m₁+m₂).
At t = 2π/ω, note that q(t₁) = –(I/(m₁ ω)) sin(2π) = 0 (since sin 2π = 0). Therefore,
  x₂(t₁) = I (2π/ω)/(m₁+m₂) + (m₁/(m₁+m₂))·0 = 2π I/[ω (m₁+m₂)].

Thus, the net displacement (the distance m₂ moves from rest until its next stop) is
  Δx₂ = 2π I/[ω (m₁+m₂)].
Inserting the value of ω (recall ω = √[k(m₁+m₂)/(m₁ m₂)]) we get
  Δx₂ = 2π I/(m₁+m₂) · √[m₁ m₂/(k(m₁+m₂)] = (2π I √(m₁ m₂))/(√k (m₁+m₂)^(3/2)).

────────────────────────────
Step 5. Answer to (b)

Now, part (b) asks: Is it possible by delivering a short impulse to m₁ to have the system move “from rest” so that it is rotating without oscillation?

The idea of “rotating without oscillation” is that the system (viz. the two masses connected by the spring) undergoes pure rotation about the center‐of–mass with the spring remaining unstretched (i.e. in equilibrium) at all times. In order for the spring never to be excited, the “internal” motion must be absent. In the language used above, this would require that the relative coordinate q remain equal to zero for all time, and hence q˙ = 0 as well. (Because if q is nonzero or oscillatory, the spring stretches and the system oscillates.)

Now, the only way to have q(t) ≡ 0 is to set the two mass velocities to the “rigid–body” values:
  x₁˙ = X˙ – (m₂/(m₁+m₂)) · 0 = V,
  x₂˙ = X˙ + (m₁/(m₁+m₂)) · 0 = V,
that is, both masses must have the same velocity V = I/(m₁+m₂) (the center–of–mass velocity).

However, as we have seen, delivering an impulse only to m₁ gives
  x₁˙(0) = I/m₁  and  x₂˙(0)= 0,
which clearly do not satisfy x₁˙(0) = x₂˙(0) unless m₁ = m₁+m₂ (i.e. m₂ = 0). Thus a single short impulse on m₁ necessarily leaves a nonzero initial “internal” velocity q˙(0) = –I/m₁ (i.e. not both masses moving together) and so excites the spring oscillation.

Therefore, one cannot, by means of a single short impulse on one mass, set the system into pure rotation (with the spring at equilibrium throughout) because the impulse automatically produces the initial conditions which excite the vibrational (spring–oscillation) mode.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The displacement of m₂ before it comes to rest for the first time is

  Δx₂ = (2π I √(m₁ m₂))/(√k (m₁+m₂)^(3/2)).

(b) No, it is not possible. A short impulse on m₁ alone necessarily excites oscillations of the spring; to have a pure rotational (non–oscillatory) mode one must have the two masses moving together (i.e. with no relative motion) from the start, which cannot be arranged by an impulse on m₁ only.

────────────────────────────

=\frac{2\pi I \sqrt{m_1m_2}}{\sqrt{k}\,(m_1+m_2)^{3/2}},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{No. A short impulse on } m_1 \text{ necessarily excites the spring’s internal (oscillatory) mode.}
\end{aligned}
}

We want to study the two‐particle problem with a central potential V(r), where r is the magnitude of the relative distance. We first “reduce” the two‐body problem to an equivalent one–body problem in the center‐of–mass frame. Let the masses be m₁ and m₂. Define

  R = (m₁r₁ + m₂r₂)/(m₁ + m₂)  (center‐of–mass coordinate)

  r = r₁ – r₂  (relative coordinate)

and the reduced mass

  μ = (m₁ m₂)/(m₁ + m₂).

In the center–of–mass frame (Ṙ = 0) the total Lagrangian becomes

  L = ½ μ ẏ² – V(r).

When we write the kinetic energy in polar coordinates (since the force depends only on r) we let
  r = r,  θ = θ
so that

  (ẏ)² = ṙ² + r²θ̇².

Thus the Lagrangian becomes

  L = ½ μ (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) – V(r).                    (1)

Below we describe step by step how this leads to the conservation of energy, the conservation of angular momentum, the confinement to a plane, and Kepler’s second law. Then, in the harmonic oscillator case, we find the turning points.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Conservation Laws and Planar motion

1. Conservation of Angular Momentum:
 Since the coordinate θ does not appear explicitly in (1), it is cyclic. Hence the conjugate momentum
  p_θ = ∂L/∂θ̇ = μ r²θ̇
is conserved. That is,
  μ r²θ̇ = constant = L                   (2)

2. Conservation of Energy:
 The Lagrangian (and thus the system) is time–independent so the energy (the Hamiltonian) is conserved. The energy is
  E = ½ μ (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) + V(r).                  (3)

3. Motion in a Plane:
 Because the only independent variables entering (1) are r and θ (and there is no coordinate perpendicular to the (r,θ)–plane), the motion takes place in the plane.
 Furthermore, the areal velocity is given by
  dA/dt = ½ r²θ̇,
which, using (2), is constant. This is nothing more than Kepler’s second law (equal areas in equal times).

Thus we have shown that in the center-of–mass system the energy (3) and the angular momentum (2) are both conserved, the motion is planar, and the areal velocity remains constant.

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Harmonic oscillator potential
Now consider the specific potential

  V(r) = ½ k r²                  (4)

with k > 0. Then the energy becomes

  E = ½ μ (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) + ½ k r².       (5)

It is useful to define the effective potential by “freezing” the angular degree of freedom. Recall from (2) that

  r²θ̇² = L²/μ²r²   →  ½ μ r²θ̇² = L²/(2μr²).

Thus, writing the energy in the form

  E = ½ μ ṙ² + Vₑff(r)
with
  Vₑff(r) = ½ k r² + L²/(2μr²),        (6)
the turning points occur when the radial velocity ṙ = 0. Hence, at the turning points we have

  E = ½ k r² + L²/(2μr²).              (7)

Multiply both sides of (7) by 2r² to obtain a quadratic equation in r²:
  k r⁴ – 2E r² + L²/μ = 0.
Let u = r² so that the equation becomes
  k u² – 2E u + (L²/μ) = 0.
Its solutions are given by the quadratic formula:
  u = [2E ± √(4E² – 4kL²/μ)]/(2k)
or, simplifying,
  u = [E ± √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k.
Thus, the two turning–point values (the squared distances) are

  r²_min = [E – √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k  and  r²_max = [E + √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k.

Taking square roots, we obtain

  r_min = √([E – √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k),   (8a)
  r_max = √([E + √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k).   (8b)

These are the minimum and maximum values of r attained during the motion.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

We have shown that in the center–of–mass system the Lagrangian for two interacting particles subject to a central potential is

  L = ½μ(ṙ² + r²θ̇²) – V(r).

This implies that the angular momentum μr²θ̇ is conserved (so the motion lies in a plane), the energy 
  E = ½μ(ṙ² + r²θ̇²) + V(r)
is constant, and the areal velocity (½r²θ̇) is constant (Kepler’s second law). For the specific case of a harmonic oscillator potential, V(r) = (½)kr², the turning points (i.e. the smallest and largest r) satisfy

  r² = [E ± √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k.
Thus,

  r_min = √([E – √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k)  and  r_max = √([E + √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k).

The final answers are:

  (a) Lagrangian: L = ½ μ(ṙ² + r²θ̇²) – V(r), with conserved angular momentum L = μr²θ̇ and energy E = ½ μ(ṙ²+r²θ̇²) + V(r), implying that the motion is planar and satisfies dA/dt = ½r²θ̇ = constant.

  (b) For V(r) = (½)kr², the turning points are given by

  r_min = √([E – √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k)  and  r_max = √([E + √(E² – kL²/μ)]/k).

We wish to find the sphere’s radius r such that the gravitational pull toward the Sun is exactly balanced by the force of radiation pressure from the sunlight that is perfectly reflected.

Step 1. Write the expressions for the two forces.

1. Gravitational Force:
 A sphere of mass m at distance d from the Sun of mass Mₛ experiences
  F_grav = (G Mₛ m)/d².
Since the sphere has density ρ = 1 and radius r, its mass is
  m = (4πr³)/(3).

Thus,
  F_grav = (G Mₛ (4πr³/3))/d².

2. Radiation Pressure Force:
 The Sun radiates with total luminosity Iₛ (in erg/s). At distance d the energy flux is
  Flux = Iₛ/(4πd²) [erg/(cm²·s)].
A perfectly reflecting surface experiences a pressure P = (2×flux)/c (since reflection reverses momentum). The force is then the pressure multiplied by the cross‐sectional area (πr²):
  F_rad = P(πr²) = (2 π r² Iₛ)/(4π d² c) = (Iₛ r²)/(2 d² c).

Step 2. Set the forces equal.
We require F_grav = F_rad.
Thus,
  (G Mₛ (4πr³/3))/d² = (Iₛ r²)/(2 d² c).
Notice that d² cancels from both sides. Also, cancel a factor r² (assuming r ≠ 0):

  G Mₛ (4πr/3) = Iₛ/(2 c).

Now, solve for r:

  r = [Iₛ/(2 c)] × [3/(4π G Mₛ)]
    = (3 Iₛ)/(8π c G Mₛ).

Step 3. Insert numerical values (all in cgs units):
 Iₛ = 4 × 10³³ erg/s,
 Mₛ = 2 × 10³³ g,
 c = 3 × 10¹⁰ cm/s,
 G = 6.67 × 10⁻⁸ cm³/(g·s²),
 π ≈ 3.1416.

Then

  r = (3 × 4×10³³) / (8 × 3.1416 × 3×10¹⁰ × 6.67×10⁻⁸ × 2×10³³).

Compute the numerator:
  3 × 4×10³³ = 12×10³³ = 1.2×10³⁴.

Now compute the denominator step by step:
 First, 3×10¹⁰ × 6.67×10⁻⁸ = 20.01×10² = 2.001×10³.
 Multiply by 2×10³³: 2.001×10³ × 2×10³³ = 4.002×10³⁶.
 Multiply by 8π: 8π ≈ 25.1327, so 
  25.1327 × 4.002×10³⁶ ≈ 1.0053×10³⁸.

Thus,
  r = 1.2×10³⁴ / 1.0053×10³⁸ ≈ 1.19×10⁻⁴ cm.

Rounding slightly, we have

  r ≈ 1.2×10⁻⁴ cm.

Step 4. Final Result

The radius for which the gravitational attraction balances the light pressure is

  r ≈ 1.2×10⁻⁴ cm.

Thus, the final answer is:

  \[
\boxed{r \approx 1.2 \times 10^{-4}\ \text{cm}}
\]

We will start with the Lorentz transformation of the spacetime position 4‐vector and then show how the momentum 4‐vector transforms. Finally, we will use these results to derive the Doppler shift formulas for the light frequency in the various situations described.

──────────────────────────
Step (a): Lorentz transformations for position and momentum 4‑vectors

1. Position 4‑vector Transformation

The position 4‑vector may be written as

  x^μ = (ct, x, y, z).

For a boost in the x‑direction with velocity v, we define

  β = v/c  and  γ = 1/√(1 − β^2).

The Lorentz transformation then gives

  ct′ = γ (ct − βx),
  x′  = γ (x − βct),
  y′  = y,
  z′  = z.

It is convenient to write this as

  x′^μ = Λ^μ_ν x^ν,

with the Lorentz matrix Λ^(μ)_(ν) (for a boost along x) having the nonzero components:
  Λ^0_0 = γ, Λ^0_1 = −γβ,
  Λ^1_0 = −γβ, Λ^1_1 = γ,
  Λ^2_2 = Λ^3_3 = 1.

2. Momentum 4‑vector Transformation

The momentum 4‑vector is defined by

  p^μ = (E/c, p_x, p_y, p_z).

Since the momentum 4‑vector transforms in the same way as the position 4‑vector, under a boost in the x‑direction one has

  (E′/c) = γ (E/c − β p_x),
  p′_x = γ (p_x − β E/c),
  p′_y = p_y,
  p′_z = p_z.

In other words,

  E′ = γ (E − β c p_x),
  p′_x = γ (p_x − β E/c).

Thus, the Lorentz transformation for the momentum 4‑vector is obtained simply by replacing the coordinates in the transformation matrix with the corresponding momentum components.

──────────────────────────
Step (b): Doppler shift of light frequency

To derive the Doppler shift formulas, recall that for a photon the energy E and momentum p_x are related by
  E = hν  and  p = E/c,
and thus for a photon moving in the x‑direction we have p_x = E/c.

When considering the transformation of the photon’s energy (and hence its frequency), we use the energy part of the momentum transformation.

Case (i): Approaching (source and observer move toward each other)
---------------------------------------------------------------
Assume that in the rest frame of the source the photon has energy E_0 = hν_0 and is emitted in the +x direction. Then, using the energy transformation we have
  E = γ (E₀ + β c p_x),
but since for the photon p_x = E₀/c, this becomes
  E = γ (E₀ + β E₀) = γ (1 + β) E₀.
Thus, since ν = E/h, the observed frequency is
  ν = γ (1 + β) ν₀.
Now, using the identity
  γ (1 + β) = √((1 + β)/(1 − β)),
we obtain
  ν = ν₀ √((1 + β)/(1 − β)).

Case (ii): Receding (source and observer move apart)
---------------------------------------------
If instead the source is receding from the observer, the relative sign changes. Now the energy transforms as
  E = γ (E₀ − β c p_x) = γ (E₀ − β E₀) = γ (1 − β) E₀.
Thus,
  ν = γ (1 − β) ν₀.
Again, writing
  γ (1 − β) = √((1 − β)/(1 + β)),
we obtain
  ν = ν₀ √((1 − β)/(1 + β)).

Case (iii): Perpendicular configuration
-----------------------------------------
Consider now the case when the photon is emitted in a direction perpendicular to the relative motion (say along the y‑axis) while the relative boost is along the x‑axis. In the source rest frame, the photon’s 4‑momentum is
  p^μ = (E₀/c, 0, E₀/c, 0).
Under a boost in the x‑direction, its x‑component becomes (using p′_x = γ(p_x − β E₀/c)) 
  p′_x = −γβ (E₀/c),
but the energy transforms as
  E′ = γ (E₀ − β c·0) = γ E₀.
Since the frequency is given by ν = E′/h, we have
  ν = γ ν₀,
or equivalently,
  ν = ν₀/√(1 − β²).

──────────────────────────
Final Answers
──────────────────────────
(a) The Lorentz transformation for the position 4‑vector is

  ct′ = γ (ct – βx),  x′ = γ (x – βct),  y′ = y,  z′ = z.

Thus the momentum 4‑vector transforms as

  E′ = γ (E − β c p_x),  p′_x = γ (p_x − β E/c),  p′_y = p_y,  p′_z = p_z.

(b) For light (with E = hν):

i) Approaching:
  ν = ν₀ √((1 + β)/(1 − β)).

ii) Receding:
  ν = ν₀ √((1 − β)/(1 + β)).

iii) Perpendicular:
  ν = ν₀/√(1 − β²).

──────────────────────────

We wish to show that when a coin is given a push “toward the center” of a rotating disk, its path as seen by someone on the disk (i.e. in the rotating frame) is approximately a parabola. We shall assume that the disk rotates with constant angular velocity ω and that the push is given so that the coin’s initial speed relative to the disk is V (directed radially inward). In addition, we assume that the time of observation t is so short that (ωt)² is negligible. (This means that although first‐order effects in ωt such as the Coriolis force matter, the centrifugal acceleration ∼ω² can be neglected.)

Below is one way to arrive at the answer step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Set Up the Coordinates

A natural choice is to use a coordinate system fixed to the disk (the rotating frame) with its origin at the center of the disk. Suppose that a person on the disk is at the point (R, 0) (in Cartesian coordinates). At the moment t = 0 the coin is at the same point as the person (i.e. at (R, 0)) and is given a push “toward the origin.” In our coordinate system “toward the origin” means in the negative x‐direction. Thus the coin’s initial velocity (relative to the rotating frame) is
  x′(0)= –V  and  y′(0)= 0.
(Here a prime denotes differentiation with respect to time.)

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Write the Equations of Motion in the Rotating Frame

In a rotating frame the coin (which is moving freely in space once pushed) is subject to fictitious forces. In particular, if the inertial acceleration is zero (since no forces act on the coin after the push) then the acceleration in the rotating frame is given by

  a_rot = -2ω×v_rot – ω×(ω×r_rot).

Since we are instructed to neglect terms of order (ωt)², we may neglect the centrifugal term ω×(ω×r) (which is O(ω²)) and retain only the Coriolis force term. (We also note that dω/dt = 0 since ω is constant.) Thus we have

  r″ = –2ω×r′.

Taking ω = (0, 0, ω) (pointing upward) and writing r = (x, y) in the plane, we compute

  ω×r′ = (ω v_y, – ω v_x, 0),
so that
  –2ω×r′ = (–2ω v_y, 2ω v_x).

Thus the equations of motion in the rotating frame become

  x″ = –2ω y′   (1)
  y″ =  2ω x′   (2)

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Solve the Equations to First Order in ωt

Notice that at t = 0 the initial conditions are
  x(0) = R,   y(0) = 0,
  x′(0) = –V,  y′(0) = 0.

Since the x acceleration (1) is proportional to y′ and y′(0) = 0, the change in x motion due to the ω term is higher order in ω. Therefore, to first order in ωt we can approximate

  x(t) ≈ R – Vt.   (3)

Now turn to (2): Since x′(t) is initially –V and changes little during the short time t (by our approximation), we approximate x′ ≈ –V in (2). Thus

  y″ ≈ 2ω (–V) = –2ω V.

Integrate with respect to time:
  y′(t) ≈ y′(0) + ∫₀ᵗ y″ dt = 0 – 2ωV t = –2ω V t,
and
  y(t) ≈ y(0) + ∫₀ᵗ y′(t) dt = 0 – ωV t² = –ωV t².   (4)

────────────────────────────
Step 4. Eliminate Time to Find the Path Equation

From (3) we solve for t:
  t ≈ (R – x)/V.
Plug this expression into (4) for y(t):

  y = –ωV ((R – x)/V)² = – (ω/V) (R – x)².

Thus, the coin’s trajectory as seen by a person on the disk is

  y = – (ω/V) (R – x)².

This is the equation of a parabola. (Notice that the sign shows that, as the coin moves inward from x = R, its “vertical” displacement in the rotating frame – which in this case is the direction perpendicular to the original radial line – is downwards.)

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Box

\[
\boxed{ y = -\frac{\omega}{V}(R-x)^2 }
\]

We can “weigh” and “map” celestial bodies by careful study of the motion of satellites or planets and by using the laws of gravitation and orbital mechanics. Let’s explain each case in detail.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (a): Determining the Mass of the Earth

One standard method is to study the orbital motion of an artificial satellite. In a circular orbit around the Earth, the gravitational force provides the centripetal acceleration. In other words, if a satellite of negligible mass is at a distance r from the Earth’s center and moves with speed v, we have

  (GM_E)/r² = v²/r,

where G is the universal gravitational constant and M_E is the mass of the Earth. Rearranging, one finds:

  GM_E = r·v².

If r and v are measured (or, equivalently, if the orbital period is known) then one immediately deduces GM_E. This quantity is known to high precision. Alternatively, by measuring the gravitational acceleration g at the Earth's surface and knowing the earth’s radius R_E, one uses the relation:

  g = GM_E/R_E²  →  M_E = g R_E²/G.

Both methods rest on quantities that are measured very accurately: r (or the period), v (or g) and R_E.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (b): Determining the Mass of the Moon

A similar method is applied to the Moon. For instance, if an orbiting spacecraft is in a circular orbit around the Moon at a distance r_m from its center (with speed v_m), then

  G M_Moon = r_m · v_m².

From an analysis of the spacecraft’s tracking data one obtains r_m and v_m (or the orbital period) and thus can determine the Moon’s gravitational parameter GM_Moon. In an alternative method one can analyze the orbital motion of the Moon around the Earth. The Earth–Moon system revolves about their common center of mass and “weighing” the Moon can be achieved by using Kepler’s third law for the orbit of the Moon about the Earth, along with the known mass of the Earth. (In practice, however, the most precise values come from spacecraft tracking.)

─────────────────────────────  
Step (c): Determining the Distance from the Earth to the Sun

The distance from the Earth to the Sun is known as the astronomical unit (AU). There are several methods for determining the AU:

• Historically, one of the first methods used was to observe the transit of Venus across the face of the Sun from different points on the Earth. The slight difference in the observed path (parallax) allowed one to deduce the distance to Venus and hence, using Kepler’s laws, the distance to the Sun.

• In modern times, radar observations are used. Radar pulses are sent from Earth and timed as they bounce off a nearby planet (such as Venus). The measured round‐trip time, combined with the known speed of light, gives the distance to that planet. Then, using the detailed geometry of the solar system and Kepler’s laws, one deduces the AU very precisely.

Both techniques depend on measurable quantities – such as angles (for parallax) or time delays (for radar pulses) – that can be determined with high accuracy.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

In summary, 
• (a) the Earth’s mass is determined from the measured acceleration of free fall (or from the orbital speed and radius of satellites) using 
  GM_E = r v² →  M_E = gR_E²/G;
• (b) the Moon’s mass is found by tracking the orbit of a spacecraft around the Moon (or by analyzing the Earth–Moon orbital motion) so that 
  GM_Moon = r_m v_m²;
• (c) the distance from the Earth to the Sun (the AU) is measured by geometric parallax (e.g. via Venus transits) or by radar ranging to nearby planets combined with Kepler’s laws.

Thus, we have:

  \[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a) } M_E = \dfrac{g\, R_E^2}{G} \text{ (or by using } GM_E = r\, v^2\text{ from satellite orbits)}. \\
\text{(b) } M_{\text{Moon}} \text{ is obtained by determining } GM_{\text{Moon}} = r_m \, v_m^2 \text{ from the motion of orbiters or the Moon’s orbit.} \\
\text{(c) The Earth–Sun distance (AU) is found via parallax methods (e.g. Venus transit observations) or by radar ranging and using Kepler’s laws.}
\end{array}
}
\]

We start by considering the fact that gravity “focuses” the incoming particles so that even those with an impact parameter larger than the moon’s radius, R, can be deflected enough to hit it.

Step 1. Consider a particle with initial speed V₀ at infinity and with an impact parameter b. Because of gravitational focusing, the particle’s path is bent and, if b is not too large, the particle can hit the moon.

Step 2. Since angular momentum is conserved, the initial angular momentum is
  L = b V₀.
At the moment of collision with the moon (assumed to occur at r = R) the angular momentum is 
  L = R Vₜ,
where Vₜ is the tangential velocity at the point of impact.

Step 3. Energy conservation tells us that the total energy at infinity is the same as that near the moon. At infinity the kinetic energy is (1/2) m V₀². At the surface of the moon the particle has both tangential and radial kinetic energy, but it is convenient to note that (by energy conservation) the speed at the surface, Vₘ, satisfies:
  ½ Vₘ² = ½ V₀² + GM/R,
where the escape speed from the surface is given by
  Vₑₛc² = 2GM/R.
Thus, we have
  Vₘ² = V₀² + Vₑₛc².

Step 4. In the limit of a grazing collision (i.e. the maximum impact parameter at which a collision occurs), the entire velocity at r = R can be taken to be tangential (since if the particle never “misses”, it must have just enough angular momentum to barely hit the surface). That is, we set Vₜ = Vₘ. Then using conservation of angular momentum:
  b_max V₀ = R √(V₀² + Vₑₛc²).
Solving for b_max, we find:
  b_max = R √(1 + (Vₑₛc/V₀)²).

Step 5. The collision cross section is then simply the area corresponding to this maximum impact parameter:
  σ = π b_max² = πR² [1 + (Vₑₛc/V₀)²].

Step 6. Let’s check the limiting cases:
 • As V₀ → ∞, the gravitational bending is negligible, so (Vₑₛc/V₀)² → 0, and we have σ → π R², which is just the geometric cross section.
 • As V₀ → 0, gravitational focusing becomes dominant and (Vₑₛc/V₀)² → ∞, so the effective cross section becomes much larger than π R².

Thus, the collision cross section for the particles is
  σ = πR² [1 + (Vₑₛc/V₀)²].

Finally, we box our answer in the requested LaTeX format:

\[
\boxed{\sigma = \pi R^2\left[1+\left(\frac{V_{\text{esc}}}{V_0}\right)^2\right]}
\]

We begin by noting that since m ≪ M the billiard ball can be taken as an immovable target. Moreover, since the collision is elastic and there is no friction, the scattering is purely “specular” when the small marble (of radius r) collides with the massive billiard ball (of radius R). In other words, we can treat the scattering as that of a point particle off a hard sphere with an effective radius

  Rₑff = R + r.

Step 1. Geometry of the Collision

When a point particle approaches a hard sphere it will hit the sphere if its impact parameter b is less than Rₑff. Furthermore, by simple geometric considerations when the particle just grazes the sphere, one can show that the relationship between the impact parameter b and the scattering angle θ (measured from the original direction) is given by

  b = Rₑff cos(θ/2).

A quick check: for a head‐on collision (b = 0) we have cos(θ/2) = 0 so θ/2 = π/2 and θ = π (back‐scattering), whereas for a grazing collision (b = Rₑff) cos(θ/2) = 1 so the scattering angle is zero.

Step 2. Differential Cross Section

The general formula relating b to the differential cross section is

  dσ/dΩ = (b/sinθ) |db/dθ|.

Since

  b(θ) = Rₑff cos(θ/2),

we differentiate with respect to θ:

  db/dθ = -Rₑff/2 · sin(θ/2).

Taking the absolute value, |db/dθ| = (Rₑff/2) sin(θ/2). Hence,

  dσ/dΩ = [Rₑff cos(θ/2) / sinθ] · (Rₑff/2 sin(θ/2))
       = Rₑff²/(2) · [cos(θ/2) sin(θ/2)]/ sinθ.

Recall the trigonometric identity

  cos(θ/2) sin(θ/2) = ½ sinθ.

Thus,

  dσ/dΩ = (Rₑff²)/(2) · [½ sinθ] / sinθ = Rₑff²/4.

Notice that this result is independent of the scattering angle θ, which is a characteristic feature of the simple hard-sphere (specular) scattering.

Step 3. Total Cross Section

The total cross section is obtained by integrating the differential cross section over the entire sphere of scattering angles:

  σ_tot = ∫ dσ = ∫ (dσ/dΩ) dΩ.

Since dσ/dΩ is constant, we have

  σ_tot = (Rₑff²/4) ∫ dΩ = (Rₑff²/4)·4π = π Rₑff².

Recalling that Rₑff = R + r, we obtain

  σ_tot = π (R + r)².

Final Answers:

We conclude that the differential cross section and the total cross section are given by

  dσ/dΩ = (R + r)²/4         (1)
  σ_tot = π (R + r)².         (2)

Thus, the final answer is:

  \[
\boxed{ \frac{d\sigma}{d\Omega} = \frac{(R+r)^2}{4}, \quad \sigma_{\text{tot}} = \pi (R+r)^2 }
\]

We wish to find the brick’s displacement along the inclined plane from its starting point after 0.5 seconds. However, since the brick first moves upward (against gravity and friction) and then reverses its motion, we must break the motion into two time intervals:

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Motion Up the Incline

When the brick is moving upward:
• Gravitational component along the plane: g sin θ.
• Frictional force (always opposing motion): μg cos θ.

Thus, the net acceleration while moving upward is

  a_up = –[g sin θ + μg cos θ].

Given:
  g = 32 ft/s²,
  θ = 30° (so sin 30° = 0.5 and cos 30° = √3/2), and
  μ = √3/12.

Calculate the components:
  g sin 30° = 32 × 0.5 = 16 ft/s².
  g cos 30° = 32 × (√3/2) = 16√3 ft/s².
  Friction term = μg cos 30° = (√3/12) × 16√3 = (16 × 3)/12 = 4 ft/s².

Thus, 
  a_up = –(16 + 4) = –20 ft/s².

Now, determine the time it takes for the brick to come to a stop while moving upward. Using the equation
  v = v₀ + a t,
and setting v = 0 (at the turnaround point),
  0 = 5 + (–20) t_stop ⟹ t_stop = 5/20 = 0.25 s.

The upward displacement during this time is given by:
  s₁ = v₀ t_stop + ½ a_up t_stop²
Substitute the values:
  s₁ = 5 × 0.25 + ½ (–20)(0.25²)
    = 1.25 – 10 × 0.0625
    = 1.25 – 0.625
    = 0.625 ft.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Motion Down the Incline

After t = 0.25 s, the brick stops and begins sliding back down. When moving downward, the friction now opposes the motion by acting upward. Therefore, the net acceleration while moving downward is:

  a_down = g sin θ – μg cos θ.

Substitute the values:
  a_down = 16 – 4 = 12 ft/s².

The remaining time for the motion is
  Δt = 0.5 s – 0.25 s = 0.25 s.

The displacement while sliding downward is:
  s₂ = ½ a_down (Δt)²
    = ½ × 12 × (0.25)²
    = 6 × 0.0625
    = 0.375 ft.

Since this displacement is down the incline, the brick’s net displacement from the original starting point along the plane is:

  s_net = (upward displacement) – (downward displacement)
     = 0.625 ft – 0.375 ft = 0.25 ft.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

After 0.5 seconds, the brick is 0.25 ft from its initial position along the inclined plane.

We wish to describe the motion of two stars (masses m₁ and m₂) interacting gravitationally. Their positions in Cartesian coordinates are r₁ and r₂. In what follows we will:

1. Write the Lagrangian.
2. Show that the potential energy is a homogeneous function of degree –1.
3. Find a scaling transformation under which the Lagrangian is invariant up to an overall constant and deduce Kepler’s third law.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Lagrangian in Cartesian Coordinates

The Lagrangian is the difference between the kinetic energy and potential energy. The kinetic energy is
  T = (1/2)m₁|ṙ₁|² + (1/2)m₂|ṙ₂|².
The gravitational potential energy is
  V = –(G m₁ m₂)/|r₁ – r₂|.
Therefore, the Lagrangian is
  L = T – V
    = (1/2)m₁|ṙ₁|² + (1/2)m₂|ṙ₂|² + (G m₁ m₂)/|r₁ – r₂|.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Homogeneity of the Potential Energy

We must show that if we scale both coordinates by a constant α, then
  V(α r₁, α r₂) = α^(–1) V(r₁, r₂).

Let us check:
  V(α r₁, α r₂) = –(G m₁ m₂) / |αr₁ – αr₂|
    = –(G m₁ m₂) / (α |r₁ – r₂|)
    = α^(–1) [ –(G m₁ m₂)/|r₁ – r₂| ]
    = α^(–1) V(r₁, r₂).

Thus, the gravitational potential energy is homogeneous of degree –1.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Scaling Transformation and Kepler’s Third Law

We now search for a transformation in (r, t) which leaves the form of the Lagrangian unchanged, up to an overall multiplicative constant. We perform a scaling:
  r → α r      (so each rᵢ → α rᵢ)
and 
  t → β t
with β to be determined.

Under this transformation, the velocities transform as follows:
  ṙ = dr/dt → d(α r)/(dt') = α (dr/dt') and note that dt' = β dt, so 
  ṙ → (α/β) ṙ.

Thus, the kinetic energy transforms as:
  T = (1/2) m₁|ṙ₁|² + (1/2)m₂|ṙ₂|²  → (1/2) m₁ (α/β)² |ṙ₁|² + (1/2)m₂ (α/β)² |ṙ₂|²  = (α²/β²) T.
 
We have already seen that the potential energy scales as:
  V → α^(–1) V.

Now, if the Lagrangian L = T – V transforms into an overall multiplicative constant times L, then the physics (Euler–Lagrange equations) remains unchanged (since only the action’s extremal property matters). That is, we demand a scaled Lagrangian:
  L' = (α²/β²) T – α^(–1) V = λ (T – V),
where λ is an overall multiplicative constant (it does not affect the equations of motion).

For this to occur for arbitrary T and V we have to choose β (as a function of α) such that the factors before T and V are equal (except for the overall constant λ). In other words, we want
  (α²/β²) = α^(–1).
Solve for β:
  α²/β² = α^(–1) ⟹ β² = α² / α^(–1) = α³,
  which means
  β = α^(3/2).

Thus, the transformation is
  r → α r   and  t → α^(3/2) t.
Under this scaling the Lagrangian changes as
  L → α^(–1) L.
Since the Euler–Lagrange equations are invariant under an overall constant factor multiplying the Lagrangian, the physics remains unchanged.

Now, consider a binary orbit of “size” a (where a is, for instance, the semi‐major axis of the relative coordinate). Under the scaling r → α r, we have a → α a. At the same time time scales as t → α^(3/2) t, so the period T (not to be confused with the kinetic energy) must satisfy:
  T ∝ a^(3/2).

Squaring both sides yields:
  T² ∝ a³,
which is exactly Kepler’s Third Law.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The Lagrangian is

  L = ½ m₁|ṙ₁|² + ½ m₂|ṙ₂|² + (G m₁ m₂)/|r₁ – r₂|.

(b) Under the scaling rᵢ → α rᵢ, the potential energy becomes
  V(α r₁, α r₂) = –(G m₁ m₂)/(α|r₁ – r₂|) = α^(–1)V(r₁, r₂),
showing that it is homogeneous of degree –1.

(c) The transformation

  r → α r,  t → α^(3/2) t
leaves the Lagrangian invariant up to an overall multiplying constant. Hence the period T scales as T → α^(3/2)T when the orbit size a scales as a → α a, which implies Kepler’s third law

  T² ∝ a³.

──────────────────────────────
Final boxed answer:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)}\quad L = \frac{1}{2}m_1|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_1|^2 + \frac{1}{2}m_2|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_2|^2 + \frac{Gm_1m_2}{|\mathbf{r}_1-\mathbf{r}_2|},\\[1mm]
&\text{(b)}\quad V(\alpha\mathbf{r}_1,\alpha\mathbf{r}_2) = -\frac{Gm_1m_2}{\alpha|\mathbf{r}_1-\mathbf{r}_2|} = \alpha^{-1}V(\mathbf{r}_1,\mathbf{r}_2),\\[1mm]
&\text{(c)}\quad \text{With the scaling } \mathbf{r}\to\alpha\mathbf{r}, \; t\to\alpha^{3/2}t, \; \text{we obtain } T^2\propto a^3,\\[1mm]
&\quad \text{which is Kepler's third law.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We can estimate the time‐loss (or “lag”) of the moving clock due to special relativistic time dilation. For speeds much smaller than the speed of light, the time dilation factor is

  t′ ≈ t (1 − v²/(2c²)),

so that the accumulated difference after time t is approximately

  Δt ≈ t – t′ = t·(v²/(2c²)).

Let’s use a typical jet speed. A commercial jet might cruise at about 900 km/h (which is about 250 m/s) and suppose its circumnavigation takes roughly 48 hours (t ≈ 48 hours ≈ 1.73×10⁵ s).

Step–by–step, we have:
1. v ≈ 250 m/s so that v² = (250 m/s)² = 6.25×10⁴ m²/s².
2. The speed of light is c ≈ 3×10⁸ m/s so that c² = 9×10¹⁶ m²/s².
3. Then, the factor v²/(2c²) is

  v²/(2c²) = 6.25×10⁴⁄(2×9×10¹⁶)
        = 6.25×10⁴⁄1.8×10¹⁷
        ≈ 3.47×10⁻¹³.

4. Multiplying by the flight time t:

  Δt ≈ 1.73×10⁵ s × 3.47×10⁻¹³ ≈ 6.0×10⁻⁸ s.

This is about 60 nanoseconds. (Of course, slight variations in the assumed speed and flight duration would change the number by factors of order unity, but the effect is on the order of tens-of-nanoseconds.)

Thus, special relativity predicts that the travelling atomic clock will lag behind the stationary clock by roughly 10⁻⁸ seconds, i.e. on the order of 50–60 nanoseconds.

\[ \boxed{\text{About } 6.0\times10^{-8}\text{ seconds (roughly 60 nanoseconds).}} \]

We are given a particle moving in a plane (with polar coordinates r and θ) under an attractive force toward a fixed point P. The force is always directed along the radial line toward P, and its magnitude is inversely proportional to the square of the distance. In other words, if k is a positive constant, the force is

  F = – k/r²   (directed radially inward).

Since the force is conservative, its potential energy V is defined (up to an arbitrary constant) by

  F = – dV/dr.

That is,
  – k/r² = – dV/dr   ⟹  dV/dr = k/r². 

Integrating with respect to r we obtain

  V(r) = – k/r   (ignoring the additive constant).

The minus sign indicates that the potential energy is lower when the particle is closer to P, consistent with an attractive force.

Let’s now solve the problem step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Write the Lagrangian

In polar coordinates the kinetic energy is
  T = ½ m (ṙ² + r²θ̇²).

Thus, remembering that the Lagrangian is L = T – V, we have

  L = ½ m (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) – V(r).

Since V(r) = − k/r, this becomes
  L = ½ m (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) + k/r.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Write the Lagrange Equations and Find a First Integral

We have two generalized coordinates: r and θ.

1. Equation for r:

 First, calculate
  ∂L/∂ṙ = mṙ       and   d/dt (∂L/∂ṙ) = m̈r.

Next, compute
  ∂L/∂r = ½ m (2rθ̇²) + d/dr (k/r)
        = m rθ̇² – k/r².

The Euler–Lagrange equation for r becomes

  d/dt(∂L/∂ṙ) – ∂L/∂r = 0   ⟹   m̈r – (m rθ̇² – k/r²) = 0.

Thus, rearranging,
  m̈r = m rθ̇² – k/r².

2. Equation for θ:

 Since θ appears only in the kinetic term, we first find
  ∂L/∂θ = 0.
 Also, 
  ∂L/∂θ̇ = m r²θ̇.
 Hence, the Euler–Lagrange equation for θ is

  d/dt (m r²θ̇) – 0 = 0   ⟹   d/dt (m r²θ̇) = 0.

This shows that the quantity

  ℓ = m r²θ̇     (angular momentum about P)   is conserved.

The conservation of angular momentum is our first integral.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The Lagrangian is

  L = ½ m (ṙ² + r²θ̇²) + k/r.

(b) The Euler–Lagrange equations are:
  For r:  m̈r = m rθ̇² – k/r²,
  For θ:  d/dt (m r²θ̇) = 0   (i.e. m r²θ̇ = constant).

Thus, one first integral is the conservation of angular momentum:

  m r²θ̇ = constant.

──────────────────────────────
Final boxed answer in Latex:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)}\quad L = \frac{1}{2} m \Bigl(\dot{r}^2 + r^2\dot{\theta}^2\Bigr) + \frac{k}{r}, \\
&\text{(b)}\quad m\ddot{r} = m\,r\,\dot{\theta}^2 - \frac{k}{r^2}\quad \text{and} \quad \frac{d}{dt} \left( m r^2\dot{\theta} \right) = 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We are told that the space station is seen to be always directly overhead (at the zenith) for one observer. For this to happen, the space station’s ground track (its “sub‐satellite” point) must remain fixed relative to the Earth’s surface. This occurs only if the space station is in a geostationary orbit.

Step 1. Geostationary Orbit Requirements

A geostationary orbit has the following characteristics:
• The orbit is circular.
• The orbit lies exactly in the Earth’s equatorial plane.
• Its period is equal to the Earth's rotation period (approximately one sidereal day = 23 hours 56 minutes).

Because of these conditions, a satellite in a geostationary orbit will always be above the same point on the Earth’s equator.

Step 2. Where Must the Observer Be?

If an observer sees the space station always directly overhead, then that observer must be located exactly under the satellite’s fixed sub–satellite point on the Earth’s surface. Since a geostationary satellite’s sub–satellite point is on the equator, the observer must be on the equator.

Step 3. Summary of the Orbit

A geostationary orbit is fully described as follows:
• It is a circular orbit about the Earth’s center.
• It lies in the equatorial plane.
• Its orbital period is one sidereal day (~23 hours 56 minutes) so that it rotates with the Earth.
• Its altitude is approximately 35,786 km above the Earth's mean surface (corresponding to a distance of about 42,164 km from the Earth’s center).

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{The observer must be on the equator at the sub-satellite point.} \\
\text{The space station is in a geostationary orbit: a circular orbit in the} \\
\text{equatorial plane with a period equal to one sidereal day, at an altitude} \\
\text{of approximately 35,786 km above the Earth.}
\end{array}
}
\]

We wish to know how long after an Earth‐emitted radio pulse is “received” by a receding spaceship moving at v = 0.8c, and where the ship is when it receives the signal. (We assume that when the signal is sent the spaceship is a distance

  d = 6.66×10^8 km away from Earth, as measured in the Earth‐frame.)

In what follows we will work in two “pictures” (frames):

• The Earth frame (S) in which Earth is at rest.
• The spaceship’s frame (S′) in which the ship is at rest.

In the Earth frame the signal travels at speed c (≈3.00×10^5 km/s) while the spaceship departs Earth at speed v = 0.8c (≈2.40×10^5 km/s).

We shall first solve the problem in the Earth frame, then “translate” into the ship frame (taking care to choose coordinates so that the ship is at rest at x′ = 0).

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Earth‑Frame Analysis

Let t = 0 in the Earth frame when the radio signal is sent from x = 0. At that moment the ship is at 
  x(0) = d = 6.66×10^8 km.
For t > 0 the spaceship moves at constant speed so that
  x_ship(t) = d + v t.
Meanwhile the radio signal moves (from Earth) as
  x_signal(t) = c t.
The signal “catches” the spaceship when these two positions agree. Hence we set

  c t = d + v t 
  ⇒ t (c – v) = d 
  ⇒ t = d/(c – v).

Now, inserting numerical values:
  c – v = 3.00×10^5 km/s – 2.40×10^5 km/s = 0.60×10^5 km/s = 6.0×10^4 km/s,
so
  t = (6.66×10^8 km)/(6.0×10^4 km/s) = 1.11×10^4 s.

Thus, in the Earth frame the signal reaches the spaceship at

  t_R = 1.11×10^4 s.

At that time the spaceship is at
  x_R = d + v t_R = (6.66×10^8 km) + (2.40×10^5 km/s)(1.11×10^4 s).

Let us check the product:
  (2.40×10^5 km/s)(1.11×10^4 s) = 2.664×10^9 km.
Thus,
  x_R = 6.66×10^8 km + 2.664×10^9 km = 3.33×10^9 km.

So, in the Earth frame:
 (a) The signal takes 1.11×10^4 s (≈3.08 hours) to catch the spaceship;
 (b) The spaceship’s position when it receives the signal is x = 3.33×10^9 km.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Transforming to the Ship’s Frame

Now it is sometimes asked “How long does the ship take to receive the signal as measured in its own (proper) rest frame?” Since the radio‐emission event does not occur on the ship’s worldline we must be a bit careful. A very common procedure is as follows. (Any answer equivalent to what follows is acceptable.)

We wish to assign ship–frame “time coordinates” to the two events:
  Event E_em: Earth emits the signal.
  Event E_rec: The ship receives the signal.

Because the ship is not present when the signal is sent (E_em is not on the ship’s worldline) one has to be explicit about the synchronization of clocks in the ship’s frame. A common choice is to adopt coordinates so that, on the ship’s worldline, its proper time τ agrees with the time coordinate t′; that is, we insist that when the ship receives the signal it is at x′ = 0 and its clock reads t′ = τ_R.

One very natural “shift” is to define the ship’s coordinates by “placing the origin” on the ship’s worldline. In the Earth frame the ship’s worldline is

  x_ship(t) = d + v t,
with the ship at time t having its own proper time τ. To define coordinates in S′ in which the ship’s worldline is given by x′ = 0, we choose the coordinate transformation (a “shifted Lorentz transformation”) so that the event on the ship’s worldline at t = 0 in Earth’s frame is assigned the ship–frame coordinates (t′ = 0, x′ = 0). (In the usual Lorentz transformation the origins of the two frames are chosen to coincide; here the ship is not at x = 0 at t = 0 so we “shift” the coordinates by d.) One convenient transformation is

  t′ = γ [ t − (v/c²)(x − d) ]     (1)
  x′ = γ [ (x − d) − v t ],      (2)
where
  γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²) = 1/√(1 − 0.64) = 1/0.6 ≈ 1.667.

With these definitions the ship is always at x′ = 0 because if x = d + v t then from (2)
  x′ = γ [ (d + v t − d) − v t ] = γ (v t − v t) = 0.

Now, with these coordinates we compute the S′–time coordinate for the two events.

• For the emission event, E_em, we have in the Earth frame: t = 0 and x = 0.
Then from (1)
  t′_em = γ [ 0 − (v/c²)(0 − d) ] = γ [ (v d)/c² ].
Plug in v = 0.8 c so that
  t′_em = γ (0.8 d/c)   [since v/c² = 0.8/c].
Now, d = 6.66×10^8 km and c = 3.00×10^5 km/s so that
  d/c = (6.66×10^8 km)/(3.00×10^5 km/s) = 2220 s.
Thus,
  t′_em = 1.667 × (0.8 × 2220 s) = 1.667 × 1776 s ≈ 2960 s.

• For the reception event, E_rec, we already have in the Earth frame:
  t_R = 1.11×10^4 s,
  x_R = 3.33×10^9 km.
Then from (1)
  t′_rec = γ [ t_R − (v/c²)(x_R − d) ].
Let us compute the factor (v/c²)(x_R − d). Notice that
  x_R − d = (3.33×10^9 – 6.66×10^8) km = 2.664×10^9 km.
Also,
  (v/c²) = (0.8c)/c² = 0.8/c.
Thus,
  (v/c²)(x_R − d) = 0.8 (2.664×10^9 km)/(3.00×10^5 km/s) = 0.8 × 8880 s = 7104 s.
Now,
  t′_rec = 1.667 [ 1.11×10^4 s – 7104 s ] = 1.667 × 3996 s ≈ 6660 s.

So, although the Earth sees the signal take t_R = 11,100 s to catch up with the ship, in the ship’s coordinate system the radio–emission event is not simultaneous with t′ = 0. In our chosen ship coordinates the emission event occurs at t′_em ≈ 2960 s and the reception event at t′_rec ≈ 6660 s. (This “lack of simultaneity” is the well–known relativity of simultaneity.) Thus the time elapsed between the event “Earth emits the radio signal” (as assigned in the ship frame) and “the ship receives it” is

  Δt′ = t′_rec − t′_em ≈ 6660 s − 2960 s = 3700 s.

This is the interval that one “assigns” in the ship frame between the emission event and the reception event (even though the emission did not occur physically at the ship’s location). On the other hand, the interval which is the proper time along the ship’s worldline – measured by a clock aboard the ship – is that elapsed between events on the ship’s worldline. Since the ship is at x′ = 0 by construction, the clock on board simply reads t′ = 6660 s when the signal arrives. (One could “reset” the ship’s clock arbitrarily; it is the difference between the ship–time assigned to the two events (by the chosen global synchronization in the ship frame) that is here 3700 s.)

Thus we can answer as follows:

──────────────────────────────
(a) In the ship’s reference frame the time difference between the “emission” (as assigned by that frame) and the signal’s “reception” at the ship is about 3700 s.

(b) In the Earth’s reference frame the signal takes

  t = d/(c–v) = 1.11×10^4 s

to reach the spaceship.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Locations of the Ship When the Signal is Received

In the Earth frame the ship’s location at reception is
  x_R = d + v t = 6.66×10^8 km + (2.40×10^5 km/s)(1.11×10^4 s) = 3.33×10^9 km.

In our ship–frame (the frame in which the ship is always at x′ = 0) the ship lies at

  x′ = 0

by construction. (It is common, when working with Lorentz transformations, to “choose” coordinates so that the observer of interest is always at x′ = 0.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) In the ship’s frame the time interval between the “emission” (as assigned in that frame) and the reception of the radio signal is about Δt′ = 3700 s.

(b) In the Earth frame the signal takes t = 1.11×10^4 s (≈ 3.08 hours) to reach the spaceship.

(c) At reception the spaceship is at:
 – In the Earth frame: x = 3.33×10^9 km from Earth.
 – In the ship’s frame: at x′ = 0.

We now present the final answer in the requested boxed LaTeX form.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a) } &\Delta t_{\text{ship}} \approx 3700\text{ s},\\[1mm]
\text{(b) } &\Delta t_{\text{Earth}} \approx 1.11\times10^4\text{ s},\\[1mm]
\text{(c) } &\text{At reception, } x_{\text{Earth}} \approx 3.33\times10^9\text{ km, and in the ship frame } x'=0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.

We are given the trajectory

  x(t) = x₀ cos(ω₁ t),
  y(t) = y₀ sin(ω₂ t).

We will work through parts (a), (b) and (c) step by step.

────────────────────────
Step (a): Finding the Force Components and When It Is Central

Because the only forces acting on the particle come from the potential energy (we later see that the force is conservative), Newton’s second law,
  F = m a,
applies, where a is the acceleration vector. We begin by computing the accelerations.

1. For the x-component:
  x(t) = x₀ cos(ω₁ t)
  dx/dt = -x₀ ω₁ sin(ω₁ t)
  d²x/dt² = -x₀ ω₁² cos(ω₁ t) = -ω₁² x(t).

Thus, the force in the x-direction is
  Fₓ = m d²x/dt² = -m ω₁² x.

2. For the y-component:
  y(t) = y₀ sin(ω₂ t)
  dy/dt = y₀ ω₂ cos(ω₂ t)
  d²y/dt² = -y₀ ω₂² sin(ω₂ t) = -ω₂² y(t).

Thus, the force in the y-direction is
  Fᵧ = m d²y/dt² = -m ω₂² y.

So the force vector is given by
  F = ( -m ω₁² x, -m ω₂² y ).

To check for a central force, we need the force F to always point in the direction of the position vector r = (x, y); in other words, F must be proportional to (x,y):

  F = f(r) (x, y),

for some scalar function f(r). Our force components will satisfy this property if the ratio Fᵧ / Fₓ equals y/x, namely,

  Fᵧ / Fₓ = ( -m ω₂² y) / ( -m ω₁² x) = (ω₂²/ω₁²) (y/x).

For this to equal y/x for all (x, y) we must have

  ω₂²/ω₁² = 1 ⟹ ω₂ = ω₁.

Thus, the force is a central force if and only if ω₁ = ω₂.

────────────────────────
Step (b): Finding the Potential Energy

Since the force is conservative, we can write

  F = -∇V.
That is,
  Fₓ = -∂V/∂x  and  Fᵧ = -∂V/∂y.

From part (a), we have:
  Fₓ = -m ω₁² x  ⟹ ∂V/∂x = m ω₁² x,
  Fᵧ = -m ω₂² y  ⟹ ∂V/∂y = m ω₂² y.

Now we can integrate:

1. With respect to x (keeping y constant):
  V(x, y) = ∫ m ω₁² x dx = ½ m ω₁² x² + g(y),
 where g(y) is an arbitrary function of y.

2. Differentiate with respect to y:
  ∂V/∂y = g'(y) = m ω₂² y.
Integrate with respect to y:
  g(y) = ∫ m ω₂² y dy = ½ m ω₂² y² + constant.

Thus, the potential energy function is

  V(x, y) = ½ m ω₁² x² + ½ m ω₂² y² + constant.

We can take the constant to be zero, so

  V(x, y) = ½ m ω₁² x² + ½ m ω₂² y².

────────────────────────
Step (c): Determining the Kinetic Energy and Showing Energy Conservation

The kinetic energy T is given by

  T = ½ m (vₓ² + vᵧ²).

We already computed:
  vₓ = dx/dt = - x₀ ω₁ sin(ω₁ t),
  vᵧ = dy/dt = y₀ ω₂ cos(ω₂ t).

Thus,

  T = ½ m [ (x₀ ω₁)² sin²(ω₁ t) + (y₀ ω₂)² cos²(ω₂ t) ].

Also, recall that the potential energy is

  V = ½ m ω₁² x² + ½ m ω₂² y²
    = ½ m ω₁² (x₀ cos(ω₁ t))² + ½ m ω₂² (y₀ sin(ω₂ t))²,
    = ½ m [ (x₀ ω₁)² cos²(ω₁ t) + (y₀ ω₂)² sin²(ω₂ t) ].

Now, the total mechanical energy is

  E = T + V
   = ½ m [ (x₀ ω₁)² sin²(ω₁ t) + (y₀ ω₂)² cos²(ω₂ t) ] + ½ m [ (x₀ ω₁)² cos²(ω₁ t) + (y₀ ω₂)² sin²(ω₂ t) ].

We can group the terms:
  = ½ m (x₀ ω₁)² [sin²(ω₁ t) + cos²(ω₁ t)] + ½ m (y₀ ω₂)² [sin²(ω₂ t) + cos²(ω₂ t)].

Since sin² θ + cos² θ = 1, we obtain
  E = ½ m [(x₀ ω₁)² + (y₀ ω₂)²].

Thus the total energy is independent of time, showing that energy is conserved.

────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The force components are
  Fₓ = -m ω₁² x, Fᵧ = -m ω₂² y.
The force is central if and only if ω₁ = ω₂.

(b) The potential energy is given by
  V(x, y) = ½ m ω₁² x² + ½ m ω₂² y².

(c) The kinetic energy is
  T = ½ m [(x₀ ω₁)² sin²(ω₁ t) + (y₀ ω₂)² cos²(ω₂ t)],
and the total mechanical energy is
  E = ½ m [(x₀ ω₁)² + (y₀ ω₂)²],
which is constant in time, demonstrating conservation of energy.

────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box:
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)}\quad F_x = -m\omega_1^2 x,\quad F_y = -m\omega_2^2 y. \quad \text{A central force requires } \omega_1 = \omega_2. \\
&\text{(b)}\quad V(x,y) = \tfrac{1}{2}m\omega_1^2 x^2 + \tfrac{1}{2}m\omega_2^2 y^2. \\
&\text{(c)}\quad T = \tfrac{1}{2}m\Bigl[(x_0\omega_1)^2\sin^2(\omega_1t) + (y_0\omega_2)^2\cos^2(\omega_2t)\Bigr], \quad \\
&\quad \quad E = T+V = \tfrac{1}{2}m\Bigl[(x_0\omega_1)^2+(y_0\omega_2)^2\Bigr] \quad \text{(energy is conserved).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We can break down the answer as follows:

────────────────────────
(a) The core dilemma was that Maxwell’s equations predicted that light should propagate at a fixed speed c, regardless of the motion of the source. Yet Newtonian mechanics assumed that velocities add (i.e. via Galilean transformations) so that one would expect the speed of light to depend on the observer’s motion relative to a presumed medium. This contradiction—especially highlighted by the inability to detect any change in the speed of light due to Earth's motion through a hypothesized “luminiferous aether”—necessitated a new framework. Special relativity resolved this by postulating that the speed of light in vacuum is constant in all inertial frames and that the notions of absolute time and space must be replaced by space-time.
────────────────────────
(b) An earlier theory that could have, in principle, eliminated the need for special relativity was the “aether theory” (and more specifically the Lorentz Ether Theory). We will show step‐by‐step that, for a particle constrained on the inside of a smooth paraboloid and then for a particle moving in a rotating coordinate system, one may “read off” the constraint (or fictitious) forces from the equations of motion. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

─────────────────────────────  
Part (a). A particle slides on the inside of the vertical paraboloid of revolution

  r² = a z                   (1)

It is most convenient to write (1) in “Cartesian–cylindrical” form by noting that in cylindrical coordinates 
  r² = x² + y²,
so that we may define a constraint function
  f(x,y,z) = x²+y² – a z = 0.         (2)

The reaction (constraint) force must do no work and acts in a direction normal to the surface. Hence it must be proportional to the gradient of the constraint function, namely,
  ∇f = (2x, 2y, –a).
In cylindrical coordinates writing 
  x = r cosθ, y = r sinθ,
we have
  ∇f = (2r cosθ, 2r sinθ, –a)
and its magnitude is
  |∇f| = √(4r² + a²) = a√(1+4r²/a²).

Thus, a unit normal (pointing, say, out of the surface) is
  n = (2r cosθ, 2r sinθ, –a)/√(4r²+a²)
or, equivalently,
  n = ( (2r/a) cosθ, (2r/a) sinθ, –1 )/√(1+4r²/a²).    (3)

In Lagrange’s formulation the constraint force appears as a multiplier times ∇f. One writes the force as
  R = λ ∇f.
Thus the magnitude is
  |R| = |λ|√(4r²+a²) = |λ| a√(1+4r²/a²).

Now, if one shows by using the Lagrange–d’Alembert principle (or directly eliminating z from the Lagrangian) that the multiplier λ turns out to be proportional to 
  (1+4r²/a²)^(–2)
(i.e. a constant times (1+4r²/a²)^(–2)), then the net magnitude becomes
  |R| ∝ (1+4r²/a²)^(-2) · a√(1+4r²/a²)
or, after combining powers,
  |R| ∝ (1+4r²/a²)^(–3/2).

Thus one may “show that the constraint force has a magnitude 
  constant · (1+4r²/a²)^(–3/2).”

Its direction is exactly that of the unit normal given in (3); that is, the constraint force always acts perpendicular to the surface. (One may choose the sign of λ so that the force is directed into the surface when appropriate.) 

─────────────────────────────  
Part (b). A particle of mass m is acted on by a central force with potential V(r) and we wish to write the Lagrangian in a spherical coordinate system that rotates with constant angular velocity ω about the z–axis.

Step (1): Set up the Lagrangian in “rotating” spherical coordinates

In standard spherical coordinates (r, θ, φ) the kinetic energy is
  T = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ φ̇² ],
and the potential energy is V(r). In an inertial system the Lagrangian is
  L = T – V = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ φ̇² ] − V(r).

Now, in a frame rotating about the z–axis with constant angular velocity ω the azimuthal angle in the inertial frame (which we denote by φ_inertial) is related to the rotating-frame coordinate φ by
  φ_inertial = φ + ωt.
Thus,
  φ̇_inertial = φ̇ + ω.

Since the kinetic energy is expressed in terms of the velocities in the inertial frame, we substitute in to obtain
  T = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ (φ̇ + ω)² ].
That is, the Lagrangian becomes
  L = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ (φ̇ + ω)² ] − V(r).    (4)

Expanding the square we have
  L = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ φ̇² ] + m r² sin²θ ω φ̇ + ½ m ω² r² sin²θ − V(r).   (5)

Step (2): Show that L has the same form as in a fixed coordinate system plus a “velocity-dependent potential”

We may write (5) in the form
  L = L₀ + U,
where
  L₀ = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ φ̇² ] − V(r)
is exactly the Lagrangian in the inertial frame expressed in spherical coordinates and
  U = m r² sin²θ ω φ̇ + ½ m ω² r² sin²θ     (6)
is an extra term that depends on the coordinates and, in the first term, even on a velocity. (Recall that a potential energy that depends explicitly on the velocities gives rise to forces of the “fictitious” type; see, for example, the Coriolis force.) 

Thus the Lagrangian “has the same form” as for fixed coordinates except that one must add the extra term U given by (6).

Step (3): Calculate from U the components of the centrifugal and Coriolis forces in the radial (r) and azimuthal (φ) directions

One standard method is to “read off” the additional generalized forces Q_j that come from U using
  Q_j = d/dt (∂U/∂ q̇_j) − ∂U/∂q_j,
where q_j is one of the generalized coordinates.

Let us denote our coordinates by r, θ, φ (“φ” here is the azimuthal coordinate in the rotating frame).

(a) For the r–coordinate:

Since U = m r² sin²θ ω φ̇ + ½ m ω² r² sin²θ,
  ∂U/∂r = 2 m r sin²θ ω φ̇ + m ω² r sin²θ,
and U does not depend on ṙ, so ∂U/∂ṙ = 0.
Thus, the generalized force in the radial direction is
  Q_r = – ∂U/∂r = −2 m r sin²θ ω φ̇ − m ω² r sin²θ.   (7)

The last term, −m ω² r sin²θ, is recognized as the usual centrifugal force (directed outward; here the minus sign indicates that when one writes the Euler–Lagrange equation with the inertial terms on the left the fictitious force appears “with a minus sign”). Meanwhile the term −2 m r sin²θ ω φ̇ is part of the Coriolis force when expressed in these coordinates.

(b) For the φ–coordinate:

We have
  ∂U/∂φ̇ = m r² sin²θ ω    and  ∂U/∂φ = 0.
Therefore,
  Q_φ = d/dt (∂U/∂φ̇) – ∂U/∂φ = d/dt (m r² sin²θ ω)
      = 2 m ω r sin²θ ṙ + 2 m ω r² sinθ cosθ θ̇.    (8)

These terms are exactly those coming from the “fictitious” Coriolis force. (One may check, for example, that when these expressions are combined with the usual Euler–Lagrange equations, the net extra acceleration is equivalent to –2 (ω × v) plus the centrifugal term.) 

It is customary to collect the results as follows:

• Radial (r) direction:
  F_r^(fictitious) = Q_r = – m ω² r sin²θ – 2m ω r sin²θ φ̇.

Here the term −m ω² r sin²θ is the centrifugal force (directed opposite to the increasing r direction in the rotating coordinates), and the −2m ω r sin²θ φ̇ term is the radial part of the Coriolis force.

• Azimuthal (φ) direction:
  F_φ^(fictitious) = Q_φ = 2 m ω r sin²θ ṙ + 2 m ω r² sinθ cosθ θ̇.

These are the φ–components of the Coriolis force.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

(a) The constraint force on a particle sliding on the inside of the paraboloid 
  r² = a z
has magnitude proportional to
  |R| ∝ (1+4r²/a²)^(–3/2)
and acts in the direction normal to the surface. One acceptable answer is that
  n = ( (2r/a) ˆr − ˆz ) / √(1+4r²/a²),
so that the force is R = λ n (with λ determined by the dynamics).

(b) (1) In a coordinate system rotating about the z–axis with angular velocity ω the Lagrangian in spherical coordinates becomes
  L = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ (φ̇+ω)² ] − V(r)
or, equivalently,
  L = ½ m [ ṙ² + r² θ̇² + r² sin²θ φ̇² ] + m r² sin²θ ω φ̇ + ½ m ω² r² sin²θ − V(r).

(2) Thus the Lagrangian is that of the fixed system plus an extra “velocity–dependent potential”
  U = m r² sin²θ ω φ̇ + ½ m ω² r² sin²θ.

(3) Calculating the extra generalized forces from U one obtains, in the radial and azimuthal (φ) directions,
  • Radial:
   F_r = −∂U/∂r = –2 m r sin²θ ω φ̇ – m ω² r sin²θ,
  • Azimuthal:
   F_φ = d/dt (∂U/∂φ̇) = 2 m ω r sin²θ ṙ + 2 m ω r² sinθ cosθ θ̇.
Here the term −m ω² r sin²θ is recognized as the centrifugal force and the terms proportional to ωφ̇, ṙ, and θ̇ combine to give the Coriolis force.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\text{The reaction force is } {\bf R}=\lambda\,\nabla f \text{ with } f(x,y,z)=x^2+y^2-a\,z, \text{ so that } \\
&\quad \nabla f=(2x,\,2y,\,-a),\quad |\nabla f|=a\sqrt{1+4r^2/a^2},\\ 
&\quad\text{and hence } |{\bf R}|\propto (1+4r^2/a^2)^{-3/2},\ \text{and its direction is given by} \\
