solution:
We wish to study the motion of a particle (of mass m) which is attracted to a fixed centre by a force that varies inversely as the cube of its distance from that centre. (Thus, if r is the distance, the force is proportional to 1/r³.) For a central force problem the angular momentum is conserved and the motion takes place in a plane; we shall use polar coordinates (r, θ).

Below we describe step‐by‐step how one may derive the equation of the orbit and then “solve” it, and we then discuss how the nature of the orbits depends on the parameters in the system.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Writing the Force and the Potential

Assume that the force is given by

  F(r)= –k/r³          (1)

with k a positive constant (so that the force is attractive). Because the force is conservative we can write

  U(r)= –∫F(r)dr.

Thus,
  U(r)= –∫(–k/r³)dr = k∫r^(–3)dr = –k/(2r²) + constant.
We may choose the constant to be zero so that
  U(r)= –k/(2r²).       (2)

Notice that the effective potential which governs the radial motion also includes the “centrifugal term”. Since the angular momentum L is conserved, one has

  U_eff(r)= L²/(2mr²)+ U(r)= [L²/(2m) – k/2]1/r².    (3)

Thus, one sees immediately that the sign of (L²/(2m) – k/2), or equivalently whether L² is larger or smaller than mk, will be important in what follows.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Obtaining the Equation for the Orbit

In many central–force problems it is convenient to introduce the variable
  u = 1/r.
A standard calculation (see e.g. Goldstein’s Classical Mechanics) shows that the orbit satisfies

  d²u/dθ² + u = –[m/(L² u²)] F(1/u).    (4)

Since the force is given by F(r)= –k/r³, when written as a function of u (with r = 1/u) one has
  F(1/u) = –k u³.
Thus, the right–hand side becomes

  –[m/(L² u²)] (–k u³)= (mk/L²) u.
Therefore, equation (4) becomes

  d²u/dθ² + u = (mk/L²) u   →  d²u/dθ² + [1 – mk/L²] u = 0.  (5)

This is a linear second–order differential equation with constant coefficients.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Solving the Orbit Equation

Define the parameter
  β² = 1 – (mk/L²).       (6)

Then equation (5) is written as

  d²u/dθ² + β² u = 0.   (7)

There are three cases to consider:

1. β² > 0 (i.e. L² > mk)

In this case the solutions are oscillatory. The general solution is

  u(θ)= A cos(βθ) + B sin(βθ),  (8)

or equivalently (by an appropriate shift of the angular coordinate) one may write

  u(θ)= C cos(βθ – δ).      (9)

Recalling that u = 1/r, we thus have

  r(θ)= 1/[C cos(βθ – δ)].   (10)

2. β² < 0 (i.e. L² < mk)

Here it is convenient to write

  γ² = mk/L² – 1       (11)

so that equation (5) becomes

  d²u/dθ² – γ² u = 0.
Its general solution is

  u(θ)= A cosh(γθ) + B sinh(γθ).  (12)

Thus

  r(θ)= 1/[A cosh(γθ) + B sinh(γθ)].  (13)

3. β² = 0 (i.e. the borderline case L² = mk)

In this degenerate case the differential equation (5) becomes

  d²u/dθ² = 0,
with general solution

  u(θ)= Aθ + B.    (14)

Hence

  r(θ)= 1/(Aθ+B).     (15)

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Discussion of the Nature of the Orbits

The three cases above have rather different behaviors:

• When L² > mk the parameter β is real (0 < β ≤ 1). The solution (10) is oscillatory in θ. In this case the effective potential

  U_eff = [L²/(2m) – k/2]1/r²
is repulsive (for sufficiently large r) so that the particle does not “fall into the centre.” The angular “frequency” in the orbit (β) is different from unity; thus the angular period of oscillation in u (or equivalently r) is 2π/β. In general the orbits are not closed: they will be closed only if β is a rational number. (When β = 1 the orbit is exactly as for the inverse–square law; note that β = 1 occurs when k = 0, which is trivial, so in the inverse–cube case one generically does not expect conic sections.)

• When L² < mk the parameter β is imaginary (that is, γ defined in (11) is real). In that case the solution (13) involves hyperbolic functions so that u (and hence r) changes monotonically with θ in one direction and the motion is not oscillatory. (Moreover note that the effective potential in (3) is then negative and unbounded below as r → 0, so the particle may spiral into the centre.)

• The borderline case L² = mk is “degenerate” and the solution becomes linear in θ, see (15).

Thus, the nature of the orbit depends critically on the ratio mk/L². When the angular momentum is large (L² > mk) the “centrifugal barrier” dominates over the attractive inverse–cube force so that the particle is repelled from the centre and its r(θ) oscillates. When the angular momentum is too small (L² < mk) the attractive force wins and the particle can spiral all the way to r = 0.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

An acceptable answer is as follows:

Starting from the force
  F(r)= –k/r³,
one finds that, with u = 1/r, the orbit obeys
  d²u/dθ² + [1 – (mk/L²)] u = 0.
Thus, writing
  β² = 1 – (mk/L²),
the general solution is:

 • For L² > mk (β real):
  u(θ)= A cos(βθ) + B sin(βθ)  or  r(θ)= 1/(A cos(βθ) + B sin(βθ)).

 • For L² < mk (β imaginary, with γ² = mk/L² – 1):
  u(θ)= A cosh(γθ) + B sinh(γθ)  or  r(θ)= 1/(A cosh(γθ) + B sinh(γθ)).

 • For L² = mk:
  u(θ)= Aθ+B  or  r(θ)= 1/(Aθ+B).

The orbits are oscillatory (and may be closed if β is a rational number) when L² > mk, while for L² < mk the motion is monotonic and the particle may fall to r = 0. The borderline case L² = mk gives a solution linear in the angle.

We wish to study the reaction

  γ + p → p + ψ′

where the ψ′ particle is taken to have a mass of 4Mₚ (with Mₚ being the proton mass). The initial proton is at rest in the laboratory (lab) frame and the incoming photon has energy E. We will determine:

  (a) The minimum photon energy E₀ (in units of Mₚc²) needed so that the reaction can take place.

  (b) The velocity (v/c) of the ψ′ particle when the photon energy is just above threshold (i.e. E = E₀ + ε with ε being a small extra energy).

Below is a step‐by‐step solution.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Finding the threshold energy E₀

For a reaction to occur, the total energy in the center-of-mass (CM) system must be at least equal to the total mass-energy of the produced particles (when produced with no extra kinetic energy in the CM frame).

a) Compute the invariant mass squared s of the initial state. In the lab frame, the initial four‐momenta are:
  Proton: pᵖ = (Mₚ, 0)   (we use units where c = 1)
  Photon: p^γ = (E, E)   (since the photon’s momentum is E in the same units)

Thus, the total four‐momentum is
  P = pᵖ + p^γ = (Mₚ + E, E).

The invariant mass squared is
  s = P² = (Mₚ + E)² − E² = Mₚ² + 2MₚE.

At threshold in the CM frame the final state particles are produced “at rest” (i.e. with no relative momentum). The final state consists of a proton (mass Mₚ) and a ψ′ (mass 4Mₚ). Hence, the minimum total energy in the CM is:
  √s₍ₘᵢₙ₎ = Mₚ + 4Mₚ = 5Mₚ.
Squaring this,
  s₍ₘᵢₙ₎ = (5Mₚ)² = 25Mₚ².

Setting our expression for s equal to 25Mₚ² gives:
  Mₚ² + 2MₚE₀ = 25Mₚ².
Solving for E₀:
  2MₚE₀ = 25Mₚ² − Mₚ² = 24Mₚ²  ⟹  E₀ = 12Mₚ.

In units of Mₚc² (with c restored, we would write E₀ = 12Mₚc²). Therefore, the minimum photon energy is 12 times the proton rest energy.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Finding the velocity of the ψ′ particle at threshold

At the threshold energy the final state particles in the CM frame have no relative kinetic energy but the entire reaction system as observed in the lab is moving. In the lab, momentum conservation requires that both final particles must move together with a common velocity such that their total momentum equals the momentum of the initial state.

Instead of dealing with the final state separately, one may note that at threshold the final state has zero internal kinetic energy in the CM frame and hence moves with the velocity of the overall CM system. Therefore, finding the CM velocity (relative to the lab) will give us the common velocity of both final particles, including the ψ′.

The total initial energy and momentum in the lab are:
  Energy: E_total = Mₚ + E₀ = Mₚ + 12Mₚ = 13Mₚ
  Momentum: p_total = E₀ = 12Mₚ   (since the proton is initially at rest)

The velocity of the CM system is given by
  β_CM = p_total/E_total = (12Mₚ)/(13Mₚ) = 12/13.

Thus, at threshold the common velocity v (which is also the velocity of the produced ψ′) in the lab is
  v/c = 12/13 ≈ 0.923.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The minimum photon energy required is

  E₀ = 12 Mₚc²   (in units of Mₚc², it is 12).

(b) At threshold, the velocity of the ψ′ particle is

  v/c = 12/13.

──────────────────────────────

We wish to study the motion of a particle of charge e and rest mass m moving in a constant electromagnetic field. In the inertial frame S the electric and magnetic fields are
  E = (a, 0, 0) and B = (0, 0, b),
with the assumption that |E| ≠ |B| (i.e. a² ≠ b²). In what follows we shall derive the equations for the four‐velocity, show that the solutions can be expressed as a sum of exponentials, and then determine the conditions under which all components of the four–velocity remain bounded.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. Writing the Differential Equations

In our notation we choose the Minkowski metric η = diag(1, –1, –1, –1) and define the four–velocity
  u^μ = (u^0, u^1, u^2, u^3),
with u^0 = γ and u^i = γ v^i. The Lorentz force equation in covariant form is
  dp^μ/dτ = e F^{μν} u_ν,
with p^μ = m u^μ and τ the proper time. (One may equally write d u^μ/dτ = (e/m) F^{μν} u_ν.)

A common choice (which we use here) is to take the components of the electromagnetic field tensor F^{μν} to be
  F^{0i} = E^i,  F^{ij} = –ε^{ijk}B_k.
With our fields, the only nonvanishing components are
  F^{01} = a,  F^{10} = –a,
  F^{12} = –b,  F^{21} = b.
(One may check that all other components vanish.)

It is a standard exercise (or one may also work from the three–vector form of the Lorentz force) to show that the four–velocity components then satisfy
  d u^0/dτ = (e/m)(E · u) ,
  d u/dτ   = (e/m)(u^0 E + u × B).
Since in our case E = (a, 0, 0) and B = (0, 0, b), we immediately obtain

  d u^0/dτ = (e/m) a u^1,
  d u^1/dτ = (e/m)[a u^0 + (u × B)_1],
  d u^2/dτ = (e/m)[0  + (u × B)_2],
  d u^3/dτ = (e/m)[0  + (u × B)_3].

Now, the cross–product u × B (with u=(u^1, u^2, u^3) and B = (0, 0, b)) is
  u × B = (b u^2, –b u^1, 0).
Thus, the equations become

  (1) d u^0/dτ = (e/m) a u^1,
  (2) d u^1/dτ = (e/m)[a u^0 + b u^2],
  (3) d u^2/dτ = –(e/m) b u^1,
  (4) d u^3/dτ = 0.
 
Note that equation (4) tells us that u^3 remains constant. The other three equations couple u^0, u^1, and u^2.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Expressing the Equations as an Eigenvalue Problem

It is sometimes convenient to write these three equations in matrix–form. Define the three–vector
  U = (u^0, u^1, u^2)ᵀ.
Then the equations above may be written as

  dU/dτ = (e/m) A U,
where
  A = ⎡ 0   a   0  ⎤
      ⎢ a   0   b  ⎥
      ⎣ 0  –b   0  ⎦.
  
A general solution will be a linear combination of modes of the form U ∝ exp(λτ) where the numbers λ are the eigenvalues of (e/m) A. To determine these eigenvalues we first find the eigenvalues μ of A by solving

  det(A – μ I) = 0.
Writing out the determinant we have

  det ⎡ –μ    a    0 ⎤
       ⎢  a   –μ    b ⎥  = 
       ⎣  0   –b   –μ⎦
 
One may compute:
  det(A – μ I) = (–μ) det ⎡ –μ   b; –b  –μ⎤ – a det ⎡ a  b; 0  –μ ⎤
            = (–μ)[(–μ)(–μ) – (b)(–b)] – a[ a(–μ) – b·0]
            = (–μ)[μ² + b²] + a² μ
            = μ[–(μ² + b²) + a²].
 
Thus, the eigenvalue equation becomes

  μ [a² – μ² – b²] = 0.
 
This gives the eigenvalues for A:
  μ₀ = 0      and  μ² = a² – b² ⇒ μ = ±√(a² – b²).

Since the differential equation is dU/dτ = (e/m) A U, its eigenvalues are

  λ = (e/m) μ,
that is,

  λ₀ = 0   and  λ = ± (e/m) √(a² – b²).

Thus, the general solution for U (and hence for u^0, u^1, u^2) is a superposition of exponentials

  exp[0 · τ] , exp[(e/m)√(a² – b²) τ] , exp[–(e/m)√(a² – b²) τ].

(Recall that u^3 is constant.)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Boundedness of the Four–Velocity

For a general linear system with exponential solutions the behavior of the solution (bounded or unbounded) depends on the real parts of the exponents. Here the relevant exponents (i.e. eigenvalues) are

  λ = ± (e/m) √(a² – b²).

There are two cases to consider:

1. If a² – b² > 0 then the square root is real and one of the exponents is positive. In that case, unless the coefficient multiplying the positive exponential is zero (i.e. for a nongeneric choice of initial conditions), the four–velocity will contain an exponentially growing term and hence will be unbounded as τ → ∞.

2. If a² – b² < 0 then √(a² – b²) is pure imaginary. In that case, the solutions are oscillatory (they are combinations of sinusoids) and no component will grow without bound; thus all components remain bounded.

A third possibility is a² – b² = 0, which is a degenerate case. (However, since the problem assumed |E| ≠ |B|, this case is excluded.)

Since |E| = |a| and |B| = |b|, we see that the four–velocity remains bounded for all τ if and only if

  a² – b² < 0  ⇔  |a| < |b|  ⇔  |E| < |B|.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

We summarize our results as follows.

1. The differential equations for the four–velocity u^μ(τ) are

  d u^0/dτ = (e/m) a u^1,
  d u^1/dτ = (e/m)[a u^0 + b u^2],
  d u^2/dτ = –(e/m) b u^1,
  d u^3/dτ = 0.

2. The solutions for the components of the four–velocity (apart from the trivial constant u^3) can be written as superpositions of exponentials of the form exp(λτ) with

  λ = 0,  λ = +(e/m)√(a² – b²),  λ = –(e/m)√(a² – b²).

3. All components of the four–velocity remain bounded along every trajectory if and only if

  a² – b² < 0  ⇔  |E| < |B|.

Thus, if the magnetic field dominates over the electric field, the four–velocity is bounded.

─────────────────────────────

We will show that when one works out the answer “in terms of γ” (with c = 1 so that γ = 1/√(1 – v²)), one acceptable answer is as follows. (Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.) We assume that each twin’s heart beats once per second in his own proper time. (All times below are measured in seconds.)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. The Traveler’s Own Pulses

Because his heart ticks once per second in his proper time his total number of pulses (both on the way out and on the way back) is simply

  N_sent(traveler) = 2 t₁.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. The Pulses the Traveler Receives from Home

Viewed from the traveler’s world‐line the radio pulses coming from the “stay‐at‐home twin” (who ticks at one pulse per second in his own frame) are Doppler–shifted. (We assume the travel (except for the instantaneous accelerations) is inertial so that the standard relativistic Doppler formula applies.)

On the outbound leg the traveler is receding from home so that he sees the source frequency reduced by the factor

  D₍out₎ = √((1 – v)/(1 + v)).

Since his proper time on this leg is t₁, the number of pulses he receives while moving away is

  N_out = t₁ √((1 – v)/(1 + v)).

On the inbound leg the traveler is approaching home so that he sees the frequencies “blue–shifted” by the factor

  D₍in₎ = √((1 + v)/(1 – v)).

Thus, during his inbound leg he receives

  N_in = t₁ √((1 + v)/(1 – v))  pulses.

Thus his total number of pulses received is

  N_rec(traveler) = t₁ [√((1 – v)/(1 + v)) + √((1 + v)/(1 – v))].

A short little algebra shows that

  √((1 – v)/(1 + v)) + √((1 + v)/(1 – v)) = 2/√(1 – v²) = 2γ.

(To see this briefly, define A = √((1+v)/(1–v)); then the sum is A + 1/A = (A²+1)/A, and one may verify that with A² = (1+v)/(1–v) the result is 2/√(1–v²).)

Therefore

  N_rec(traveler) = 2γ t₁.

Thus the ratio (total received)/(sent) for the traveler is

  (2γ t₁)/(2 t₁) = γ.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Now Consider the Stay‐at–Home Twin

The home twin sends out pulses according to his own clock, once per second, for the entire round–trip. In the home frame the traveler’s round–trip lasts a coordinate time

  T_total(Home) = 2γ t₁   
    (since a half–trip lasts γ t₁).

Thus he sends out

  N_sent(home) = 2γ t₁  pulses.

The home twin, however, receives signals from the traveling twin. (Remember that although the traveler’s heart beats once per second in his own proper time, his pulses travel in the inertial frame of the home twin with a rate that is also affected by the Doppler shifts.) In the home twin’s frame the situation is as follows:

• For some initial period (we call it t₂) he receives the pulses that were emitted when the traveler was on his outbound leg. Since on that leg the traveler’s pulses (sent at one per proper second) are “time dilated” and further “red–shifted” by the fact that the traveler is receding, the net effect is that the pulses are received at an effective rate

  f_rec(out) = √((1 – v)/(1 + v))
     (pulses per home–second).

Now, one may show (by “tracing” the light–signals) that the last pulse sent on the outbound leg (which is the one the traveler emits at his turnaround event at proper time t₁) is received by the home twin at time

  t₂ = γ t₁ (1+v).

Thus, during the interval t₂ the number of pulses received from the outbound portion is

  N_out(home) = t₂ √((1 – v)/(1 + v)) = [γ t₁ (1+v)] √((1 – v)/(1 + v))
     = γ t₁ √((1+v)(1–v)) = γ t₁ √(1–v²).

But since γ = 1/√(1–v²), this simply gives

  N_out(home) = t₁.

• After time t₂ the home twin begins to receive pulses from the traveler’s inbound leg. (Let us denote by t₃ the interval from t₂ till the end of the trip in the home twin’s frame. Clearly, t₃ = T_total – t₂ = 2γ t₁ – γ t₁ (1+v) = γ t₁ (1–v).) On the inbound leg the effective Doppler shift is now

  f_rec(in) = √((1+v)/(1–v))
    (pulses per home–second).

Hence the number of pulses received during the inbound portion is

  N_in(home) = t₃ √((1+v)/(1–v)) = [γ t₁ (1–v)] √((1+v)/(1–v))
     = γ t₁ √((1–v)(1+v)) = γ t₁ √(1–v²)
     = t₁.

Thus the total number received by the home twin is

  N_rec(home) = N_out(home) + N_in(home) = t₁ + t₁ = 2 t₁.

So the ratio of (pulses sent)/(pulses received) for the home twin is

  (2γ t₁)/(2 t₁) = γ.

Notice that while the traveler sees a different Doppler–shifted rate on his two legs (namely, receiving N_out(traveler) and N_in(traveler) as above, whose sum is 2γ t₁) the home twin sees an equal number of pulses coming from the outbound portion and then the inbound portion (namely, t₁ each).

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

1. For the traveler:
  a) Pulses sent altogether:         2 t₁.
  b) Pulses received on the outgoing trip:  t₁ √((1 – v)/(1 + v)).
  c) Pulses received on the ingoing trip:    t₁ √((1 + v)/(1 – v)).
  d) Ratio of total received to sent:     (√((1–v)/(1+v)) + √((1+v)/(1–v)))/2 = γ.

2. For the stay‐at–home twin:
  He sends out pulses for a time 2γ t₁ (i.e. 2γ t₁ pulses).
  He receives pulses from the traveler as follows:
   – During the interval t₂ (up to signal switching) he receives t₁ pulses.
   – During the interval t₃ (from t₂ to the end) he receives t₁ pulses.
  Thus, total pulses received = 2 t₁, and the ratio (sent/received) is (2γ t₁)/(2 t₁) = γ.
  (The ratio between the pulses received in the two intervals is 1 : 1.)

─────────────────────────────

We will show that the answer may be obtained by “going into the mirror‐frame” in which the mirror is at rest, applying ordinary (specular) reflection, and then “boosting back” to the lab. (Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.) In what follows we use units in which c remains explicitly in formulas.

Let us suppose that in the lab frame S an incident photon has frequency ν and is coming in at an angle θi measured from the mirror’s normal. (Throughout we assume that the plane mirror has its surface in the “x–z” plane so that the normal is along the y–axis.) Then its 4–momentum is

  p = (hν/c, p_x, p_y)
       = (hν/c, (hν/c) sinθi, (hν/c) cosθi).

We now consider two cases separately.

───────────────────────────── Case 1: Mirror moving in the x–direction ─────────────────────────────

Here the mirror moves “side‐ways” (that is, along the mirror’s surface) with constant velocity v (with β = v/c and Lorentz factor γ = 1/√(1–β²)). In this case the “boost” connecting the lab S to the mirror frame S′ is along the x–direction. (Since the mirror’s surface is at rest in S′ the law “angle of incidence = angle of reflection” holds there.) 

A Lorentz transformation along x gives

  ω′ = γ (ω – v k_x) ,
  k′_x = γ (k_x – (v/c²) ω) ,
  k′_y = k_y .

For our photon, with
  ω = 2πν , k_x = (ω/c) sinθi , k_y = (ω/c) cosθi, 
we have

  ω′ = ω γ (1 – β sinθi).

Similarly,
  k′_x = (ω/c) γ (sinθi – β) , k′_y = (ω/c) cosθi.

Now, in the mirror frame the mirror is at rest and the reflection is specular. Since the mirror’s plane is perpendicular to the y–axis the component of momentum parallel to the mirror (the x–component) is unchanged while the y–component is reversed. That is, after reflection
  k″_x = k′_x, k″_y = – k′_y ,
and the frequency remains ω′.

Transforming the reflected photon back to the lab (i.e. applying the inverse Lorentz boost along x) we find
  ω_r = γ (ω′ + v k″_x)
     = γ [ω γ (1 – β sinθi) + v · γ (ω/c)(sinθi – β)]
     = γ² ω [(1 – β sinθi) + β (sinθi – β)].
A short algebra shows that
  (1 – β sinθi) + β(sinθi – β) = 1 – β²,
so that
  ω_r = γ² (1 – β²) ω = ω    (since γ²(1–β²)=1).

Also it is not hard to show that the lab–components of the reflected photon are
  k_{r,x} = (ω/c) sinθi , k_{r,y} = – (ω/c) cosθi.
Thus, the reflected photon in S has exactly the same frequency and the same “angle with respect to the normal” (but on the opposite side) as the incident photon. In other words, when the mirror moves along x we have

  θr = θi  and  ν′ = ν.

───────────────────────────── Case 2: Mirror moving in the y–direction ─────────────────────────────

Now suppose that the mirror moves with speed v along the y–axis (i.e. along its normal). Then the Lorentz boost is along the y–direction. (Of course, for a “normal incidence” one expects a Doppler shift corresponding to a double–Doppler effect.)

The Lorentz transformation for a boost along y gives

  ω′ = γ (ω – v k_y) ,
  k′_y = γ (k_y – (v/c²) ω) ,
  k′_x = k_x .

For the incident photon we thus have

  ω′ = γ ω (1 – β cosθi) ,
  k′_x = (ω/c) sinθi ,
  k′_y = γ (ω/c)(cosθi – β).

In the mirror’s rest frame the law of reflection holds. Since the mirror’s surface still lies in the x–z plane (its normal is the y–axis) the x–component is unaffected while the y–component changes sign. Therefore the reflected photon in S′ has

  k″_x = k′_x, k″_y = – k′_y,
  ω″ = ω′ (= γ ω (1 – β cosθi) ).

Now we boost back to the lab. (The inverse Lorentz transformation for a boost in the y–direction is very similar to the forward one.) In particular,
  ω_r = γ (ω″ + v k″_y)
     = γ [ω′ + v (– k′_y)]
     = γ [γ ω (1 – β cosθi) – v·γ (ω/c)(cosθi – β)]
     = γ² ω [ (1 – β cosθi) – β (cosθi – β)].
A little algebra gives
  (1 – β cosθi) – β (cosθi – β) = 1 – 2β cosθi + β².
Thus, in the lab the reflected photon has frequency
  ω_r = γ² ω (1 – 2β cosθi + β²)   or equivalently ν_r = ν γ² (1 – 2β cosθi + β²).

Let us also find the reflected direction. (One may either compute the transformed momentum components directly or use the relativistic “aberration‐formula”. Here we note that the x–component is unaffected by a boost in y.) In our case, after transforming back to the lab one obtains

  k_{r,x} = k″_x = (ω/c) sinθi,
  k_{r,y} = γ (k″_y + (v/c²) ω″)
     = γ [ – γ (ω/c)(cosθi – β) + β·(ω″/c)],
with ω″ = γ ω (1 – β cosθi). A short calculation shows that

  k_{r,y} = (ω/c) · γ² [2β – (1+β²) cosθi].
Thus the reflected ray makes an angle θr (with the normal) defined by

  tanθr = (|k_{r,x}|)/(|k_{r,y}|)
     = sinθi / { γ² [ (1+β²) cosθi – 2β ] }.

It is straightforward to check that when β = 0 one recovers tanθr = tanθi.

───────────────────────────── Final Answer ─────────────────────────────

An acceptable answer is to state that

1. For a mirror moving in the x–direction (parallel to its surface)
   θ_r = θ_i  and  ν′ = ν.

2. For a mirror moving in the y–direction (i.e. along the normal)
   ν′ = ν · γ² (1 – 2β cosθ_i + β²),
   tan θ_r = sinθ_i⁄{ γ² [ (1+β²) cosθ_i – 2β ] }         (with β = v/c and γ = 1/√(1–β²)). 

Any answer equivalent to the answer above is correct.

Thus, our final boxed answer is

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\text{For mirror moving in the $x$–direction:} \\
&\theta_r=\theta_i,\quad \nu'=\nu, \\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{For mirror moving in the $y$–direction:} \\
&\nu'=\nu\,\gamma^2\Bigl(1-2\beta\cos\theta_i+\beta^2\Bigr),\\[1mm]
&\tan\theta_r=\frac{\sin\theta_i}{\gamma^2\Bigl[(1+\beta^2)\cos\theta_i-2\beta\Bigr]}\,,
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start with the fact that in observer 1’s frame the particle has speed v and its velocity makes an angle φ with the z‐axis. If we assume (without loss of generality) that the particle is moving in the x–z plane then its components in observer 1’s frame are

  vₓ = v sin φ  and  v_z = v cos φ.

Observer 2 moves with speed u in the z‑direction relative to observer 1. For a boost in the z‑direction the standard velocity‐addition formulas tell us that the components of the particle’s velocity in observer 2’s frame are given by

  (1)  v′ₓ = vₓ / [γ_u (1 – u v_z/c²)],
  (2)  v′_z = (v_z – u) / (1 – u v_z/c²),

with

  γ_u = 1/√(1 – u²/c²).

Since vₓ = v sin φ and v_z = v cos φ we have

  v′ₓ = (v sin φ) / [γ_u (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)]
  v′_z = (v cos φ – u) / [1 – (u v cos φ)/c²].

The magnitude of the velocity in observer 2’s frame is then

  v′ = √[(v′ₓ)² + (v′_z)²] = √{ [v² sin² φ / (γ_u² (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)²)] + [ (v cos φ – u)² / (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)² ] }.

It is convenient to factor out the common denominator:

  v′ = 1/(1 – (u v cos φ)/c²) · √[ (v² sin² φ)/γ_u² + (v cos φ – u)² ].

The direction of the particle in observer 2’s frame is given by the angle φ′ (with respect to the z‑axis), which satisfies

  tan φ′ = v′ₓ/v′_z = (v sin φ)/(γ_u (v cos φ – u)).

Thus, we have obtained the following formulas:
  • The velocity components in observer 2’s frame are
    v′ₓ = (v sin φ)/[γ_u (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)],
    v′_z = (v cos φ – u)/(1 – (u v cos φ)/c²).
  • The speed is
    v′ = √{ (v sin φ)²/(γ_u² (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)²) + (v cos φ – u)²/(1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)² },
  • The direction is given by
    tan φ′ = (v sin φ)/(γ_u (v cos φ – u)).

Now, let’s check the limit v → c. If we set v = c the components become

  v′ₓ = (c sin φ)/[γ_u (1 – (u c cos φ)/c²)] = (c sin φ)/[γ_u (1 – (u cos φ)/c)],
  v′_z = (c cos φ – u)/(1 – (u cos φ)/c).

Then the speed v′ is

  v′ = √{ (c sin φ)²/(γ_u² (1 – (u cos φ)/c)²) + (c cos φ – u)²/(1 – (u cos φ)/c)² }
     = 1/(1 – (u cos φ)/c) √[ c² sin² φ/γ_u² + (c cos φ – u)² ].

After some algebra (or by recalling that the speed of light is invariant), one verifies that v′ = c. Also, the aberration formula for light is recovered from the relation for the direction. In fact, one can show that the aberration of light is given by

  cos φ′ = (cos φ – u/c)/(1 – (u cos φ)/c)
  sin φ′ = sin φ/(γ_u (1 – (u cos φ)/c)),

which is entirely equivalent to the expression we derived for tan φ′.

Thus, our final results are: 

  Speed components in observer 2’s frame:
   v′ₓ = (v sin φ)⁄[γ_u (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)],
   v′_z = (v cos φ – u)⁄(1 – (u v cos φ)/c²).

  The speed:
   v′ = √{ (v sin φ)²⁄[γ_u² (1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)²] + (v cos φ – u)²⁄(1 – (u v cos φ)/c²)² }.

  The direction (angle with the z‑axis):
   tan φ′ = (v sin φ)/(γ_u (v cos φ – u)).

All of these formulas reduce to the standard results for the aberration of light when v → c.

We wish to study the reaction

  γ + p → p + π⁰     (1)

with the proton mass mₚ = 938 MeV and the neutral pion mass m_π = 135 MeV. We will use natural units (c = 1) and work step‐by‐step.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Threshold for a Proton at Rest

When the target proton is at rest, the four–momentum of the system is
  pₚ = (mₚ, 0)
  p_γ = (E_γ, E_γ)     (since a photon’s momentum equals its energy).

The square of the total four–momentum (the invariant amount s) is a Lorentz invariant and must equal the square of the total mass in the final state when the reaction just “goes” (threshold). At threshold the final particles are produced at rest in the overall center‐of–mass frame so that

  s_threshold = (mₚ + m_π)².

On the other hand, using the initial state we have

  s = (pₚ + p_γ)² = mₚ² + 2 mₚ E_γ + 0    (since pₚ·p_γ = mₚE_γ when pₚ = (mₚ,0)).

Setting these equal gives

  mₚ² + 2 mₚ E_γ^th = (mₚ + m_π)².

Let us solve for E_γ^th:

  2 mₚ E_γ^th = (mₚ + m_π)² – mₚ²
  2 mₚ E_γ^th = mₚ² + 2 mₚ m_π + m_π² – mₚ²
  2 mₚ E_γ^th = 2 mₚ m_π + m_π²

Thus

  E_γ^th = m_π +  m_π²/(2 mₚ).

Plugging in the numbers:

  m_π = 135 MeV,
  m_π² = (135 MeV)² = 18225 MeV²,
  2 mₚ = 2 × 938 MeV = 1876 MeV.

Thus

  E_γ^th = 135 MeV + (18225 / 1876) MeV
      ≈ 135 MeV + 9.72 MeV
      ≈ 144.7 MeV.

So, to trigger the reaction with a proton at rest, the gamma–ray must have a laboratory energy of approximately 145 MeV.

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Head–On Collision of a Proton and a 10^(–3) eV Photon

Now let the photon be a low–energy cosmic background photon with energy
  E_γ = 10^(–3) eV.
It is most effective if the collision with a high–energy proton is head–on.

In the laboratory frame (which we now take to be the rest frame of the cosmic background), the incident proton is moving with energy Eₚ (to be determined). Its four–momentum is
  pₚ = (Eₚ, p),
and the photon’s four–momentum is
  p_γ = (E_γ, –E_γ)     (head–on: their momenta are opposite).

Then the invariant is

  s = (pₚ + p_γ)² = mₚ² + 2 Eₚ E_γ + 2 p E_γ    (since the photon’s energy equals its momentum in magnitude).

For a head–on collision the two momenta add; in fact, more generally one obtains:
  s = mₚ² + 2EₚE_γ (1 + β)
with β = p/Eₚ. For a very energetic proton, β ≈ 1 so that
  1 + β ≈ 2.
Thus, approximately,

  s ≈ mₚ² + 4 Eₚ E_γ.

At threshold the invariant must equal (mₚ + m_π)². Setting
  mₚ² + 4 Eₚ E_γ = (mₚ + m_π)²,
we solve for the proton energy Eₚ^th:

  4 Eₚ^th E_γ = (mₚ + m_π)² – mₚ² = 2 mₚ m_π + m_π².

Thus

  Eₚ^th = (2 mₚ m_π + m_π²) / (4 E_γ).

Now, substitute the numbers remembering to use consistent energy units. It is convenient to convert the photon energy from eV to MeV:
  1 eV = 10^(–6) MeV,
so  E_γ = 10^(–3) eV = 10^(–9) MeV.

Now compute the numerator:
  2 mₚ m_π = 2 × 938 × 135 = 2 × 126630 = 253260 MeV²,
  m_π² = 18225 MeV².
Adding,
  2 mₚ m_π + m_π² = 253260 + 18225 = 271485 MeV².

Thus

  Eₚ^th = 271485 MeV² / [4 × 10^(–9) MeV]
      = 271485 / (4 × 10^(–9)) MeV
      = 6.787125 × 10^(13) MeV.

It is customary to express ultra–high energies in eV. Convert MeV to eV:
  1 MeV = 10^(6) eV, so
  Eₚ^th = 6.787125 × 10^(13) MeV × 10^(6) eV/MeV
       = 6.787125 × 10^(19) eV.

Thus the minimum proton energy required is approximately 6.8 × 10^(19) eV, which is of the same order as the famous Greisen–Zatsepin–Kuzmin (GZK) cutoff.

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Implications for the Energy Spectrum of Cosmic–Ray Protons

Since the cosmic–microwave background (CMB) has typical photon energies on the order of 10^(–3) eV, high–energy protons with energies above roughly 7 × 10^(19) eV can interact with these abundant low–energy photons to produce pions via the reaction (1). This interaction leads to energy losses for the cosmic–ray protons as they propagate over cosmological distances. Consequently, one expects a suppression in the number of cosmic–ray protons with energies above this threshold, resulting in a cutoff in the observed cosmic–ray energy spectrum. This is known as the GZK cutoff.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers in Boxed LaTeX Format

(a) The threshold gamma–ray energy (for p at rest) is
  E_γ^th = m_π + m_π²/(2mₚ) ≈ 145 MeV.

(b) For a head–on collision with a 10^(–3) eV photon, the threshold proton energy is approximately 6.8 × 10^(19) eV.

(c) This result implies that cosmic–ray protons with energies above ~10^(20) eV will interact with CMB photons and lose energy through pion photoproduction, leading to an effective cutoff (the GZK cutoff) in the high–energy cosmic–ray spectrum.

We are given two particles of the same mass m with momenta

  p₁ = 5mc   and   p₂ = 10mc,

both moving in the same direction in some “lab” frame. We wish to know, for example, what is the speed of the faster particle as seen from the slower one’s rest frame, and vice‐versa.

Step 1. Find the velocities in the lab frame.

For a particle of mass m the momentum is given by

  p = γ m v  (1)

with

  γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²).

It is convenient to write (1) in “unit‐free” form by dividing by mc:

  p/(mc) = (γ v/c) = β/√(1 − β²)  (2)

where β = v/c. For each particle we equate (2) with the given numbers.

Particle 1:
  β₁/√(1 − β₁²) = 5.  
Squaring and solving,
  β₁²/(1 − β₁²) = 25  →  β₁² = 25(1 − β₁²)  →  β₁² (1 + 25) = 25  
  β₁² = 25/26  →  β₁ = 5/√26.
Thus, the velocity of particle 1 is
  v₁ = (5c)/√26.

Particle 2:
  β₂/√(1 − β₂²) = 10.  
Similarly,
  β₂²/(1 − β₂²) = 100  →  β₂² = 100(1 − β₂²)  →  β₂² (1 + 100) = 100  
  β₂² = 100/101  →  β₂ = 10/√101.
Thus,
  v₂ = (10c)/√101.

A numerical evaluation gives approximately:
  √26 ≈ 5.099 → v₁ ≈ 5c/5.099 ≈ 0.9804 c,
  √101 ≈ 10.05 → v₂ ≈ 10c/10.05 ≈ 0.9950 c.

Step 2. Find the relative velocity.

In special relativity, if two objects move along the same line with speeds v₁ and v₂ (v₂ > v₁), then the speed u of the faster as seen in the rest frame of the slower particle is given by the velocity–addition formula:
  u = (v₂ − v₁)/(1 − (v₁v₂)/c²).  (3)

Substitute v₁ and v₂:
  u = [v₂ − v₁] / [1 − (v₁v₂)/c²]
    = [(10c/√101) − (5c/√26)] / [1 − ( (5/√26)(10/√101) ].

Let’s evaluate this approximately:
  v₂ − v₁ ≈ (0.9950c − 0.9804c) = 0.0146c.
  The product v₁v₂/c² ≈ 0.9804 × 0.9950 ≈ 0.9755, so the denominator is 1 − 0.9755 = 0.0245.
Thus,
  u ≈ 0.0146c/0.0245 ≈ 0.596c.

Step 3. Interpret the Result

Thus, as seen from the slower particle’s rest frame, the faster particle is moving at approximately 0.60c. By the symmetry of relative velocities in special relativity, in the rest frame of the faster particle, the slower particle will be seen to have speed ≈ 0.60c (but in the opposite direction).

Final Answer:
  The relative speed between the two particles is approximately 0.60c.

Thus, we write the final result as:

  \[
\boxed{ u \approx 0.60\,c }
\]

We start by noting that in this reaction the kaon “regenerates” by changing its internal state; the mass changes from that of the long‐lived kaon (Kₗ) to that of the short‐lived kaon (Kₛ). That is, initially the kaon has mass

  m(Kₗ) = 5×10⁸ eV/c²

and after the collision its mass is smaller by

  Δm = m(Kₗ) – m(Kₛ) = 3.5×10⁻⁶ eV/c².

Even though the brick’s internal state does not change, by conservation of momentum the brick must “absorb” the momentum difference between the incident and outgoing kaon. In our case the meson beam is moving with velocity v given by

  β = v/c = 1/√2 ⟹ v = c/√2.

Because the kaons are relativistic the momentum is given by

  p = γ m v

where the Lorentz factor is

  γ = 1/√(1 – β²) = 1/√(1 – 1/2) = √2.

Thus, the incident kaon momentum is

  pₗ = γ m(Kₗ) v

and the exiting kaon momentum is

  pₛ = γ m(Kₛ) v.

Since the directions are the same we have a momentum change per meson of

  Δp = pₗ – pₛ = γ [m(Kₗ) – m(Kₛ)] v.

Now note that
  γ v = (√2)(c/√2) = c.
Thus the momentum change becomes

  Δp = (m(Kₗ) – m(Kₛ)) · c = Δm · c.

It is this momentum difference per collision that is transferred to the brick. With a beam intensity of 10⁶ kaons per second, the net force (rate of momentum transfer) on the brick is

  F = (number rate) × Δp = (10⁶ s⁻¹) · (Δm · c).

Before plugging in numbers we must get our units in SI. The mass difference is given in eV/c². First, note that
  Δm = 3.5×10⁻⁶ eV/c².
Multiply by c to get momentum units in eV/c:
  Δp = (3.5×10⁻⁶ eV/c²)·c = 3.5×10⁻⁶ eV/c.

Now we convert eV/c to SI momentum:
  1 eV = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J
and therefore
  1 eV/c = (1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J)/(3×10⁸ m/s) ≈ 5.34×10⁻²⁸ kg·m/s.

Thus
  Δp ≈ 3.5×10⁻⁶ × 5.34×10⁻²⁸ kg·m/s ≈ 1.87×10⁻³³ kg·m/s.

Then the average force is

  F = (10⁶ s⁻¹) × (1.87×10⁻³³ kg·m/s) = 1.87×10⁻²⁷ N.

Since the momentum of the kaon decreases in the forward (beam) direction, by conservation of momentum the brick experiences a force in the direction of the beam.

Thus, the average force exerted on the brick is approximately

  F ≈ 1.9×10⁻²⁷ N  (in the direction of the beam).

Finally, if one wishes to express the answer in dynes, recall that 1 N = 10⁵ dynes so that

  F ≈ 1.9×10⁻²⁷ N ≈ 1.9×10⁻²² dynes.

The final answer is:

  \[
\boxed{ F \approx 1.9 \times 10^{-27}\,\mathrm{N} \quad \text{(in the direction of the beam)} }
\]

We wish to find the frequency ν′ measured by an observer in frame K′ and the angle at which the wave is seen. In frame K (the source frame) the wave has frequency ν and the propagation direction makes an angle θ = 60° with the x‑axis. The source is moving with speed v = (4/5)c in the +x‑direction (i.e. along the x‑axis) toward an observer at rest in frame K′.

Step 1. Transforming the Wave’s 4‑Wavevector

For a photon (or any wave propagating at speed c), the 4‑wavevector in K is given by
  k = (ω/c, kx, ky, 0),
where ω = 2πν and
  kx = (ω/c) cosθ,  ky = (ω/c) sinθ.

A Lorentz boost in the +x‑direction (from K to K′) transforms the time component and the x‑component of the wave vector as follows:
  k′₀ = γ (k₀ − β kx)
  k′ₓ = γ (kx − β k₀)
while the y‑component is unchanged:
  k′_y = ky.
Here, β = v/c = 4/5 and the Lorentz factor is
  γ = 1/√(1 − β²) = 1/√(1 − (16/25)) = 5/3.

Since k₀ = ω/c = 2πν/c, we see that the measured frequency in K′ will be given by
  ν′ = (c/2π) k′₀ = γ (1 − β cosθ) ν.

Step 2. Calculating ν′

Substitute β = 4/5 and cosθ = cos 60° = 1/2:
  ν′ = γ (1 − β cos60°) ν
    = (5/3) (1 − (4/5)(1/2)) ν
    = (5/3) (1 − 2/5) ν
    = (5/3) (3/5) ν
    = ν.

Thus, the observer in K′ measures the same frequency as the proper frequency ν.

Step 3. Determining the Observed Angle in K′

The aberration of light formula gives the relation between the angle θ in K and the angle θ′ in K′:
  cosθ′ = (cosθ − β) / (1 − β cosθ).

Plug in cosθ = 1/2 and β = 4/5:
  cosθ′ = (1/2 − 4/5) / (1 − (4/5)(1/2))
    = ((5 − 8)/10) / (1 − 2/5)
    = (–3/10) / (3/5)
    = (–3/10) × (5/3)
    = –1/2.

Since cosine of the angle in K′ is –1/2, it means
  θ′ = 120°    (since cos120° = –1/2).

Thus the wave, originally moving at 60° in K, is seen at an angle of 120° in the moving frame K′.

Final Answer:

(a) ν′ = ν  
(b) The wave is observed at an angle θ′ = 120° in K′.

\[ \boxed{ \text{(a) } \nu' = \nu \quad \text{and} \quad \text{(b) } \theta' = 120^\circ } \]

We wish to study the following situation. In the laboratory frame the initial state is

• Particle 1: mass m, total energy E₀ (so that its momentum is p₀ = √(E₀² – m²)); it is moving to the right with speed V.
• Particle 2: mass m, initially at rest (energy = m).

After an elastic collision the two particles emerge with the same kinetic energy (and, of course, the same rest mass). Thus, if we denote by E the total energy of either outgoing particle, then

  Energy conservation: E₀ + m = 2E  ⟹  E = (E₀ + m)/2.

Since the particles have equal total energies, they also have equal momenta in the lab frame; call the magnitude of each final momentum p. (Note that p is given by p = √(E² – m²) with E = (E₀+m)/2.)

We now assume that after the collision the two outgoing particles have a relative scattering angle θ. (That is, the two particles’ momentum vectors make an angle θ with respect to each other.)

Our plan is to use momentum conservation to relate the scattering angle θ with the given quantities E₀ and m.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Write the Conservation Laws

In the lab frame the total 3‐momentum must be conserved. Initially, the momentum is entirely in one direction (say, the x–direction) with magnitude p₀. After the collision, if the momenta of the two particles are p₁ and p₂ (with |p₁| = |p₂| = p) and the angle between them is θ, then the vector sum is

  p_total² = |p₁ + p₂|² = p² + p² + 2p² cosθ = 2p²(1 + cosθ).

Thus, we must have

  p₀² = 2p²(1 + cosθ).             (1)
 
──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Express p₀ and p in terms of E₀ and m

The incoming particle has
  p₀ = √(E₀² – m²).

For either outgoing particle, we have (recalling that energy and momentum for a relativistic particle satisfy E² = p² + m²)
  p = √(E² – m²)  with E = (E₀ + m)/2.

Thus,
  p² = E² – m² = ((E₀ + m)²/4) – m²
      = [E₀² + 2mE₀ + m² – 4m²] / 4
      = (E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²) / 4.      (2)
 
──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Equate and Solve for cosθ

Inserting (1) and (2) into the conservation of momentum, we have:
  E₀² – m² = 2 · [(E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²)/4] (1 + cosθ).

Simplify the right‐hand side:
  E₀² – m² = [(E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²)/2](1 + cosθ).

Now solve for (1 + cosθ):

  1 + cosθ = 2(E₀² – m²) / (E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²).

Thus,
  cosθ = [2(E₀² – m²) / (E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²)] – 1.  (3)

It is useful to simplify this expression further. Notice that
  2(E₀² – m²) – (E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²)
   = 2E₀² – 2m² – E₀² – 2mE₀ + 3m²
   = E₀² – 2mE₀ + m²
   = (E₀ – m)².

Thus, the right‐hand side of (3) can be written as

  cosθ = (E₀ – m)² / (E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m²).

Now, note that the quadratic in the denominator factors nicely. In fact, one may check that

  E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m² = (E₀ – m)(E₀ + 3m).

(You can verify this by expanding (E₀ – m)(E₀ + 3m) = E₀² + 3mE₀ – mE₀ – 3m² = E₀² + 2mE₀ – 3m².)

Cancelling a factor of (E₀ – m) (and remembering that E₀ > m so the cancellation is valid) we arrive at a very neat result:

  cosθ = (E₀ – m) / (E₀ + 3m).         (4)

Thus, the answer to part (a) is: the scattering angle θ in the lab frame is given by

  θ = arccos[(E₀ – m)/(E₀ + 3m)].

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Finding the Limits

(i) Low energy (V ≪ c)

For a non‐relativistic incoming particle its total energy is just a little more than its rest energy, so we write:
  E₀ = m + 𝜖,  with 𝜖 ≪ m.

Then,
  (E₀ – m)/(E₀ + 3m) = 𝜖/(m + 𝜖 + 3m) = 𝜖/(4m + 𝜖) ≈ 𝜖/(4m),  which is very small.

Since cosθ is very small (i.e. approximately 0) we have
  θ ≈ arccos(0) = π/2.

Thus, in the nonrelativistic limit the two particles scatter at 90° relative to one another.

(ii) High energy (V ~ c)

For a highly relativistic incoming particle E₀ ≫ m. Then,
  (E₀ – m) ≈ E₀
  (E₀ + 3m) ≈ E₀,
so that
  (E₀ – m)/(E₀ + 3m) ≈ 1.

Thus, cosθ ≈ 1, which implies
  θ ≈ arccos(1) = 0.

That is, at very high energies the scattering is very forward – the outgoing particles move nearly in the same direction.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The relationship between the scattering angle θ, the mass m, and the incident total energy E₀ is
  θ = arccos((E₀ – m)/(E₀ + 3m)).

(b) In the two limits:
  (i) For low-energy (V ≪ c): θ → π/2.
  (ii) For high-energy (V ~ c): θ → 0.

Thus, we have

  Final Answer:
        
    ∴ θ = arccos[(E₀ – m)/(E₀ + 3m)], with θ ≈ π/2 for E₀ ≈ m and θ ≈ 0 for E₀ ≫ m.

In boxed form, the final answer is

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)} \quad \theta &= \arccos\left(\frac{E_0 - m}{E_0 + 3m}\right), \\
\text{(b)} \quad \text{(i) For } V \ll c: \quad \theta &\to \frac{\pi}{2}, \quad
\text{(ii) For } V \sim c: \quad \theta \to 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that by choosing appropriate generalized coordinates the problem “decouples” into a free translation plus a one‐dimensional “radial” oscillator (with an extra “centrifugal” term) together with an angle whose evolution is obtained by quadrature. One acceptable answer is as follows. (Any answer equivalent to the one below is correct.)

Step 1. (Choosing coordinates)

Because we assume that the two particles remain equidistant from the geometrical center of the rod, it is natural to introduce

 • R⃗ = the position of the center-of-mass of the rod (which we shall take to be its “center”), and

 • φ = the orientation (angle) of the rod (with respect to a fixed direction).

In addition, we let r be the common distance along the rod from the center to each particle. (A priori the unstretched spring has some “natural length” r₀ so that the spring potential will involve r–r₀.)

Thus the positions of the two particles are given by
  r⃗₁ = R⃗ + r (cos φ, sin φ),
  r⃗₂ = R⃗ – r (cos φ, sin φ).

Step 2. (Writing the kinetic energy)

The rod, which we take to be uniform and of mass M and length L, has translational kinetic energy
  T₁ = (1/2) M (Ṙ²)
and rotational kinetic energy (about its center) 
  T₂ = (1/2) I₀ φ̇²,
with
  I₀ = (1/12) M L².

Each particle (mass m) has kinetic energy
  Tₚ = ½ m |d/dt (R⃗ ± r u⃗)|²,
with u⃗ = (cos φ, sin φ). Calculating the time derivative,
  d/dt (r u⃗) = ṙ u⃗ + r φ̇ (–sin φ, cos φ),
so that
  |d/dt (r u⃗)|² = ṙ² + r² φ̇².
Since the cross terms cancel for the two particles (because one has +r and the other –r), their total kinetic energy is
  T_particles = 2·½ m (Ṙ² + ṙ² + r² φ̇²)
         = m Ṙ² + m (ṙ² + r² φ̇²).

Thus the total kinetic energy is
  T = ½ M Ṙ² + ½ I₀ φ̇² + m Ṙ² + m (ṙ² + r² φ̇²)
    = ½ (M + 2m) Ṙ² + m ṙ² + (½ I₀ + m r²) φ̇².

Notice that the center-of-mass coordinate R⃗ is “cyclic” (because there is no potential depending on it) and its equation of motion will be that of a free particle.

Step 3. (The potential energy)

Both springs, assumed identical with spring constant k (and natural length r₀), contribute
  Vₚ = ½ k (r – r₀)² 
for each spring. Hence the total potential energy is
  V = 2·½ k (r – r₀)² = k (r – r₀)².

Thus the Lagrangian for the “internal” degrees of freedom (r and φ) is
  L = m ṙ² + (½ I₀ + m r²) φ̇² – k (r – r₀)².

Step 4. (Euler–Lagrange equations)

Since the overall center-of-mass coordinate R⃗ does not appear in the potential, its equation is simply
  d²R⃗/dt² = 0,
so that R⃗ moves uniformly.

There remain two coordinates, r and φ.

a) φ is cyclic. Its conjugate momentum is
  p₍φ₎ = ∂L/∂φ̇ = I₀ φ̇ + 2 m r² φ̇ = (I₀ + 2m r²) φ̇.
Thus conservation of angular momentum gives
  (I₀ + 2m r²) φ̇ = L₀    (1)
with L₀ a constant.

b) The r equation follows from
  d/dt (∂L/∂ṙ) – ∂L/∂r = 0.
We have
  ∂L/∂ṙ = 2m ṙ    so d/dt(2m ṙ) = 2m r̈,
and
  ∂L/∂r = d/dr [(½ I₀ + m r²) φ̇²] + d/dr [–k (r–r₀)²]
       = 2m r φ̇² – 2k (r – r₀).
Thus the r equation is
  2m r̈ – [2m r φ̇² – 2k (r – r₀)] = 0.
Dividing by 2 we obtain
  m r̈ = m r φ̇² – k (r – r₀).    (2)

Using (1) we may express φ̇ in terms of r:
  φ̇ = L₀/(I₀ + 2m r²).

Thus the r–equation becomes
  m r̈ = m r (L₀/(I₀ + 2m r²))² – k (r – r₀).

Step 5. (Energy conservation and integration)

Since there is no explicit time dependence in L, the “internal” energy is conserved. The energy associated with r and φ is
  E = m ṙ² + (½ (I₀ + 2m r²) φ̇²) + k (r – r₀)².
Using (1), we can rewrite the rotational kinetic energy as
  ½ (I₀+2m r²) φ̇² = L₀²/[2(I₀+2m r²)].
Thus an expression for the conserved energy is
  E = m ṙ² + L₀²/[2(I₀+2m r²)] + k (r – r₀)².    (3)
It is then possible to write
  t = ∫ dr/√{(1/m)[E – k (r–r₀)² – L₀²/(2(I₀+2m r²))]}, 
so that, up to quadratures, the r–motion is fully solved. Once r(t) is known, φ(t) follows immediately from (1) via
  φ(t) = φ(0) + ∫₀ᵗ L₀/(I₀+2m r(τ)²) dτ.

Step 6. (Qualitative description of the motion)

Qualitatively, the overall motion separates into three parts:
 1. The center-of-mass R⃗ moves with constant velocity (free translation).
 2. The “radial” coordinate r oscillates about an equilibrium value (which would be r₀ if L₀ = 0, but is shifted if there is nonzero angular momentum) as a result of the restoring force from the springs and an “effective centrifugal” force m r φ̇².
 3. The angle φ changes according to the conservation law (1); because the moment of inertia is I₀ + 2m r², the angular speed φ̇ is not constant. In particular, when r is larger (so the particles are farther from the rod’s center) the rod rotates more slowly, and vice‐versa.

Thus the full motion consists of uniform translation, an oscillatory “breathing” (extension/contraction) of the system along the rod accompanied by variations in the rotational speed of the rod (and attached particles), so that the angular momentum is conserved.

Step 7. (Final Answer)

We may therefore summarize our answer as follows:

The full equations of motion (in a fixed inertial frame) are

(1) The free motion of the center-of-mass:
  d²R⃗/dt² = 0.

(2) The “radial” motion:
  m r̈ = m r φ̇² – k (r – r₀),
with
  φ̇ = L₀/(I₀+2m r²),  I₀ = (1/12)ML².

(3) Conservation of energy (for the internal degrees of freedom):
  E = m ṙ² + L₀²/[2(I₀+2m r²)] + k (r – r₀)².

Thus, given initial conditions, one may integrate
  t = ∫ dr/√{(1/m)[E – k (r–r₀)² – L₀²/(2(I₀+2m r²))]}
to obtain r(t) and then obtain φ(t) from
  φ(t) = φ(0) + ∫₀ᵗ L₀/(I₀+2m r(τ)²) dτ.
Qualitatively, the system’s center-of-mass moves uniformly in space while the particles “breathe” symmetrically about the rod’s center under the combined effects of the spring force and the “centrifugal” force (when there is nonzero angular momentum). At the same time the rod rotates with an angular speed that varies inversely with the instantaneous moment of inertia (I₀ + 2m r²).

Final Answer in boxed form:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a) The center‐of‐mass motion:} \quad \ddot{\mathbf R} = 0,\\[1mm]
&\text{(b) The “internal” motion is given by:}\\[1mm]
&\quad m\ddot{r} = m\,r\,\dot{\phi}^2 - k (r-r_0),\\[1mm]
&\quad (I_0+2mr^2)\dot{\phi} = L_0,\quad\text{with } I_0=\frac{ML^2}{12},\\[1mm]
&\text{and energy conservation:}\quad E = m\dot{r}^2 + \frac{L_0^2}{2(I_0+2mr^2)} + k (r-r_0)^2.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

This answer, expressed up to the point of quadratures (i.e. one may write an integral for t as a function of r), is completely equivalent to the answer given above.

We begin with a particle of mass m moving under a potential V(x, y, z) in an inertial frame. However, we wish to describe its dynamics using a coordinate system that rotates about the z‐axis with constant angular velocity ω. In the rotating frame the coordinates (x, y, z) remain the same, but the relationship between the time–derivative of the coordinates in the rotating frame and those in the inertial (lab) frame is modified.

Step 1. (Expressing the Kinetic Energy in the Rotating Frame)

If we denote by (x, y, z) the coordinates in the rotating frame, then a point has the same coordinate values in this frame. However, in the inertial frame the velocity is given by

  v_lab = (ẋ – ωy, ẏ + ωx, ż).

Thus the kinetic energy, as seen in the inertial frame, is

  T = (1/2)m[(ẋ – ωy)² + (ẏ + ωx)² + ż²].

Expanding the squares we have

  (ẋ – ωy)² = ẋ² – 2ωyẋ + ω²y²,
  (ẏ + ωx)² = ẏ² + 2ωxẏ + ω²x².

Hence,
  T = (1/2)m[ẋ² + ẏ² + ż²] + mω(xẏ – yẋ) + (1/2)mω²(x² + y²).

The Lagrangian in the inertial frame is L = T – V; therefore, when written in the rotating coordinates it becomes

  L = ½m(ẋ² + ẏ² + ż²) + mω(xẏ – yẋ) + ½mω²(x² + y²) – V(x, y, z).

Step 2. (Rewriting in “Fixed–Frame Form”)

We now wish to show that the equations of motion determined by Lagrange’s equations in the rotating system can be written in the same form as those for a particle in a fixed coordinate system acted on by two forces:
1. The force –∇V, and 
2. A force derived from a velocity–dependent potential U.

To do this, write the Lagrangian in the form

  L = ½m(ẋ² + ẏ² + ż²) – [V(x, y, z) + U(x, y, z, ẋ, ẏ)],

so that the extra terms coming from the rotation (namely, the mω(xẏ – yẋ) and the term ½mω²(x² + y²)) are now collected in U (with an overall minus sign in the Lagrangian). Comparing with our previous expression, we identify

  –U(x, y, z, ẋ, ẏ) = mω(xẏ – yẋ) + ½mω² (x² + y²).

Thus, the velocity–dependent potential is

  U(x, y, z, ẋ, ẏ) = –mω(xẏ – yẋ) – ½mω² (x² + y²).

Step 3. (Verifying the Form of the Lagrange Equations)

Let us now briefly check that with the Lagrangian written as

  L = ½m(ẋ² + ẏ² + ż²) – V(x, y, z) – U(x, y, z, ẋ, ẏ),

the Euler–Lagrange equations yield the usual fictitious forces.

For example, consider the x–coordinate. The Euler–Lagrange equation is

  d/dt (∂L/∂ẋ) – ∂L/∂x = 0.

Since the standard kinetic part contributes mẋ, and U is velocity–dependent, we have
  ∂L/∂ẋ = mẋ – (∂U/∂ẋ),
and
  ∂L/∂x = –(∂V/∂x) – ∂U/∂x.
A straightforward calculation shows that
  ∂U/∂ẋ = mωy  and  ∂U/∂x = –mωẏ – mω²x.
Thus,
  d/dt (mẋ – mωy) = mẍ – mωẏ,
and then the x–equation becomes
  mẍ – mωẏ + ∂V/∂x + mωẏ + mω²x = 0,
or
  mẍ + ∂V/∂x + mω²x – 2mωẏ = 0.
This is the familiar x–component, with the −2mωẏ being the Coriolis force and –mω²x the centrifugal force. A similar procedure for the y–coordinate yields the corresponding terms.

Step 4. (Final Answer)

Thus we see that, in the rotating coordinate system, the equations of motion are identical to those for a particle in a fixed coordinate system subject to the force –∇V and an extra force derived from the velocity–dependent potential

  U(x, y, ẋ, ẏ) = –mω(xẏ – yẋ) – ½mω²(x² + y²).

The final answer is:

    
    \[
\boxed{U(x,y,\dot{x},\dot{y}) = - m\omega\Bigl(x\dot{y}-y\dot{x}\Bigr) - \frac{1}{2} m\omega^2\,(x^2+y^2)}
\]

We start by noting that the K meson (with rest energy E_K = 494 MeV) decays at rest into a μ meson (rest energy E_μ,rest = 106 MeV) and a nearly mass‐less neutrino (rest energy 0). Conservation of energy requires

  E_K = E_μ + E_ν.

Since the K meson is initially at rest, momentum conservation further gives the two decay products equal and opposite momenta, and so their energies are uniquely determined by the masses. For a two‐body decay, the energy of particle 1 (here, the μ meson) is given by

  E_μ = (m_K² + m_μ² − m_ν²) / (2 m_K).

Since the neutrino’s rest energy is zero (m_ν = 0), we have

  E_μ = (m_K² + m_μ²)/(2 m_K).

Here, we work in units where the energy (MeV) and rest mass energy (MeV) are directly comparable. Substitute the values:

  m_K = 494 MeV,
  m_μ = 106 MeV.

Step 1. Calculate m_K² and m_μ²:
  m_K² = 494² = 244036 MeV²,
  m_μ² = 106² = 11236 MeV².

Step 2. Sum them:
  244036 + 11236 = 255272 MeV².

Step 3. Divide by 2 m_K = 2 × 494 = 988 MeV:
  E_μ = 255272/988 ≈ 258.37 MeV.

Thus the total energy of the μ meson is approximately 258.37 MeV. Its kinetic energy, K_μ, is the total energy minus its rest energy:

  K_μ = E_μ − m_μ = 258.37 MeV − 106 MeV ≈ 152.37 MeV.

Step 4. The neutrino carries the remaining energy. Since the total energy available is 494 MeV, we have
  E_ν = 494 MeV − E_μ ≈ 494 − 258.37 = 235.63 MeV.

For the neutrino the entire energy is kinetic (K_ν = E_ν) since its rest mass is zero.

Thus, the kinetic energies of the decay products are approximately:

  Kinetic energy of the μ meson: 152 MeV
  Kinetic energy of the neutrino: 236 MeV

Finally, we can express the answer in LaTeX boxed format as follows:

\[
\boxed{K_{\mu} \approx 152\,\text{MeV}, \quad K_{\nu} \approx 236\,\text{MeV}}
\]

We are given a 200 GeV/c pion beam. The pion decays according to

  π → μ + ν  (ν is massless).

The pion’s rest lifetime is

  τ₀ = 2.60×10⁻⁸ s

and its rest energy (mass) is

  m_π = 139.6 MeV. 

The muon’s rest energy is

  m_μ = 105.7 MeV.

Because the neutrino is massless, in the pion rest frame its “energy” equals its momentum.

In what follows we will work in “natural” units for the low‐energy numbers (MeV, etc.) while being careful with the very high energy (GeV) pion beam. (Recall that 1 GeV = 1000 MeV.)

We now work through parts (a), (b) and (c) step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Mean distance traveled by the pions

In the rest frame a pion decays after an average time τ₀. In the laboratory the pion’s lifetime is time–dilated by the Lorentz factor

  γ = E/m_π.

Here the pion’s energy in the lab is approximately its momentum (since its rest mass is very small compared to 200 GeV) so:
  E_π ≃ 200 GeV = 200×10³ MeV.
Thus,
  γ = (200×10³ MeV)/(139.6 MeV) ≃ 1433.

Now the mean distance L traveled in the lab is
  L = γ c τ₀.
With c = 3×10⁸ m/s, and τ₀ = 2.60×10⁻⁸ s, we have
  L = 1433 × (3×10⁸ m/s)(2.60×10⁻⁸ s).

First compute cτ₀:
  cτ₀ = 3×10⁸ m/s × 2.60×10⁻⁸ s = 7.8 m.
Then,
  L = 1433 × 7.8 m ≃ 11177 m ≃ 1.12×10⁴ m.
Thus, the pions travel on the order of 11 km on average before decaying.

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Maximum lab angle of the muons

To find the lab angle at which a muon appears relative to the pion direction, we need to “boost” the decay from the pion rest frame into the lab.

1. First, work out the muon momentum in the pion rest frame.

Because the decay is two–body, energies in the pion rest frame are fixed. Conservation of energy gives:
  E_π^* = m_π = E_μ^* + E_ν^*.
Since the neutrino is massless, E_ν^* = p_ν^*. For the muon we have:
  E_μ^* = √((p_μ^*)² + m_μ²).

Standard two–body decay formulas yield the muon energy (see, e.g., any text on two–body decays):
  E_μ^* = (m_π² + m_μ²)/(2 m_π).
Numerically,
  m_π² = (139.6)² ≃ 19488 (MeV)²
  m_μ² = (105.7)² ≃ 11172 (MeV)²,
so that
  E_μ^* = (19488 + 11172)/(2×139.6) MeV = (30660)/(279.2) MeV ≃ 109.8 MeV.
Then the muon momentum in the pion rest frame is
  p_μ^* = √((E_μ^*)² – m_μ²) = √(109.8² – 105.7²) MeV.
Compute the inside:
  109.8² ≃ 12056,
  105.7² ≃ 11172,
so
  p_μ^* = √(12056 – 11172) ≃ √(884) ≃ 29.7 MeV/c.

(One may verify that the neutrino in the pion rest frame has momentum p_ν^* = p_μ^* ≃ 29.7 MeV/c and energy 29.7 MeV.)

2. Next, we “boost” the muon 4–momentum along the direction of the pion (which we take as the z–axis). If in the pion rest frame the muon is emitted at an angle θ* relative to the boost direction, then the lab components are

  p_∥ (lab) = γ (p_μ^* cosθ* + β E_μ^*),
  p_⊥ (lab) = p_μ^* sinθ*,
where β ≃ 1 and γ ≃ 1433.

The lab angle θ_lab is given by
  tan θ_lab = p_⊥ (lab) / p_∥ (lab) = p_μ^* sinθ* / [γ (p_μ^* cosθ* + E_μ^*)].

To find the maximum possible θ_lab we must vary θ*.
Let
  f(θ*) = tan θ_lab = [p_μ^* sinθ*] / [γ (p_μ^* cosθ* + E_μ^*)].
Since γ is huge, the denominator is dominated by E_μ^*. However, for a given p_μ^* and E_μ^*, one can show (by setting the derivative d/dθ* f(θ*) equal to zero) that the maximum occurs when
  E_μ^* cosθ* + p_μ^* = 0  →  cos θ* = – p_μ^*/E_μ^*.
Numerically,
  p_μ^*/E_μ^* ≃ 29.7/109.8 ≃ 0.27.
Thus,
  cosθ* = –0.27  implying  θ* ≃ arccos(–0.27) ≃ 105.7°.
At this optimum, sinθ* = √(1 – (–0.27)²) ≃ √(0.9271) ≃ 0.963.

Now substitute back into the expression for tanθ_lab:

  tanθ_lab^(max) = [29.7×0.963] / [1433×(29.7 cosθ* + 109.8)].
But cosθ* = –0.27, so
  29.7 cosθ* = 29.7×(–0.27) ≃ –8.02 MeV.
Thus, the denominator becomes
  1433×(109.8 – 8.02) = 1433×101.78 ≃ 145800 (in MeV units).
The numerator is
  29.7×0.963 ≃ 28.64 MeV.
Then
  tanθ_lab^(max) ≃ 28.64/145800 ≃ 1.96×10⁻⁴.
Since the angle is very small, θ_lab^(max) ≃ tanθ_lab^(max) in radians; that is,
  θ_lab^(max) ≃ 1.96×10⁻⁴ rad.
In degrees this is roughly (1.96×10⁻⁴)×(180/π) ≃ 0.011°.

Thus the maximum muon angle in the lab is on the order of 2×10⁻⁴ radians.

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Minimum and maximum neutrino momenta in the lab

In the pion rest frame the neutrino is produced with a fixed momentum (and energy) given by conservation. Since the pion decays into two bodies, by momentum conservation in the pion rest frame
  p_ν^* = p_μ^* ≃ 29.7 MeV/c.
Its energy is
  E_ν^* = p_ν^* ≃ 29.7 MeV  (since it is massless).

Now when boosting along the z–axis the neutrino’s lab energy is:
  E_ν (lab) = γ (p_ν^* cosθ* + E_ν^*),
with θ* the angle (in the pion rest frame) between the neutrino momentum and the boost direction.

Because the neutrino is massless its momentum in the lab is just its energy. To find the maximum and minimum lab energies (or momenta) we examine the two extremal cases:

1. Maximum neutrino momentum:
Set θ* = 0 (neutrino emitted in the same direction as the pion). Then
  E_ν^(max) = γ (29.7 + 29.7) MeV = γ×59.4 MeV.
With γ ≃ 1433,
  E_ν^(max) ≃ 1433 × 59.4 MeV ≃ 85100 MeV ≃ 85.1 GeV.
Thus, the maximum neutrino momentum is approximately 85 GeV/c.

2. Minimum neutrino momentum:
Set θ* = π (neutrino emitted opposite to the boost). Then cosπ = –1, and
  E_ν^(min) = γ (–29.7 + 29.7) = 0.
In an ideal two–body decay the extreme “backwards” emission leads to a vanishing energy in the lab. (In practice, because of the finite angular spread and the fact that one is usually interested only in the forward–collimated neutrinos, one might only see neutrinos with appreciable energies. But as far as kinematics is concerned, the minimum allowed momentum is 0.)

Thus,
  p_ν (min) = 0  and  p_ν (max) ≃ 85 GeV/c.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The mean distance traveled by the 200 GeV/c π’s is

  L = γ c τ₀ ≃ 1.12×10⁴ m.

(b) The maximum lab angle at which a muon can be observed relative to the pion direction is

  θₘᵤ^(max) ≃ 2×10⁻⁴ rad (≈ 0.011°).

(c) In the lab the neutrino can have momenta (and hence energies) in the range

  p_ν: 0 ≤ p_ν ≤ ≃ 85 GeV/c.

We wish to determine the ratio of the mean density of the Earth, ρ_E, to that of the Sun, ρ_S, using only some “back‐of‐the‐envelope” data. The data given are

 θ = angular diameter of the Sun as seen from Earth = ½°,
 l = length along Earth’s surface corresponding to 1° of latitude = 100 km,
 t ≈ one year = 3×10^7 s,
 g ≈ 10 m/s².

A very clever way to “extract” the density ratio is to combine the following ideas:
 
1. Use g to get the Earth’s mass (and hence its density) in terms of its radius.
2. Use Kepler’s law (which relates the Earth’s orbital period, t, and its orbital distance, a, to the Sun’s mass) together with the apparent angular size of the Sun (θ) to deduce the Sun’s radius and then its density.
3. Take the ratio ρ_E/ρ_S so that many unknown factors cancel.

Let’s go through the steps.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Density of the Earth

One may estimate the Earth’s mass from its gravitational acceleration. Near the surface one has

  g = GM_E/R_E²    (1)

so that

  M_E = gR_E²/G.

The mean density is defined as

  ρ_E = M_E/[(4π/3) R_E³] = (3M_E)/(4π R_E³).

Thus, substituting for M_E we get
  ρ_E = (3gR_E²/(G))/(4π R_E³) = (3g)/(4π G R_E).    (2)

Now, the Earth’s radius R_E can be estimated from the fact that 1° along a great circle subtends an arc length l. Since an angle of 1° is (π/180) radians we have
  R_E = l/(π/180) = 100 km×(180/π).

Converting 100 km to meters (100 km = 1×10^5 m) gives

  R_E ≈ (1×10^5 m)×(180/π) ≈ (1×10^5×57.3) m ≈ 5.73×10^6 m.
────────────────────────────
Step 2. Density of the Sun

(a) Kepler’s third law tells us that the Earth’s orbit (assumed approximately circular) obeys
  a³ = (G M_S/(4π²)) t²    (3)
or, equivalently, the Sun’s mass is
  M_S = (4π²/G) (a³/t²).

(b) The Sun’s apparent angular diameter as seen from Earth is given as θ = ½°. (This is the full angle; when using the small-angle formula for the radius we must use the half–angle.) Thus, the Sun’s physical radius is
  R_S = a × (θ/2),    (4)
with θ in radians. Since ½° = 0.5° = (0.5×π/180) radians, the half–angle is
  θ_eff = (θ/2) = (0.5/2)° = 0.25° = π/720 radians.

(c) The mean density of the Sun is
  ρ_S = M_S/[(4π/3) R_S³]    (5)

Substitute (3) and (4) into (5):

  ρ_S = { (4π² a³/(G t²)) } / { (4π/3)[a (θ/2)]³ }
     = { (4π² a³/(G t²)) } / { (4π/3)[a (θ_eff)]³ }    [since θ_eff = θ/2].

Cancel the a³:
  ρ_S = (4π²/(G t²)) / { (4π/3)(θ_eff³) } = (4π²/(G t²))×(3/(4π θ_eff³))
     = (3π)/(G t² θ_eff³).    (6)

────────────────────────────
Step 3. The Density Ratio

Now take the ratio ρ_E/ρ_S using (2) and (6):

  ρ_E/ρ_S = [ (3g)/(4π G R_E) ] / [ (3π)/(G t² θ_eff³) ].

Notice that factors of 3 and G cancel. This gives:

  ρ_E/ρ_S = [ g/(4π R_E) ] × [ t² θ_eff³/(π) ]
     = (g t² θ_eff³)/(4π² R_E).    (7)

Remember, θ_eff = π/720.

────────────────────────────
Step 4. Inserting the Numbers

Plug in:
 g = 10 m/s²,
 t = 3×10^7 s,
 θ_eff = π/720,
 R_E ≈ 5.73×10^6 m.

Then
  ρ_E/ρ_S = (10 × (3×10^7)² × (π/720)³) / (4π² × 5.73×10^6).

Compute step‐by‐step:

1. t² = (3×10^7)² = 9×10^14.
2. θ_eff³ = (π/720)³ = π³/(720³). Since 720³ ≈ 3.73×10^8.
3. Numerator = 10 × 9×10^14 × (π³/(3.73×10^8)) = 9×10^15 × π³/(3.73×10^8).
4. Denominator = 4π² × 5.73×10^6.

Thus,
  ρ_E/ρ_S = [9×10^15 π³/(3.73×10^8)] / [4π²×5.73×10^6].

Combine the numbers:
 First, multiply the factors in the denominator: 4π²×5.73×10^6. The product of the non–π numbers is 4×5.73×10^6 = 22.92×10^6.
 Next, write the ratio as
  ρ_E/ρ_S = (9×10^15/3.73×10^8) * (π³/(4π²×5.73×10^6)).

Now, (9×10^15)/(3.73×10^8) ≈ 2.41×10^7.
And the π factors reduce: π³/(4π²) = π/4.
Then we still have the factor 1/(5.73×10^6) in the denominator, so

  ρ_E/ρ_S = [2.41×10^7 × (π/4)]/(5.73×10^6).

Now, 2.41×10^7/(5.73×10^6) ≈ 4.21.
Then multiply by (π/4) ≈ (3.14/4) ≈ 0.785.

Thus,
  ρ_E/ρ_S ≈ 4.21×0.785 ≈ 3.3.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

The mean density of the Earth is about 3.3 times that of the Sun. That is,

  ρ_E/ρ_S ≈ 3.3.

We wish to study a system consisting of a wedge (an “inclined‐plane”) of mass M resting on a horizontal floor (with coefficient static friction μ), with a small block m₂ that slides without friction on the wedge (whose surface is inclined at an angle θ to the horizontal). A mass m₁ hangs vertically and is attached by a light inextensible string that passes over a smooth peg fixed to the wedge’s upper edge and attaches to m₂. (See figure in your text.) In what follows we shall assume that the string remains taut. (Also, note that the motion “chosen” by the system is that in which m₁ moves vertically (say) downward while m₂ moves (relatively) upward along the plane.)

Part (a) asks us to solve for the accelerations of m₁ and m₂ and the string’s tension when the friction between the wedge and the floor is so large that the wedge does not move. (In other words we treat the wedge as fixed.)

──────────────────────────
Step 1. (Wedge fixed: Find a and T)

Since the wedge is not moving, the only dynamics are those of m₁ and m₂. (We assume, of course, that m₁, m₂ are such that the resulting motion is consistent with our choice of directions.) Choose the positive directions so that m₁ has acceleration a downward and m₂ has acceleration a up the plane. Then

(1) For m₁ (moving vertically) the forces are its weight and the tension T. Taking downward to be positive we have
  m₁g − T = m₁a.

(2) For m₂ (on the friction‐free inclined plane) the forces along the incline are the tension T (pulling up the plane, i.e. in the positive direction) and the component of gravity m₂g sinθ (pulling down the plane). Hence,
  T − m₂g sinθ = m₂a.

Add these two equations to eliminate T:
  m₁g − m₂g sinθ = (m₁ + m₂)a.
Thus, the acceleration is
  a = (m₁g − m₂g sinθ)/(m₁ + m₂).      (1)

Then, using (1) in, say, the first equation to obtain T, we have
  T = m₁g − m₁a
    = m₁g − m₁ (m₁g − m₂g sinθ)/(m₁ + m₂)
    = [m₁(m₁ + m₂)g − m₁²g + m₁m₂g sinθ]⁄(m₁ + m₂)
    = [m₁m₂g + m₁m₂g sinθ]⁄(m₁ + m₂)
    = (m₁m₂g(1+ sinθ))/(m₁+m₂).     (2)

Thus, when the wedge is held fixed we obtain

  a = (m₁g − m₂g sinθ)/(m₁+m₂),
  T = (m₁m₂g(1+ sinθ))/(m₁+m₂).

A quick check of the units and limits shows that these answers are acceptable.

──────────────────────────
Step 2. (Wedge free to move: find μmin so that it remains at rest)

Now we wish to know how “sticky” the floor must be—in other words, how large μ must be—so that the wedge remains at rest even though it is being “pushed” by the forces from the dynamics of m₁ and m₂.

Although the wedge does not move, it is subject to horizontal forces that must be balanced by friction from the floor. There are two sources of force on the wedge:
 (a) the contact force from the sliding mass m₂,
 (b) the force transmitted through the peg by the string.

Let us analyze these one by one.

──────────────────────────
2(a) The contact force from m₂

The block m₂ is in contact with the smooth inclined surface of the wedge. Its weight produces a normal force N on the surface. (Because m₂ slides without acceleration normal to the surface – its acceleration is along the plane – we have)
  N = m₂g cosθ.
This normal force acts perpendicular to the surface. (Choose a coordinate system in which the horizontal (x) axis is to the right and the vertical (y) axis is upward. For an incline with its “up‐the–plane” direction making an angle θ with the horizontal, a unit normal (pointing out of the wedge) is
  n = (– sinθ, cosθ).)
By Newton’s third law, m₂ exerts on the wedge the reaction force Fₙ = –N n. That is,
  Fₙ = – m₂g cosθ (– sinθ, cosθ)
     = (m₂g cosθ sinθ, – m₂g cos²θ).     (3)

Notice that the horizontal (x) component of Fₙ is
  (Fₙ)_x = m₂g cosθ sinθ.

──────────────────────────
2(b) The force from the string via the peg

The string passes over a smooth peg fixed to the wedge. (If you imagine “removing” the string and isolating the peg, then by the usual arguments the string exerts on the peg forces along each segment equal to the tension T.) On one side the string is attached to m₁; since m₁ hangs vertically, the string exerts a force of magnitude T on the peg in the vertical direction. On the other side, the string is attached to m₂; since m₂ is on the incline the string along that side is directed along the plane. (More precisely, the string leaves the peg along the line joining the peg to m₂. Since m₂ slides on the plane, this direction is along the plane; it is “down the plane” because m₂ is being pulled upward along the plane by the string.) Thus the two forces on the peg (and hence on the wedge) are:
 • From the m₁ side:  F₁ = T (0, –1)  (i.e. downward)
 • From the m₂ side:  F₂ = T (– cosθ, – sinθ)  (since the unit vector “down the plane” is (– cosθ, – sinθ).)
Thus the net force from the string acting on the peg (and so on the wedge) is
  F_string = F₁ + F₂ = T (– cosθ, – (1+ sinθ) ). 
By Newton’s third law the wedge “feels” the opposite of this, hence
  F_rope = – F_string = T (cosθ, 1+ sinθ).     (4)

Here the horizontal (x) component is
  (F_rope)_x = T cosθ.

──────────────────────────
2(c) Total force on the wedge and the friction condition

The wedge is in contact with a horizontal floor. Let R be the magnitude of the floor’s normal force on the wedge and f be the friction force. (We will see that the net force on the wedge coming from the “internal” connections of m₁ and m₂ has both horizontal and vertical components. The vertical components must be balanced by R. The friction f is the horizontal force that the floor must provide so that the wedge does not accelerate.)

• The total horizontal force Fₓ acting on the wedge is the sum of the x‐components from (3) and (4):
  Fₓ = (T cosθ) + (m₂g cosθ sinθ).     (5)

For the wedge to remain at rest the friction force must be able to counteract this horizontal force. (In the limit, if f_max is the maximum static friction then we require f_max = μ R to be at least Fₓ.)

To find R we need to sum the vertical forces on the wedge. The vertical forces are:
 – The weight of the wedge: M g (downward)
 – The vertical component of F_rope from (4):  T (1+ sinθ) (upward)
 – The vertical component of the contact force from m₂ from (3): – m₂g cos²θ (downward)
 – The floor’s normal reaction R (upward).

Thus, setting upward as positive, vertical force balance gives:
  R + [T(1+ sinθ)] – m₂g cos²θ – M g = 0.
That is,
  R = M g – T(1+ sinθ) + m₂g cos²θ.    (6)

Then the friction condition (that the static friction is just large enough to balance the horizontal force) is
  μ R = Fₓ.
Thus the minimum coefficient of static friction required is
  μ_min = Fₓ/R
so that
  μ_min = [T cosθ + m₂g cosθ sinθ] / [Mg – T(1+ sinθ) + m₂g cos²θ].    (7)

It is best to express this answer entirely in terms of the given parameters. But recall from (2) that
  T = (m₁m₂g(1+ sinθ))/(m₁+m₂).

Thus we may also write
  μ_min = { g cosθ [T/g + m₂ sinθ] } / [Mg – T(1+ sinθ) + m₂g cos²θ]
or, substituting T explicitly,
  μ_min = [ (m₁m₂g(1+ sinθ)/(m₁+m₂)) cosθ + m₂g cosθ sinθ]
      / [Mg – (m₁m₂g(1+ sinθ)/(m₁+m₂)) (1+ sinθ)+ m₂g cos²θ].

One may leave the answer in either form.

──────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) When the wedge is held fixed (μ very large), the acceleration and string tension are

  a = (m₁g – m₂g sinθ)/(m₁ + m₂),
  T = (m₁m₂g (1+ sinθ))/(m₁ + m₂).

(b) In order that the wedge remain at rest the coefficient of static friction must satisfy

  μ ≥ μ_min with
  μ_min = [T cosθ + m₂g cosθ sinθ] / [Mg – T(1+ sinθ) + m₂g cos²θ],
      with T = (m₁m₂g(1+ sinθ))/(m₁+m₂).

We now box the answers.

──────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{ 
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad a &= \frac{m_1g - m_2g\sin\theta}{m_1+m_2},\quad T = \frac{m_1m_2g (1+\sin\theta)}{m_1+m_2},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \mu_{\min} &= \frac{T\cos\theta+m_2g\cos\theta\sin\theta}{Mg-T(1+\sin\theta)+m_2g\cos^2\theta},\quad \text{with } T=\frac{m_1m_2g(1+\sin\theta)}{m_1+m_2}.

We will work through the problem step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Find the impact velocity V₀ and the time to impact.

The diver starts from rest at a height h = 10 m. Ignoring air resistance, energy conservation gives

  Kinetic Energy at impact = Loss in Gravitational Potential Energy  
  ½ mV₀² = mgh    ⇒  V₀ = √(2gh)

Plugging in g ≈ 9.8 m/s² and h = 10 m we obtain

  V₀ = √(2 × 9.8 m/s² × 10 m) = √196 ≈ 14 m/s.

An alternative method to find the time to impact is to use the equation for free fall:

  h = ½ g t²    so  t = √(2h/g) ≈ √(20/9.8) ≈ 1.43 s.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Set up the equation of motion under water and solve for V(x).

Underwater, the buoyant force is assumed to balance the gravitational force. Therefore the only net force is from the viscous drag which we are told is proportional to v². Since the drag force on the diver (acting upward, opposing the downward motion) is b v², the equation of motion is

  m (dv/dt) = – b v².

It is often easier to work with position x (with x = 0 taken at the water surface, and x increasing downward). Since
  dv/dt = (dv/dx)(dx/dt) = v (dv/dx),
we have

  m v (dv/dx) = – b v².

Dividing both sides by v (v ≠ 0) gives

  m (dv/dx) = – b v   ⇒  dv/v = – (b/m) dx.

Integrate both sides from x = 0 (with v = V₀) to a general depth x (with velocity v):

  ∫[V₀ to v] (dv'/v') = – (b/m) ∫[0 to x] dx'.

This yields

  ln(v/V₀) = – (b/m)x   ⇒  v = V₀ exp[ – (b/m)x ].

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Find the depth where the underwater speed has decreased to V₀/10.

We set v = V₀/10 into the result above:

  V₀/10 = V₀ exp[ – (b/m)x ]  
  ⇒ 1/10 = exp[ – (b/m)x ]  
  ⇒ – (b/m)x = ln(1/10) = – ln(10)
  ⇒ x = (m/b) ln(10).

If we are given that b/m = 0.4 m⁻¹ then

  m/b = 1/(b/m) = 1/0.4 = 2.5 m,
  so  x = 2.5 ln(10) ≈ 2.5 × 2.3026 ≈ 5.76 m.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): Solve for the vertical depth x(t) as a function of time under water.

We have from part (b):

  v = dx/dt = V₀ exp[ – (b/m)x ].

This is a separable differential equation. Separate variables to solve for x as a function of t:

  exp[(b/m)x] dx = V₀ dt.

Integrate both sides. Take t = 0 when x = 0:

  ∫[0 to x] exp[(b/m)x'] dx' = ∫[0 to t] V₀ dt'.

The left-hand side integrates as

  ∫ exp[(b/m)x'] dx' = (m/b) exp[(b/m)x'] + C.

So from x'=0 to x,
  (m/b) [exp((b/m)x) – 1] = V₀ t.

Solve for x:

  exp[(b/m)x] = 1 + (b V₀/m)t,
  ⇒ x = (m/b) ln[1 + (bV₀/m)t].

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The diver strikes the water with speed
  V₀ = √(2gh) ≈ 14 m/s,
and the time to impact is
